EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of muck fires which started in May continued to burn into June along the dry lakebed of southwestern Lake Okeechobee near the Glades and Hendry county shoreline. Smoke from these fires periodically closed area roadways.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wildfires burning muck or peat exposed by ongoing dry conditions along the southwestern shore of Lake Okeechobee spread to over 15 miles long from near Lakeport to near Clewiston and covered almost 30,000 acres as of June 1. Multiple road closures occurred nearly every night through the period, especially along US 27 and state roads 720 and 78, as the smoke settled near the ground and caused low visibilities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of muck fires burned along the dry lakebed of southwestern Lake Okeechobee near the Glades and Hendry county shoreline for almost the entire month of May. Smoke from these fires periodically closed area roads and caused an accident involving fatalities in northern Hendry County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wildfires burning muck or peat exposed by ongoing dry conditions along the southwestern shore of Lake Okeechobee spread to over 15 miles long from near Lakeport to near Clewiston and covered almost 30,000 acres as of May 31. Multiple road closures occurred nearly every night through the period, especially along US 27 and state roads 720 and 78, as the smoke settled near the ground and caused low visibilities. Several RVs were also threatened near the Moore Haven Marina & RV Resort.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very dry conditions led to the igniting of a wildfire in western Glades County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire of unknown origin burned over 200 acres in western Glades County in the Muse community. Two homes were burned, and 20 homes had to be evacuated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions helped to spark a wildfire in northern Glades County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Crane Wildfire burned about 5,000 acres in northern Glades County east of U.S. 27. Three outbuildings were damaged. The fire came close to the Brighton Seminole Indian Reservation but did not directly impact that area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions sparked the Hutto Wildfire in Glades County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Hutto Wildfire started two miles east of U.S. 27 and north of State Road 29, burning about 300 acres. A pickup truck was destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions across South Florida allowed a wildfire to burn in Glades County. A wildfire started near LaBelle and burned around 40 acres. The wildfire destroyed two mobile uninhabited mobile homes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hendry County EM reports a 40 acre wildfire in Glades County just north of La Belle. There were no reported injuries or evacuations. FFS Okeechobee District was on-scene and reported that the fire was fully contained. Two uninhabited mobile homes were damaged by the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fire burned 2 acres near the northwest side of Mecca. One firefighter suffered from heat exhaustion.

The Esperanza Fire was intentionally set during the early morning hours of the 26th at the foot of the San Jacinto Mountains near Cabazon. Weather conditions during the onset of the fire were typical of a Santa Ana wind event with gusty east to northeast winds and relative humidity values of less than 10%. Red Flag conditions and abundant dry fuels resulted in the rapid spread of the fire westward through the Banning Pass and up the steep slopes of the San Jacinto Mountains. Observed rates of spread were 20 mph on level terrain and 40 mph where steep terrain and gusty winds aligned. The fire destroyed 34 homes and 20 outbuildings and resulted in an estimated $10.3 million in damage. Five firefighters were overtaken by the flames while trying to protect a house in Twin Pines near Poppet Flats. Three of the firefighters were killed at the scene, the fourth firefighter died while in route to the hospital, and the fifth firefighter died 5 days later at the hospital. The Santa Ana wind event peaked the following day before finally turning onshore with lighter winds and higher humidity on the 29th through the 30th.
No entry
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Creek Fire burned 300 acres of grass and desert brush near the unincorporated community of Snow Creek. No structures were burned and no injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Polk Fire burned 100 acres south of Thermal Airport near Polk Street and Avenue 62. The cause of the Polk Fire was a vehcile fire. There were no reports of damage or injury.

An upper-level trough coupled with a 125 MPH jet max and strong onshore pressure gradients brought light rain and strong winds to Southern California on March 22nd. Gusty winds knocked down trees, freeway signs, and power lines in the mountains and deserts. Two fires were reported during this time, both of which caused damage to structures and trees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vegetation fire fueled by gusty winds spread to a single family home near La Quinta and partially destroyed the roof.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level trough coupled with a 125 MPH jet max and strong onshore pressure gradients brought light rain and strong winds to Southern California on March 22nd. Gusty winds knocked down trees, freeway signs, and power lines in the mountains and deserts. Two fires were reported during this time, both of which caused damage to structures and trees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vegetation fire fueled by gusty winds spread through Lake Cahuilla Park near La Quinta. The fire destroyed playground equipment, an awning of a building, and 35 palm trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 50 acre brush fire in Palm Springs, driven by strong gusty winds, damaged two homes and led to the evacuation of 50 other homes. The fire began in the late afternoon, burning desert scrub near a residential neighborhood. The fire was contained later that evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The fire began in sparse desert brush near a residential neighborhood. Strong, gusty winds spread the fire towards the neighborhood, resulting in the damage of two homes and the evacuation of approximately 50 other homes. No major injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Windy Point fire started around 1753 PST on the 24th, west of the Palm Springs Tramway in steep, rocky terrain. During the firefight, State Highway 111 was closed in both directions. The fire burned 541 acres before being fully contained around 1700 PST on the 26th. At no time were any structures damaged or threatened and despite the rocky terrain, no injuries occurred.

The Pierce Fire began around 1537 PST on the 15th near the intersection of Avenue 66 and Pierce Street in Thermal. Initially reported at 10 acres, the fire burned at a moderate rate of spread through medium to heavy brush, increasing rapidly to 200 acres over just a few hours. Road closures were in effect along north and southbound Highway 86 between Avenue 86 and Avenue 80, as well as Avenue 66 from Avenue 86 to Pierce Street. The fire burned a total of 350 acres before being fully contained at 2234 PST on the 15th. The fire downed power lines in the area and destroyed one outbuilding. No injuries to firefighters or civilians were reported.

A fire broke out at the Torres Martinez Desert Cahuilla Reservation in the Coachella Valley on June 23rd. Seven homes were destroyed and the fire affected 30 tribal members in total. Members were displaced from their homes and lost all of their possessions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Martinez Fire broke out around 1400 PST on June 23rd. Dry conditions and temperatures in the 120s helped exasperate the fire. Seven homes were destroyed. Approximately 30 tribal members were displaced from their homes and lost nearly all of their possessions. Three firefighters suffered minor injuries in the blaze.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Martinez Fire broke out on the Torres Martinez Reservation in Mecca around 1400 PST on July 23rd. Seven homes were destroyed and 30 tribal members were displaced. Three firefighters suffered minor injuries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Martinez Fire broke out around 1400 PST on July 23rd. Dry conditions and temperatures in the 120s helped exasperate the fire. Seven homes were destroyed. Approximately 30 tribal members were displaced from their homes and lost nearly all of their possessions. Three firefighters suffered minor injuries in the blaze.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This fire was named the Mail Draw Fire and occurred on BLM property 25 miles northeast of Vernal. The fire consumed 2,800 acres of timber, pinyon pine, juniper, and sage brush. The estimated cost of fighting the fire was 915 thousand dollars.
This wildfire was named the McConkie Ranch Fire and occurred 13 miles northwest of Vernal on BLM public lands. The fire consumed approximately 368 acres of logging slash and juniper.

This incident was named the Pot Hole Fire and occurred about 25 miles northeast of Vernal. About 1,398 acres of sagebrush, grass, and timber were consumed by the blaze. Several residences were threatened by the fire.
A wildfire began from unknown causes 18 miles northwest of Vernal on a mix of private, Bureau of Land Management and U.S. Forest Service lands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pine Ridge Fire began from unknown causes 18 miles northwest of Vernal and grew to a total of 519 acres before it was contained.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire that was likely ignited by humans, burned in the extreme northeast corner of Utah near the intersection of the Utah, Wyoming and Colorado borders.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bender Mountain Fire that was likely ignited by humans, burned in the extreme northeast corner of Utah. The fire grew to 4,116 acres before it was contained.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm temperatures in combination with low relative humidity values, resulted in conditions favorable for wildfire starts in southern South Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The South Carolina Forestry Commission reported a 100 acre wildfire near Shulerville, South Carolina.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small wildfire developed following a prescribed burn in the afternoon hours. Conditions were warm and dry and the wildfire developed overnight. The wildfire spread toward a residential area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 25 acre wildfire occurred on Frost Lane in Huger, within the Francis Marion National Forest. The fire threatened multiple homes in the area, but no property damage occurred. One male victim sustained burns over 70 percent of his body while trying to contain the fire using a tractor.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire burned in a sparsely populated area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire started east of I-40 between Sidbury and Holly Shelter Road and burned 1200 acres of sparsely populated land. No structures were damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry fuels, combined with windy conditions, caused a wildfire in western Pender County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A fire broke containment near Shiloh Road west of Highway 421 near Atkinson and quickly grew to 300 acres.  The fire eventually burned over 1500 acres in a two day period before it was contained.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary front across Alabama and Georgia combined with high pressure over the Florida Keys to produce hot and breezy west winds across East Central Florida. On May 11th winds gusted from 30 to 40 mph and high temperatures were in the 90s. Wind gusts subsided to about 25 mph on May 12 and 15 mph on May 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong westerly winds gusting to near 40 mph and high temperatures on May 11th began a four day fire event in Brevard County. The greatest damage occurred around and near the communities of Palm Bay and Malabar. Fire damage also occurred near the town of Cocoa. In all 162 homes were damaged or destroyed and over 10,000 acres burned. There were three minor injuries to fire fighters. Interstate 95 in Brevard County was shut down by smoke on numerous occasions. Damage was over 16 million dollars.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire damaged multiple structures in the Maytown area in Volusia County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire burned over 2400 acres and damaged multiple structures in a wooded, rural area of  Maytown. The damaged structures included 1 trailer, 1 other structure, 10 outbuildings and more than 13 hunting camps. The fire was suspected to have re-ignited from a previous fire. Most of the structural damage occurred on June 13, however, the wildfire was not fully contained until late June.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm with frequent cloud-to-ground lightning affected Deleon Springs during the evening of July 6 and started a late evening wildfire which grew overnight.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm with frequent cloud-to-ground lightning affected Deleon Springs during the evening of July 6. This lightning ignited a wildfire around midnight in the Lake Woodruff National Wildlife Refuge. The total area burned by mid morning July 7 was reported to be around 1200 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Red Flag Warning was issued for Oregon fire weather zones 618/691/620 for expected strong winds and poor recoveries, effective at the above listed time interval.  The winds did blow, but recoveries were much better than expected, so the warning did not verify.
No entry
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire near SW 177th Avenue and U.S. 41 caused the closure of the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large wildfire which began in mid-May burned over the Everglades of western Miami-Dade County until it was declared 100% contained as of June 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mustang Corner Fire started on May 14th and continued |until June 4th when it was declared 100% contained. The fire burned a total of 39,465 acres in the Everglades National Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large wildfire burned over the Everglades of western Miami-Dade County during the latter half of May. The fire known as the Mustang Corner Wildfire, got to within 3-5 miles of the far western edge of the Miami metropolitan area but did not damage any structures. The fire  prompted dense smoke advisories for the Miami Metropolitan area from May 17th to May 21st as dense smoke moved into the area during the night and early morning hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mustang Corner Fire started during the morning of 14th and continued through the remainder of the month of May. The fire burned 39,465 acres in the Everglades National Park. The fire also prompted the evacuation of some 1,753 prisoners and 250 employees from the Everglades Correctional facility and 535 detainees from the Krome Detention Center as the fire closed within ten miles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large grass fire ignited on a farm and burned equipment and 20 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire broke out near Southwest 227th Avenue and Southwest 232nd Street in the Redland area of western Miami-Dade County, covering about 20 acres and threatening a home before being extinguished. The fire consumed 20 acres of a 30 acre farm, two vehicles, and some farm equipment.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small brush/wildfire developed in the Tamiami Pinelands Park area in the afternoon. The fire quickly spread causing damage to two vehicles. Smoke produced very low to no visibility in the area at the time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple media reports of the a wildfire in Tamiami Pinelands Park. The fire quickly spread causing damage to 3 cars in the adjacent area to the park. The total acreage of the fire is unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Red flag warning conditions developed behind a late season dry arctic front.  The offshore, downslope flow and extremely dry atmosphere (dewpoints near zero) combined with sufficiently dry flashy fuels (grasses) near sea level to heighten the wildfire danger throughout Southeast Alaska.  A total of five small grass fires (1 acre or less) were reported in the Haines, Juneau and Wrangell areas.  No damage nor injuries occurred though our fire departments were called into action for grass fires about month earlier than normal.

A small brush fire increased in size as high winds moved through the Yakima Valley.  The fire threatened several homes in West Yakima.  There were no injuries, but an estimated $3,000 damage was done to plants.
A 400 acre wildfire east of Toppenish.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This wildfire burned 400 acres 9 miles east of Toppenish.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning started the Dry Creek Complex Fire from 6 miles north of Sunnyside to the  Columbia River.  It burned 49,000 acres from August 20 to August 24. Strong winds up to 40 mph occurred during the fire. A manufactured home and cafe were destroyed.
A wind whipped fire destroyed a home near Outlook.

A fast moving cold front brought high winds. Peak wind gusts in miles per hour included Hanford Emergency Ops Center (72), Gable Mountain (71), Yakima Barricade (77), Hanford (61), Rattlesnake Springs (69), Hanford 200 West (71), Hanford Army Loop (69), Vernita Bridge (78), Richland Airport (58). Tree branches up to 1.5 inches in diameter were downed by the winds 8 miles west northwest of Connell.  A wildfire in White Swan, fanned by the high winds up to 69 mph, was carried from a house to a logging mill and into the town. The wildfire burned 20 homes.  A trailer was blown over west of Ellensburg.

High winds caused multiple power failures for 1800 customers in the Tieton area.  The first outage was around 11 am due to downed power lines and the second was around 4 pm.  The wind also fanned a spontaneous combustion wildfire at the Boise Cascade mill site in Yakima.
Winds to 30 mph caused a wildfire to grow rapidly in southeast Yakima County.  The fire near Konnowac Pass grew to 1200 acres.
A neighbor's grinding tool sent sparks into a yard which started a grass fire which then spread into the house.

The Range 12 Fire started on Saturday evening around 7:00pm, July 30, 2016. The fire moved from the Yakima Training Center onto BLM, state and private lands. Wind driven fire quickly grew into sage and grass. The fire is currently (Aug 5th) 95% contained, but has covered over 176,600 acres.

The Range 12 Fire started on Saturday evening around 7:00pm, July 30, 2016. The fire moved from the Yakima Training Center onto BLM, state and private lands. Wind driven fire quickly grew into sage and grass.
On July 2, 2017, a grass and brush fire was reported approximately 30 miles northwest of Richland, WA. The fire reached 30,984 acres in size in Yakima and Benton counties.

A large wildfire burned amid the grass and sagebrush of the military's Yakima Training Center in Washington state. The fire grew to 50 square miles (129 square kilometers) by Friday morning, but was not threatening any structures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A fire burned 24,650 acres of grass and sagebrush on the Army's Yakima Training Center in Yakima county.  Fire increased rapidly on the 20th due to gusty winds.  A brief evacuation order was issued for 225 members of the Wanapum village near the Priest Rapids Dam.  No structures were damaged or lost.  Fire was 99% contained by late on the 24th or early on the 25th.  Spot forecasts were provide by NWS PDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A grass and brush fire burned in urban/rural interface are north of Selah Washington in late July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Selah Fire Department responded to a reported fire on the LT Murray State Wildlife area near Sheep Company Road.  Upon arrival emergency responders observed active fire behavior fueled by grass and brush with 10 mile per hour wind pushing the fire to the south.  Early morning hours of July 24 saw the winds calm which aided in the successful construction of hand and dozer line that curtailed the spread of the fire keeping it north of Huntzinger Road and east of Sheep Company Road.  20 to 30 homes were initially threatened and residents were advised to evacuate.  No homes were damaged; residents have returned to their homes and evacuation levels are now level 1.  Fire was 75 percent contained by early morning on the 25th with 1,771 acres burned.  No more updates on fire were available after the 25th and estimated fire contained by the 26th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Glade Creek fire occurred south of Mabton in Yakima county Washington.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Glade Creek fire burned in grass, sagebrush and wheat stubble south of Mabton in Yakima county.  The fire burned a total of 12,765 acres.  No structures were threatened and no evacuations were needed.  Total cost of fighting the fire was around $300,000.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Conrad Fire burned near Naches in Yakima county Washington.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Conrad Fire in Yakima has burned 5,354 acres as of 10:00 a.m. on Tuesday the 3rd. Washington Department of Natural Resources officials said the fire is 85% contained. On Sunday evening, the 1st, nearly 50 homes in the area of Box Canyon and Conrad roads were evacuated. WADNR said no structures are threatened as of the 3rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The HWY 24 Command fire occurred at the east end of the Moxee Valley, approximately 17 miles east of Yakima.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The HWY 24 Command fire burned in grass and brush along and north of Washington State Highway 24 in northeast Yakima county.  The fire burned approximately 1,800 acres, and prompted road and local area closures.  Cause of the fire is still unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Mile Marker 44 fire burned in tall grass west of Highway 97 in southern Yakima county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mile Marker 44 fire burned in tall grass west of U.S. Highway 97 in southern Yakima county Washington.  This fire affected approximately 3,000 acres of open and rugged terrain.  No known structures were threatened.  Location was roughly 17 miles southwest of Toppenish WA.  The cause of this fire is still under investigation.  Information from NIFC daily reports.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The HWY 24 Command fire occurred at the east end of the Moxee Valley, approximately 17 miles east of Yakima.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The HWY 24 Command fire burned in grass and brush along and north of Washington State Highway 24 in northeast Yakima county. The fire burned approximately 1,800 acres, and prompted road and local area closures. Cause of the fire still unknown.  Fire was suppressed and 60 percent contained on 8/1/18 with no further updates after that date.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Meninick Pass fire burned short grass and sagebrush in Yakima county, Washington.  The fire was located roughly 10 miles west of Toppenish and 5 miles west of White Swan.  This fire was started by lightning and burned a total of 5,537 acres.
No entry
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Southwest winds of 25 to 45 mph spread a wildfire across rural Pottawattamie east of Oakland and Carson.  The blaze swept across 4,000 acres, destroyed 4 homes and many outbuildings, and left about a dozen people homeless.  Total damage was reported at one million dollars.  Two firefighters were treated at a Council Bluffs hospital for smoke inhalation and were released.  The fire evidently spread from a tree stump that was still smoldering from being burnt several days earlier.  The fire's containment was greatly aided by farmers who began plowing fields under ahead of the blaze.  The fire was first reported around 1 pm and was contained around 7 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A forest fire in Wharton State Forest, when discovered at about 9:00 AM EDT on the 20th, covered about 30 acres in Waterford Township in Camden County. The fire, fanned by brisk winds of 20 to 25 mph, spread to 325 acres mainly in the Camden County part of the state forest. No homes were in danger. Wind-whipped embers caused spot fires east of the Mullica River in Shamong Township (Burlington County). These were quickly extinguished. The blaze was reported to be under control at 9:30 PM EDT on the 20th. The cause of the fire was not known. It appeared to have ignited about one mile east of the raceway on Old Atsion Road. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) had temporary flight restrictions for three square miles of airspace around the fire. The Hammonton Airport was closed so the fire service could fly its aircraft in and out unimpeded. No rain since April 8th, low humidity levels and sporadic high winds contributed to the rapid spread of the fire. The unseasonably dry weather caused the Forestry Service to declare Stage 1 campfire restrictions in effect, with no fires on the ground unless they are in a prepared fire ring.

A forest fire started in Wharton State Forest in Washington Township on the afternoon of August 3rd. It burned 2,443 acres in Washington and Shamong Townships before it was contained. It was spotted in the air by a New Jersey Forestry Service helicopter at 250 p.m. EDT. It started near a dirt road about a mile off of U.S. Route 206 in Washington Township and was believed to have been the work of an arsonist. The fire jumped the Mullica River and spread into Shamong Township quickly. No homes, camping or recreational facilities were threatened. But, U.S. Route 206 was sporadically closed from the 3rd into the morning of the 5th between U.S. Route 30 in Atlantic County and either Tuckertown Road (County Route 620) or County Route 541 in Burlington County. The fire briefly jumped across U.S. Route 206 near Atsion Lake in Shamong Township. As a precaution, the Atsion Lake recreational area, the Mullica and Lower Forge Camping areas and canoeing sites on the Mullica and Batsto Rivers were closed until the fire was completely contained. The fire was contained at 8 a.m. EDT on the 6th. About an inch of rain that fell overnight assisted the fire fighters. No injuries or property damage was reported.

A lightning strike helped ignite a fire that burned 8 acres of woodland in Shamong Township. The lightning struck a tree and ignited dry leaves, pine needles and underbrush in Wharton State Forest. The fire was five miles off of U.S. Route 206. The fire smoldered for about twenty-four hours before it was spotted. About thirty fire fighters helped extinguish the blaze. The fire was tough to fight because of the swampy ground around it. The fire was contained on the 29th. No homes or campers were threatened.

The Sauder Ditch Wildfire, consumed about 1950 acres of forest before it was contained. The fire began in a secluded section of Wharton State Forest in Waterford Township (Camden County) close to 3 p.m. EDT on the 21st. This location is west of U.S. Route 206 and south of the Atsion Recreational Area. It spread into parts of Shamong Township (Burlington County) and Hammonton Township (Atlantic County). ||Gusty northwest winds along with recent dry weather helped spread the fire quickly and hampered fire fighting efforts on the 21st and 22nd. A state of emergency was declared in Shamong Township (Burlington County) on the 21st and lifted on the 22nd. About four homes and two businesses on U.S. Route 206 in Hammonton (Atlantic County) were evacuated because of fear of smoke and the fire itself on the 21st. They were allowed to return at Noon EDT on the 22nd. ||The fire reached up to 100 feet in the air and was visible from Atlantic City. Smoke was smelled as far away as Ocean County. The heavily traveled U.S. Route 206 was closed between the White Horse Pike (U.S. Route 30) in Hammonton and Atsion Lake (Shamong Township) after the fire jumped the roadway on the evening of the 21st. The roadway had sporadic closures, especially at night when the smoke became thicker, through the 25th.||About 200 fire fighters battled the blaze and used brush trucks, helicopters, bull dozers and air tankers in their efforts. Water was retreived from nearby Atsion Lake. The fire was considered twenty percent contained on the 21st, forty percent contained on the 22nd, fifty percent contained on the 23rd, seventy percent contained on the 24th, ninety percent contained on the 26th and fully contained on the morning of the 27th. A firefighter suffered an irregular heart beat from battling the blaze and one traffic cop was struck by a vehicle. ||On the morning of the 24th, an atmospheric inversion caused by a nearby high pressure system trapped the smoke near the ground. This caused thick smoke with near zero visibilities to affect Hammonton (Atlantic County) and Winslow (Camden County). All Hammonton schools were closed and the White Horse Pike (U.S. Route 30) in Hammonton and Winslow was closed. The New Jersey Motor Vehicle inspection center was closed in Winslow. Several asthmatics were treated at Cooper Hospital.||Heavy rain on the 25th helped fire fighting efforts. The peak wind gusts at Atlantic City International Airport were 37 mph on the 21st and 35 mph on the 22nd. At Atlantic City International Airport (Prior to the 25th when 1.13 inches of rain fell.) only 0.16 of an inch of rain had  fallen during the month of October.

A lightning strike on the 25th started a wildfire within the Bass River State Forest in Burlington County. The wildfire occurred within a swampy area north of Dan Bridge Road in Bass River Township. The fire was first spotted on the 26th and caused the evacuation of about twenty-two families that were within the camp site and recreation area. The park was reopened on the 27th. The wildfire also forced the closures of Stage Road between the Garden State Parkway and Burlington County Route 679 and East Greenbush Road between U.S. Route 9 and Stage Road. The smoke was visible as far away as Atlantic County. The fire was considered 30 percent contained on the evening of the 26th, 60 percent contained on the afternoon of the 27th and fully contained on the 29th. Approximately 677 acres were consumed by the wildfire.
A lightning strike started a wildfire in Wharton State Forest off of U.S. Route 206 in Shamong Township. Approximately 152 acres were consumed before it was contained.

A lightning strike started a wildfire in Wharton State Forest off of U.S. Route 206 in Shamong Township. Approximately 171 acres were consumed before it was contained. The fire was initially spotted just before 7 a.m. EDT east of U.S. Route 206 near Atsion Lake behind the Atsion Ranger station. The swampy terrain made it cumbersome to battle the blaze. The fire was about forty percent contained on the morning of the 28th. Heavier rain later that day helped to contain the fire. About 50 firefighters battled the blaze. No property was in danger, but a state campground about seven miles from the blaze was closed.

The unseasonably dry weather coupled with strong winds helped quickly spread two wildfires on the 9th in central Burlington County. The South Park fire started just after Midnight EDT on the 9th in Woodland Township in Burlington County near South Park and Sooy Roads. Most of it occurred on the grounds of the South Park Hunting Club. The strong winds helped spread the fire quickly.  It was suspected that gypsy moth tree damage also contributed to the rapid spread of  the fire.  Air resources were used to battle the blaze. Over 250 local and state forestry fire fighters helped battle the blaze. At 8 a.m. EDT on the 9th, the fire was partially contained and already burned 400 acres.  Sections of Sooy Road and South Park Roads were closed in Tabernacle and Woodland Townships. Helicopters were used by the State Forest Fire Service to battle the blaze and plow lines had been established behind the houses on Sooy Place Road.  Controlled burns have been completed to reduce the threat of property damage. Overnight on the 9th, the fire did not grow due to the lower temperatures, increased humidity, and subsiding winds.  The fire reached about 50 percent containment.  On noon on the 10th,  the wildfire reached 75 percent containment.  It was expected to consume about 1000 acres before total containment was reached.|  |A second wildfire occurred on the Fort Dix Military Installation, near the Burlington and Ocean County border on the 9th. It was totally contained on the 10th. The fire started on Training Ranges 13 and 14. Fortunately, the wind was spreading the fire toward a controlled burn area.  With the assistance of three other fire companies, Joint Base fire personnel extinguished the blaze and there were no reported injuries or damage.  The fire consumed about 300 acres. ||Other smaller wildfires also occurred in Monroe Township (Middlesex County) on Disbrow Road on the afternoon of the 9th and in West Windsor Township (Mercer County) off Meadow Road.  In all, there were thirty-three reported wildfires throughout the state of New Jersey on the 9th. Because of the increased fire weather risk, the New Jersey Forestry Service went to Stage III restrictions on camp fires south of the Raritan River. All fires in wooded areas were now prohibited unless contained within an elevated stove.

A wildfire began during the afternoon of the 5th and before it was contained on the evening of the 6th scorched about 300 acres along the Camden and Burlington County line in the Wharton State Forest in Waterford and Shamong Townships.  The fire could be seen as far away as Atlantic City. The wildfire was believed to have started as a small brush fire in the Goshen Pond Camping Area within the state forest off of Atsion Road and the Raritan Avenue Spur.  By the middle of the day on the 6th, it was ninety percent contained.  About forty firefighters battled the blaze in this remote area off of U.S. Route 206. Aggressive bulldozer lines and back fires were undertaken to mitigate and bring the fire under containment.  Some traffic control was required along U.S. Route 206 and Jackson Road. No property was damaged or serious injuries reported.

A wildfire that that started within the Wharton State Forest in Shamong Township (Burlington County) on the night of the 6th consumed about 150 acres of woodland. The fire started deep within the woods in an unpopulated area off of Carranza Road near the Tabernacle Township border. It was first reported at 7 p.m. EDT on the 6th. Tufts of smoke and smoldering logs could be seen in the woods near Carranza Road in Tabernacle on the morning of the 7th. The wildfire did not damage any homes and was 75 percent contained on the 7th. ||In Washington Township in Morris County on the 7th firefighters battled a brush fire for about two hours that included a forest fire airplane to help drop water on it to contain the blaze. The fire started behind homes on Naughtright Road but spread up a hill, away from the houses. Five separate fire companies helped battle the blaze. In all 42 separate wildfires consumed 182 acres on the weekend of April 6th and 7th in the state. The first nine days of April 2013 had a dry start with less than half an inch of precipitation falling throughout most of the state.

A wildfire consumed approximately 1,600 acres of forest in Wharton State Forest in Washington Township (Burlington County) until it was contained.  The wildfire started on the afternoon of the 6th. A wind shift and increase in overall wind speed associated with the passage of a sea breeze front around 5 p.m. EDT that afternoon helped spread the fire faster. Aviation resources were used to help battle the blaze as the fire was located in an extremely remote area of the state forest and resources were having trouble accessing the fire area due to poor road conditions. The wildfire was about 30 percent contained at 930 p.m. EDT on the 6th.  Due to the wind shift from the sea breeze front and then the overall synoptic scale easterly flow, the smoke from the wildfire could be smelled throughout Burlington and Ocean Counties. Cooler and moister conditions coupled with afternoon rain on the 7th helped the New Jersey Forest Fire Service achieve 100 percent containment of the wildfire at 4 p.m. EDT that afternoon.||At the opposite end of the state, a few smaller wildfires occurred in Sussex County from the 6th into the night of the 7th. The largest was a 75 acre wildfire on a mountain ridge behind an A&P Supermarket on County Route 515 in Vernon Township. Forty firefighters battled the blaze and water from Highland Lake was used to extinguish it. Smaller brush fires charred 9 acres along U.S. Route 206 in Byram Township. Other brush fires occurred along State Route 15 in Sparta Township and Twin Oaks Road in Stillwater Township.

A wildfire consumed about 250 acres of forest in the Wharton State Forest in Shamong Township off of Stokes Road (County Route 541) on the 25th. The wildfire was first spotted at 930 a.m. EDT that morning and was contained at Noon EDT on the 26th. Overall lighter southeast winds which also raised humidity levels and overnight rain helped with containment efforts. No evacuations were necessary.

A large wildfire consumed 710 acres of forest within Shamong Township in Burlington County on the 7th and 8th. The wildfire started about 1 p.m. EDT on the 7th near the intersection of U.S. Route 206 and Quaker Bridge Road in Shamong Township. The thick smoke conditions forced the closure of U.S. Route 206 between U.S. Route 30 and Atsion Road that afternoon. Evacuations were recommended in Shamong Township for homes between Stokes Road (County Route 541) and Atsion Road on the east side of U.S. Route 206. The fire occurred in a very inaccessible area that did have a wildfire in over 80 years. Helicopters took water from Atsion Lake to battle the blaze. The fire was 50 percent contained on the evening of the 7th and U.S. Route 206 was re-opened.  Because of an inversion and a light east to southeast wind, smoke was smelled as far west as Bucks County in Pennsylvania. Dense fog on the morning of the 8th helped stopped the spread of the wildfire and it was 75 percent contained that morning.  The wildfire was 100 percent contained later that day. No property was damage and no serious injuries were reported. While the wind was not strong on the 7th, the recent very dry weather (Only nine hundredths of an inch of rain had fallen at Atlantic City International Airport since April 23rd) and inaccessibility made it easier for this wildfire to spread.

A wildfire consumed 1,012 acres of woodland along the Burlington and Ocean County borders from September 7th through the 9th. The wildfire coincided with the last run of 90 degree weather in the state for the year. The Woodmansie Wildfire started in that section of Woodland Township shortly after Noon EDT on the 7th and then spread eastward into Manchester Township in Ocean County. About ninety percent of the acreage that was burned was within this township. The wildfire was contained at Noon EDT on the 9th. ||The wildfire occurred during the last hot spell of the year and what was becoming overall drier conditions. No measurable rain fell in the southern half of New Jersey since August 21st. The high temperature of 94 degrees in Trenton (Mercer County) on the 8th tied a couple of other days during the summer for the highest temperature of the year.  The unseasonably hot start to the month made it easier for the state of New Jersey to have one of its warmest Septembers on record. Since 1895 it was the second warmest September on record for the state with an average temperature of 70.7 degrees (4.9 degrees above normal).  At the Atlantic City International Airport (Atlantic County), the September monthly average temperature of 71.6 degrees (4.4 degrees above normal) was the 6th warmest September on record and in Trenton (Mercer County), the September average temperature of 71.5 degrees was 5.3 degrees above average.

On March 30, a wildfire ignited in the Penn State Forest region within the Pinelands of Burlington County, NJ. The source of the fire was non-meteorological, but gusty southerly winds helped to cause rapid fire spread. The fire was most intense the afternoon, evening, and overnight of March 30, before a cold front with widespread showers helped with containment efforts on March 31. By the time the fire was fully contained, more than 11,000 acres of forest had burned. Smoke plumes traveled northward, and a low level inversion led to numerous reports of the smell of smoke in areas north of the fire region. Smoke plumes relating to this fire were reported in METAR observations from multiple large New York City area airports on the morning of the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reference the episode narrative for a summary of events. The start time of the fire is approximated. Fire continued burning early on April 1, but was considered contained the prior evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: No entry
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous grass fires were reported across Yankton County as strong winds combined with dry weather conditions and dry vegetation. The fires burned mainly in fields, with several along railroad tracks. No reports of damage amounts were received.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Mule Peak Fire, centered 19 miles ESE of Union, was a lightning caused fire which burned 1400 acres.  The fire continued to burn into the month of August.
The Mule Peak Fire, centered 19 miles ESE of Union, was a lightning caused fire which burned 1400 acres.  The fire started on July 28th.
The Rinehart Road Fire, centered 15 miles northeast of La Grande, burned 670 acres.
The Thief Valley Fire, centered four miles ENE of North Powder, was a lightning sparked fire that burned 240 acres.
Abundand lightning and dry vegetation caused several large wildfires in eastern Oregon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: No entry
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wildfire destroyed 20 acres of a grain field in the Michaud Creek area of the Arbon Valley east of American Falls.  Fire contained after an hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stubble and brush fire burned 12 acres in Fort Hall.  Four homes were evacuated.  No damage occurred.

Several fires made up the Fort Hall Complex believed to have been started by dry lightning early in the morning on September 4th.   The fires were comprised fo the Rattlesnake fire in Arbon Valley.  The Sawmill and Putnam fires east of Fort Hall as well as the Yandell fire northeast of Fort Hall.  The Rattlesnake Fire forced the evacuation of three homes and caused closures on Arbon Valley Road, Trail Creek Road and Simplot Road on September 4th.  The fire burned about 20,000 acres including 6,120 acres of Fort Hall Indian Reservation land,   2,218 acres of BLM land, 1,831 acres of private land, and 549 acres of Forest Service Land.  The fort Hall Complex was considered 100 percent contained by September 12th at an estimated cost of 3.3 million dollars.
Crystal fire burned 220,042 acres of grass and brush northwest of American Falls.  No property damage was reported.

The Howard wildfire begain on June 17th in the hills just to the southwest of the city of Pocatello.  The 1,650 acre grass and brush fire was considered contained on June 21st.  No buildings or sturctures were damaged.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Howard wildfire just to the southwest of the city of Pocatello began on June 17th and was contained on June 21st.  The fire burned 1,650 acres of grass and brush in the hills just west of the city.  No structures were damaged by the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An 800 acre wildfire began August 10th in the Cedar Creek area 15 miles east of Blackfoot.  The fire got to within a half mile of the Aldridge Post Office and School House on Blackfoot River Road but no damage was caused by the fire.  It was contained on August 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Three fires which were all man made occurred in Bannock County.  One was near the Power County border near West Siphon Road and started on a salvage yard and high winds pushed it through 20 acres of land burning cars, propane tanks.  In Chubbuck a fire started between Ward and Laurel Drives and two unoccupied homes were destroyed in the quarter acre fire.  It also got into an industrial yard burning a fence and pallets.  In Pocatello a brush fire covered 60 acres off of Sunrise Way and Satterfield Drive.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three fires which were all man made occurred in Bannock County.  One was near the Power County border near West Siphon Road and started on a salvage yard and high winds pushed it through 20 acres of land burning cars, propane tanks.  In Chubbuck a fire started between Ward and Laurel Drives and two unoccupied homes were destroyed in the quarter acre fire.  It also got into an industrial yard burning a fence and pallets.  In Pocatello a brush fire covered 60 acres off of Sunrise Way and Satterfield Drive.   The fire cost fire departments $25,000 and Bannock County was declared a disaster area at 6 pm MDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 50 acre wildfire began just east of exit 80 off of interstate 15 near Fort Hall on June 19th.  The fire began at 6 pm EDT and threatened homes and area structires.  the fire was contained at 8 pm and was in total control by June 20th.

The fire was about 1100 acres and grew nearly 1000 acres on July 1st due to swirling and gusty winds.   Only one home was evacuated due to the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An overall dry first part of February, combined with gusty winds, led to several wildfires within United States Forest Service land.  All of the wildfires were human caused.  Between February 12th and February 14th, three wildfires were observed, one in Union, another in Chattooga, and a third in Putnam counties.  These three fires combined consumed two acres and resulted in $2,400 in damages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The U.S. Forest Service reported a wildfire in the Dry Creek area.  The fire was human caused.  It consumed 1.0 acre and resulted in $1,200 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: While the majority of the wild fires occurred during the first part of the month, three additional wild fires were observed during the later half of the month.  Again, these were all human caused.  The most significant wildfire of the month occurred during this period in Walker county on March 22nd, resulting in $10,000 in damages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire, labeled Narrows, burned 0.50 acres.  The fire was human caused.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: While the majority of the wild fires occurred during the first part of the month, three additional wild fires were observed during the later half of the month.  Again, these were all human caused.  The most significant wildfire of the month occurred during this period in Walker county on March 22nd, resulting in $10,000 in damages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A second wildfire, labeled Gore, was observed in Chattooga county.  This fire burned 3.9 acres.  As with the others, this fire was human caused.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Outside of significant rainfall the last week of October, mostly dry conditions prevailed throughout much of September, October, and the early part of November.  Temperatures were generally above normal during most of this period as well.  Two human-caused wildfires were reported in north Georgia during November.  These occurred as follows:||(a).  Veterans in Chattooga County - 11/11/10:1500 LT to 11/11/10:1800 LT burning 6.5 acres.|(b).  Lake in Fannin County - 11/13/10:1415 LT to 11/13/10:1530 LT burning 1/4 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Georgia Forestry Commission reported that human-caused wildfire labeled Veterans burned 6.5 acres and resulted in $10,000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a very wet fall and winter, rainfall during the March and April period fell below normal in many areas, especially the north part of the state.  Wildfires were on the increase during April 2010 with several human caused wildfires reported by the Georgia Forestry Commission during the month.  Wildfires were reported in Gilmer, Chattooga, Fannin, Union, and Murray counties.  The most significant wildfire during the month was actually the result of a T9 military aircraft crash in Fannin county just east of Blue Ridge.  This incident fueled a 23 acre wild fire in the forests just east of Blue Ridge.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Georgia Forestry Commission reported a human-caused wildfire in the Narrows area of Chattooga county.  The fire burned 11 acres resulting in estimated damages of $8,300.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front moved through the area on the 18th and 19th, bringing scattered showers to the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Rough Creek burned 0.1 acres and resulted in $100 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very dry airmass continued in place with strong surface high pressure dominating over the Southeast.  High fire danger conditions continued on the 6th with relative humidities dropping below 25 percent.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Rocking R Ranch burned 17 acres and resulted in $1,500 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the area kept dry conditions in place.  Though afternoon mixing was weak, dewpoints were dry enough for prolonged dangerous fire weather conditions, especially across north Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a wildfire of unknown cause labeled Yellow Trail burned 0.1 acres and resulted in $500 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak upper ridge over Florida helped to suppress convection across the Southeast, but afternoon instability still allowed a few showers and thunderstorms to develop especially across north Georgia.  Fuel moistures and relative humidity values were above critical levels, but one wildfire did occur.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Mack White burned 1.94 acres and resulted in $1500 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dangerous fire weather conditions were in place across north Georgia for the first couple of days in April due to dry low level conditions and low fuel moisture values.  A few wildfires developed, including a significant one in Floyd County with over 100 acres burned.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a wildfire of unknown cause labeled Crazy Coot burned 5.5 acres and resulted in $1100 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very cold airmass was in place on the 25th, cold enough to support some dry snow in the Georgia mountains.  Temperatures warmed on the 26th as weak high pressure moved over the area.  High fire danger conditions were in place both on the 25th and 26th, based on low fuel moistures and a combination of strong winds on the 25th and low relative humidities on the 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Mack White Gap burned 47 acres and resulted in $15,000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: No entry
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Intense wildfire (Mason Gulch) burned almost 12,000 acres of land in eastern Custer County and western Pueblo County between Wetmore and Beulah.  The fire was started by lightning on the evening of July 6th approximately 2 miles south of Wetmore and made a run towards Beulah on July 10th.  The wildfire was contained by 8 PM on July 16th.  During the height of the fire...the community of Beulah was evacuated while the towns of San Isabel...Colorado City and Rye were put on standby evacuation orders.  The total cost to battle the fire was approximately 5.3 million dollars.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire, human-caused, started near Rye, consuming around 20 acres, and forced the closing of Highway 165 west of Rye.  Around a dozen houses were evacuated.
Lightning started the wildfire, which eventually burned nearly 500 acres north and west of Highway 96, southwest of Wetmore.
Lightning started the Sand Gulch Fire on April 26th, which eventually burned nearly 500 acres north and west of Highway 96, southwest of Wetmore.

A wildfire of unknown cause spread rapidly eastward.  It consumed 15 houses and additional out-buildings in the Greenwood Village subdivision.  Scores of residences were evacuated during the height of the wildfire. Twenty organizations responded to the wildfire, which scorched 1998 acres in Custer and Pueblo Counties.

A wildfire, started by lightning, has burned under 100 acres approximately 4 miles northwest of Beulah, in Custer County.  It continues to be a difficult fire to fight due to the steep terrain, and was still smoldering into the month of September.

The human-caused wildfire started October 17th around 3:30 a.m.  A piece of metal roofing was lofted into power lines by high winds, starting the wildfire.  The fire burned on the Pike/San Isabel National Forest (PSI), Bureau of Land Management (BLM), Colorado State Land Board, and Private lands. Initially, it rapidly burned through mixed fuels, scorching over 15,000 acres within the first 24 hours, affecting Custer and Pueblo Counties. Nine houses were destroyed, along with 17 outbuildings. Multiple communities were threatened and around 600 people were evacuated from their properties for a time.  There were numerous road closures. The wildfire impacted the popular hunting and recreational area.  The fire burned just over 18,000 acres as the month closed out.

The human-caused wildfire started October 17th around 3:30 a.m.  A piece of metal roofing was lofted into power lines by high winds, starting the wildfire.  The fire burned on the Pike/San Isabel National Forest (PSI), Bureau of Land Management (BLM), Colorado State Land Board, and Private lands. Initially, it rapidly burned through mixed fuels, scorching over 15,000 acres within the first 24 hours, affecting Custer and Pueblo Counties. Nine houses were destroyed, along with 17 outbuildings. Multiple communities were threatened and around 600 people were evacuated from their properties for a time.  There were numerous road closures. The wildfire impacted the popular hunting and recreational area.  The fire burned 18,403, and was contained on the 5th.
Gusty northwest winds developed behind a dry wintertime cold front that moved through the area on the 5th.  This helped fuel a wildfire in northwest Georgia during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rome News Tribune reported that a wildfire was sparked by a truck traveling along Georgia Highway 101 near Zona Kay Road in the far southern portion of the county near the Polk county line.  The quickly spread through the dormant vegetation on the heels on 15 to 25 mph gusty, northwest winds.  The fire was extinguished before any structures were damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated wildfire was observed in the woods off Flowery Branch Road, a dirt road, about one mile from Wayside Road in the northeast part of the county.  The fire grew to the size of three to five acres before firefighters arrived at the scene.  The fire was approximately one-half mile from any structures, but was in a heavily wooded pine forest with considerable underbrush.  The suspected cause was a tossed lit cigarette.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rome News Tribune reported that the Rome Fire Department responded to a wildfire in the woods off Flowery Branch Road, a dirt road, about one mile from Wayside Road.  The fire grew to the size of three to five acres before firefighters arrived at the scene.  The fire was approximately one-half mile from any structures, but was in a heavily wooded pine forest with considerable underbrush.  The suspected cause was a tossed lit cigarette.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With the exception of early morning fog, above-normal temperatures and mainly dry conditions prevailed on the 3rd.  A cold front began to push into the area on the 4th, bringing showers and isolated thunderstorms to the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Johns Creek burned 0.3 acres and resulted in $250 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With the exception of early morning fog, above-normal temperatures and mainly dry conditions prevailed on the 3rd.  A cold front began to push into the area on the 4th, bringing showers and isolated thunderstorms to the region.
