EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a wildfire of unknown origin labeled Crackerneck burned 117 acres and resulted in $11,000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a very wet fall and winter, rainfall during the March and April period fell below normal in many areas, especially the north part of the state.  Wildfires were on the increase during April 2010 with several human caused wildfires reported by the Georgia Forestry Commission during the month.  Wildfires were reported in Gilmer, Chattooga, Fannin, Union, and Murray counties.  The most significant wildfire during the month was actually the result of a T9 military aircraft crash in Fannin county just east of Blue Ridge.  This incident fueled a 23 acre wild fire in the forests just east of Blue Ridge.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Georgia Forestry commission reported a wildfire in Gilmer county.  The human caused wildfire, labeled Brushy Head, burned 160 acres of forestry land and 240 acres of private land.  Losses sustained were estimated to be nearly $17,000.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper low over the region shifted east, allowing flow to transition to nearly zonal aloft. A large surface ridge dominated the eastern United States, continuing to bring dry air to the region. Fuels dried significantly through this dry period, with relative humidity values dropping below 25 percent, leading to widespread fire danger conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Black Mtn. burned 455 acres and resulted in $225,000 in damages.  The wildfire suppression ended on December 3.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the area kept dry conditions in place.  Though afternoon mixing was weak, dewpoints were dry enough for prolonged dangerous fire weather conditions, especially across north Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a wildfire of unknown cause labeled Cub Trail burned 1.5 acres and resulted in $500 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave pushed through the area on the 14th, bringing light rain during the early morning hours on the 15th.  Skies cleared during the daytime hours on the 15th with dry conditions returning to the area, though relative humidity values remained just above critical levels for fire danger conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Wildcat burned 12 acres and resulted in $3000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front pushed into northwest Georgia during the morning hours of the 12th.  Very little precipitation was associated with the cold front, but winds increased behind the front to between 15 and 20 MPH and gusting to over 25 MPH, creating high fire danger conditions.  Dry high pressure moved in behind the front, with low relative humidity values creating high fire danger conditions through the 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Little Mountaintown Trail burned 5 acres and resulted in $2850 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry high pressure dominated the area on the 11th.  Relative humidity values dropped to the low to mid 20 percent range during the afternoon hours, creating high fire danger conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Little Amy Creek burned 2.5 acres and resulted in $7000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Generally quiet conditions were in place the 22nd through the 25th, with high pressure mainly in control of the area and only isolated weak afternoon showers and thunderstorms developing.  However, a surface low did develop on the 25th, generating strong winds across the area which when combined with the dry fuels did lead to red flag conditions. A few wildfires developed over the period, one significant with almost 100 acres burned.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Old Parker Road burned 2 acres and resulted in $2300 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Throughout the spring, summer and autumn, north Georgia saw an extended period of below normal rainfall. By late summer and early fall all of north Georgia was experiencing severe, extreme or exceptional drought conditions. As summer vegetation began to die off and autumn leaves began falling from the trees, the continued extremely dry conditions led to very dangerous wildfire conditions. From early October through November, numerous wildfires erupted across north and central Georgia including 3 major wildfires covering multiple thousands of acres apiece in the north Georgia mountains. By early December, over $20 million dollars in federal funds had been spent fighting wildfires in the Chattahoochee National Forest and on surrounding federal and state lands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In the early morning hours of October 16th, lightning ignited a wildfire deep in the heart of the Cohutta Wilderness in the Chattahoochee National Forest. The ���Rough Ridge��� wildfire spread through the very remote Cohutta Wilderness and surrounding portions of the Chattahoochee National Forest, eventually consuming 27,950 acres in Fannin, Gilmer and Murray Counties. Nearly $8.5 million federal dollars were expended fighting this wildfire before it was finally declared contained on November 30th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Throughout the spring, summer and autumn, north Georgia saw an extended period of below normal rainfall. By late summer and early fall all of north Georgia was experiencing severe, extreme or exceptional drought conditions. As summer vegetation began to die off and autumn leaves began falling from the trees, the continued extremely dry conditions led to very dangerous wildfire conditions. From early October through November, numerous wildfires erupted across north and central Georgia including 3 major wildfires covering multiple thousands of acres apiece in the north Georgia mountains. By early December, over $20 million dollars in federal funds had been spent fighting wildfires in the Chattahoochee National Forest and on surrounding federal and state lands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In the early morning hours of October 16th, lightning ignited a wildfire deep in the heart of the Cohutta Wilderness in the Chattahoochee National Forest. The ���Rough Ridge��� wildfire spread through the very remote Cohutta Wilderness and surrounding portions of the Chattahoochee National Forest, eventually consuming 27,950 acres in Fannin, Gilmer and Murray Counties. Nearly $8.5 million federal dollars were expended fighting this wildfire before it was finally declared contained on November 30th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Despite wet ground conditions, strong winds and low relative humidities following the departure of a strong storm system on the 15th, helped to fuel a couple of wild fires in the northeast mountains and another in Jasper county in central Georgia.||Jasper county - The Georgia Forestry Commission reported a wildfire in Jasper county in east central Georgia.  This fire was started as a result of power lines arcing in the wind.  The fire only consumed 1/2 acre.||Towns county - The Georgia Forestry commission reported a significant human-caused wildfire fueled by strong winds and low relative humidity in the mountains of Towns county.  The fire, labeled Bear Meat, burned for over three days and consumed 18.0 acres.||Union county - The Georgia Forestry commission reported a human-caused wildfire, labeled number 195.  The fire consumed 10 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Georgia Forestry Commission reported a wildfire in Jasper county in east central Georgia.  This fire was started as a result of power lines arcing in the wind.  The fire only consumed 1/2 acre.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak dry cold front moved across the area on the 5th, bringing cooler and drier air to the region.  High fire danger conditions prevailed, especially behind the front where the winds increased to between 10 to 20 MPH and relative humidities dropped below 25 percent.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Smith Mill burned 305 acres and resulted in $25,000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak stationary front was stretched across the area, with an upper trough along the Eastern Seaboard.  Multiple shortwaves continued across the area.  Scattered afternoon showers and thunderstorms developed mainly in the vicinity of the trough, and in general relative humidity values remained too high for dangerous fire weather conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a wildfire of unknown cause labeled Lazenbury Mill burned 0.1 acres and resulted in $1,500 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface high was in place across the Southeast, and with upslope flow across north Georgia, a few light showers developed in the afternoon and evening.  While no critical fire weather conditions developed, a small wildfire start in central Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Star burned 4.87 acres and resulted in no damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Generally quiet conditions were in place the 22nd through the 25th, with high pressure mainly in control of the area and only isolated weak afternoon showers and thunderstorms developing.  However, a surface low did develop on the 25th, generating strong winds across the area which when combined with the dry fuels did lead to red flag conditions. A few wildfires developed over the period, one significant with almost 100 acres burned.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a wildfire caused by a power line labeled Turner burned 2.25 acres and resulted in $1000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This incident was named the Commissary Fire and occurred about 22 miles west of Gunnison in the Gunnison National Forest. The fire burned mainly in hardwood litter and consumed approximately 161 acres by the end of July. The fire resulted in closures of a campground and a road. For a continuation on this fire please see the August 2005 Storm Data publication.
A lightning strike ignited a wildfire on Buttermilk Ridge in the Gunnison Gorge National Conservation Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Buttermilk Fire began due to lightning ignition on Buttermilk Ridge in the Gunnison Gorge National Conservation Area and grew to about 748 acres before it was contained in mid October.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike ignited a wildfire on Buttermilk Ridge in the Gunnison Gorge National Conservation Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Buttermilk Fire began due to lightning on Buttermilk Ridge in the Gunnison Gorge National Conservation Area and grew to 748 acres before it was contained in mid October.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike ignited a wildfire on Buttermilk Ridge in the Gunnison Gorge National Conservation Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Buttermilk Fire began due to lightning ignition on Buttermilk Ridge in the Gunnison Gorge National Conservation Area and grew to 748 acres before it was contained in mid October.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike ignited a wildfire on Buttermilk Ridge in the Gunnison Gorge National Conservation Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Buttermilk Fire began due to lightning on Buttermilk Ridge in the Gunnison Gorge National Conservation Area and grew to 748 acres before it was contained in mid October.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ongoing extreme to exceptional drought conditions across southwest Louisiana contributed to several large wildfires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Waco Wildfire burned 130 acres around 9 miles north of Pitkin.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ongoing extreme to exceptional drought conditions across southeast Texas contributed to a large wildfire across Hardin County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Post Oak Wildfire burned around 800 acres about 4 miles south-southwest of Wildwood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ongoing extreme to exceptional drought conditions across southeast Texas contributed to several large wildfires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pipeline Road Wildfire burned an estimated 7500 acres across northern Hardin and southern Tyler counties over a period of nearly 2 weeks from April 16 to April 28. Up to 40 homes were threatened and evacuated, but the only property damage was destroyed logging equipment. Firefighters were brought in from around the country to help contain the blaze.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme to exceptional drought conditions contributed to a wildfire in Hardin County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Over 910 acres were burned four miles south of Kountze, TX. No losses were reported, but 24 homes had to be evacuated for precautionary measures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme to exceptional drought conditions contributed to a wildfire in Hardin County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Over 577 acres burned 4 miles north of Kountze. No property loss was reported, but US Highway 69 was closed for a few hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme to exceptional drought conditions contributed to a wildfire in Hardin County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Over 1400 acres were burned 5 miles west of Kountze. No losses were reported, but several homes had to be evacuated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long term persistent drought across north and central Georgia, along with an extended period of dry, cold weather from late October through mid-November resulted in an increased fire danger across the state.  Several wildfires were reported during mid-month by the U.S. Forest Service in the Chattahoochee National Forecast in far northeast Georgia.  Wildfires were observed in Fannin, Lumpkin, and Rabun counties.  Wildfires broke out in the Three Forks and Dry Branch area of the forest in Fannin county and the Woody Creek area of Lumpkin county.  The Three Forks and Woody Creek fires spanned a period of three and four days, respectively.  Damages from the three fires was estimated at $130,000.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The U.S. Forest Service reported that there was a wildfire in the Woody Creek area of the Chattahoochee National Forecast.  The wildfire took three days to contain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of Arctic air mass spread across north and central Georgia during the later half of the month.  Rainfall was well below normal during this period.  Soil and ground conditions were quite dry.  A couple of small wildfires in far north Georgia had to be contained by the Georgia Forestry Department.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Georgia Forestry Commission reported that a human caused wildfire had to be contained at Dockery Gap.  Approximately 0.16 acres of forest were burned.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A week long period of Arctic air and dry northwest flow help fuel a wildfire in Lumpkin county.  The human-caused wildfire burned 1/4 acre and resulted in $600 in damages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Georgia Forestry Commission reported a human-caused wildfire labeled Rock Climbing Fire that impacted a small 1/4 acre portion of Lumpkin county.  The fire took a little less than three hours to bring under control and resulted in $600.00 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first three weeks of October brought mostly dry weather conditions to north Georgia preceded by an unusually hot and dry September.  As a result, conditions were favorable for wildfires.  Three human-caused wildfires were observed in October between the 16th and 22nd.  The first fire took four days to contain.||The three wildfires were:|(a).  Mill Creek in Walker county from 10/16/10:2200 LT to 10/20/10:2000 LT burning 36.5 acres.|(b).  Rock Wall in Lumpkin county from 10/21/10:1830 LT to 10/21/10:2100 LT burning 1/4 acre.|(c).  Hall Road in Murray county from 10/22/10:1530 LT to 10/22/10:1530 LT burning 82.75 acres.||Estimated damages from these fires were in excess of $10,000.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Georgia Forestry Commission reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Rockwall burned 1/4 acre causing an esimated $2,500 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep Arctic air mass persisted across north Georgia during the first two weeks of January.  Gusty northwest winds and a dry air mass were common during this period. The dry air mass and strong winds combined to fuel a human-caused wildfire in Lumpkin county.  The fire affected an area of 20 acres, burned for five hours, and resulted in $4500 in damages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Georgia Forestry Commission reported that a human-caused wildfire fueled by strong northwest winds and low relative humidity burned 20 acres, took five hours to contain, and resulted in $4500 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper low over the region shifted east, allowing flow to transition to nearly zonal aloft. A large surface ridge dominated the eastern United States, continuing to bring dry air to the region. Fuels dried significantly through this dry period, with relative humidity values dropping below 25 percent, leading to widespread fire danger conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Nimblewill Church Rd burned 1 acre and resulted in $500 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With the exception of early morning fog, above-normal temperatures and mainly dry conditions prevailed on the 3rd.  A cold front began to push into the area on the 4th, bringing showers and isolated thunderstorms to the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Washrider burned 7.25 acres and resulted in $2,000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Surface high pressure moved into the area on the 14th, with a cold front approaching the state.  Dry weather prevailed, but relative humidity values remained above fire danger criteria.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Washrider 2 burned 0.12 acres and resulted in $500 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A back door dry cold front moved through the state early on the 8th.  An upper ridge was slowly building across the area as well, leading to dry conditions, although relative humidity values remained above critical levels for dangerous fire weather conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a wildfire of unknown cause labeled May Mtn. burned 3 acres and resulted in $250 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although low-level moisture was beginning to increase, several days of dry and sunny weather prior to the 15th and 16th led to dry fuels and increased fire danger across North Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire named Whissenhunt 2 resulted in 23 acres burned and $5000 in costs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Generally quiet conditions were in place the 22nd through the 25th, with high pressure mainly in control of the area and only isolated weak afternoon showers and thunderstorms developing.  However, a surface low did develop on the 25th, generating strong winds across the area which when combined with the dry fuels did lead to red flag conditions. A few wildfires developed over the period, one significant with almost 100 acres burned.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Turner Creek burned 95 acres and resulted in $14,200 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Throughout the spring, summer and autumn, north Georgia saw an extended period of below normal rainfall. By late summer and early fall all of north Georgia was experiencing severe, extreme or exceptional drought conditions. As summer vegetation began to die off and autumn leaves began falling from the trees, the continued extremely dry conditions led to very dangerous wildfire conditions. From early October through November and into December, numerous wildfires erupted across north and central Georgia including 3 major wildfires covering multiple thousands of acres apiece in the north Georgia mountains. By the end of December, over $20 million dollars in federal funds had been spent fighting wildfires across north Georgia in the Chattahoochee National Forest and on surrounding federal and state lands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The USDA National Forest Service reported that a vehicle fire along State Highway 129 south of Neels Gap resulted in a wildfire. The Swains Cove fire which started on December 22st was reported to be fully contained on December 28th after burning 200 acres. The Swains Cove fire resulted in the closure of the Appalachian Trail for several days from Neels Gap to Tesnatee Gap.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Despite wet ground conditions, strong winds and low relative humidities following the departure of a strong storm system on the 15th, helped to fuel a couple of wild fires in the northeast mountains and another in Jasper county in central Georgia.||Jasper county - The Georgia Forestry Commission reported a wildfire in Jasper county in east central Georgia.  This fire was started as a result of power lines arcing in the wind.  The fire only consumed 1/2 acre.||Towns county - The Georgia Forestry commission reported a significant human-caused wildfire fueled by strong winds and low relative humidity in the mountains of Towns county.  The fire, labeled Bear Meat, burned for over three days and consumed 18.0 acres.||Union county - The Georgia Forestry commission reported a human-caused wildfire, labeled number 195.  The fire consumed 10 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Georgia Forestry commission reported a significant human-caused wildfire fueled by strong winds and low relative humidities in the mountains of Towns county.  The fire, labeled Bear Meat, burned for over three days and consumed 18.0 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions continued across the area with surface high pressure in control of the Southeast and dry northwest flow aloft.  Dangerous fire weather conditions existed across the entire area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Vortac burned 36 acres and resulted in $50,000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northwest flow pattern was in place with a deep trough across the eastern United States.  A weak shortwave moved into the Southeast with only light scattered showers developing in the afternoon.  Otherwise, dry conditions prevailed across the area, though relative humidity values were not quite dry enough for fire danger conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a wildfire of unknown cause burned 1 acre and resulted in $2,000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A high pressure ridge continued to dominate the area on the 26th, but was beginning to break down in advance of Hurricane Sandy.  Dry conditions continued across the area, but not to critical levels for fire danger conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Saddler Ridge burned 10 acres and resulted in $1000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the area kept dry conditions in place.  Though afternoon mixing was weak, dewpoints were dry enough for prolonged dangerous fire weather conditions, especially across north Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a wildfire of unknown cause labeled Holcomb Road burned 7.25 acres and resulted in $12,000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the area kept dry conditions in place.  Though afternoon mixing was weak, dewpoints were dry enough for prolonged dangerous fire weather conditions, especially across north Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Rocky Knob burned 0.1 acres and resulted in $1,000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front pushed into northwest Georgia during the morning hours of the 12th.  Very little precipitation was associated with the cold front, but winds increased behind the front to between 15 and 20 MPH and gusting to over 25 MPH, creating high fire danger conditions.  Dry high pressure moved in behind the front, with low relative humidity values creating high fire danger conditions through the 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Charlie's Creek burned 3.1 acres and resulted in $3300 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface high dominated the area on the 10th and 11th, with dry conditions in place.  Relative humidity values dropped below critical levels and with dry fuels, dangerous fire weather conditions developed, allowing several wildfires to burn.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a wildfire of unknown cause labeled Upper Plott Town burned 5 acres and resulted in $800 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry high pressure was in place on the 4th.  Though relative humidity values hovered just above critical levels, a wildfire was able to develop in northeast Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Jewel Mtn. burned 12.1 acres and resulted in $10,000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Throughout the spring, summer and autumn, north Georgia saw an extended period of below normal rainfall. By late summer and early fall all of north Georgia was experiencing severe, extreme or exceptional drought conditions. As summer vegetation began to die off and autumn leaves began falling from the trees, the continued extremely dry conditions led to very dangerous wildfire conditions. From early October through November, numerous wildfires erupted across north and central Georgia including 3 major wildfires covering multiple thousands of acres apiece in the north Georgia mountains. By early December, over $20 million dollars in federal funds had been spent fighting wildfires in the Chattahoochee National Forest and on surrounding federal and state lands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On November 11th a human caused wildfire erupted along the border between Towns and Rabun Counties. Before the Rocky Mountain wildfire was declared contained on December 15th it had consumed 1,851 acres in the eastern portion of Towns County. In total, this wildfire burned nearly 25,000 acres of Chattahoochee National Forest and state and private forest land in Georgia and Tennessee. More tham $11 million federal dollars was expended fighting this wildfire, nearly $900,000 in Towns County alone.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Throughout the spring, summer and autumn, north Georgia saw an extended period of below normal rainfall. By late summer and early fall all of north Georgia was experiencing severe, extreme or exceptional drought conditions. As summer vegetation began to die off and autumn leaves began falling from the trees, the continued extremely dry conditions led to very dangerous wildfire conditions. From early October through November and into December, numerous wildfires erupted across north and central Georgia including 3 major wildfires covering multiple thousands of acres apiece in the north Georgia mountains. By the end of December, over $20 million dollars in federal funds had been spent fighting wildfires across north Georgia in the Chattahoochee National Forest and on surrounding federal and state lands.

Before the Rocky Mountain wildfire was declared contained on December 15th it had consumed 1,851 acres in the eastern portion of Towns County. In total, this wildfire burned nearly 25,000 acres of Chattahoochee National Forest and state and private forest land in Georgia and Tennessee. More tham $11 million federal dollars were expended fighting this wildfire, nearly $900,000 in Towns County alone.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wildfire 14 miles southeast of Carey burned 25,000 acres of sagebrush and grassland.  No damage reported.
3 Wells fire burned 5,500 acres of grass and brush just west of Shoshone.  No damage reported.

Intense 50 to 60 mph thunderstorm winds caused a small wildfire of 1000 acres to grow and spread rapidly to 45,862 acres just south and southeast of Shoshone.  No homes were damaged, but 5 outbuildings were destroyed and 5 were damaged.  Damage was caused to two large power transmission lines maintained by Idaho Power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Intense 50 to 60 mph thunderstorm winds caused a small wilfire of 1000 acres to grow and spread rapidly to 45,682 acres just south and southeast of Shoshone.  No homes were damaged, but 5 outbuildings were destroyed and 5 were damaged.  Damage was caused to two large power transmission lines maintained by Idaho Power.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning started a 34,000 acre fire 10 miles southeast of Shoshone.   It occurred in open land and no damage occurred to structures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning started a 34,000 acre fire 10 miles southeast of Shoshone.   It occurred in open land and no damage occurred to structures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Kimama Wildfire was caused by a lightning strike on June 29th and grew to 300 acres.   The fire was located 3 miles northwest of Paul and was contained by the afternoon of June 30th.    No structures were threatened.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Kimama Wildfire was caused by a lightning strike on June 29th and grew to 300 acres.   The fire was located 3 miles northwest of Paul and was contained by the afternoon of June 30th.    No structures were threatened.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Brown Butte wildfire was located about 10 miles northeast of Shoshone.   It began on July 21st and was controlled by July 23rd.   It burned over 7000 acres.   No homes or structures were threatened.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Brown Butte wildfire was located about 10 miles northeast of Shoshone.   It began on July 21st and was controlled by July 23rd.   It burned over 7000 acres.   No homes or structures were threatened.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Jim Brown wildfire was a lightning started wildfire on July 1st 6 miles southeast of Richfield that grew to 14,444 acres before being contained and controlled on July 6th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jim Brown wildfire was a lightning started wildfire on July 1st 6 miles southeast of Richfield that grew to 14,444 acres before being contained and controlled on July 6th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The 900 fire began August 14th due to lightning strikes and burned 2,245 acres of grass and brush.  It was located approximately 7 miles south of Shoshone and closed US route 93 to motorists for a lengthy period of time.   Traffic backups were up to a mile on the 14th.   The fire was contained by August 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 900 fire began August 14th due to lightning strikes and burned 2,245 acres of grass and brush.  It was located approximately 7 miles south of Shoshone and closed US route 93 to motorists for a lengthy period of time.   Traffic backups were up to a mile on the 14th.   The fire was contained by August 17th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Laidlaw fire began August 18th southeast of Carey due to lightning strikes and burned 39,000 acres in open land.    It did start to spread into the Craters of the Moon National Monument but was slowed by rock formations.    The fire was considered controlled by August 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Laidlaw fire began August 18th southeast of Carey due to lightning strikes and burned 39,000 acres in open land.    It did start to spread into the Craters of the Moon National Monument but was slowed by rock formations.    The fire was considered controlled by August 20th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning caused a wildfire about 5 miles north of Carey on August 31st and it grew quickly to 3,000 acres.   Full containment occurred on September 1st.   Lava rock helped to contain further growth.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning caused a wildfire about 5 miles north of Carey on August 31st and it grew quickly to 3,000 acres.   Full containment occurred on September 1st.   Lava rock helped to contain further growth.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 40 acre fire was human started 2 miles north of Shoshone and moved north.   Highway 75 was closed for one hour fighting the fire and several structures were threatened but none were damaged.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 40 acre fire was human started 2 miles north of Shoshone and moved north.   Highway 75 was closed for one hour fighting the fire and several structures were threatened but none were damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Mammoth wildfire was reported on August 5th 7 miles north of Shoshone and rapidly grew to 60,000 acres due to strong winds.   The fire burned grass and brush and threatened one primary residence and two minor structures.   The cause of the fire was undetermined and was contained by August 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mammoth wildfire was reported on August 5th 7 miles north of Shoshone and rapidly grew to 60,000 acres due to strong winds.   The fire burned grass and brush and threatened one primary residence and two minor structures.   The cause of the fire was undetermined and was contained by August 10th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fire burned 1,700 acres of grass, brush and juniper southwest of Kimama on July 3rd.   The fire was reported at 8:30 AM and was contained by 7 pm.   It was controlled by 6 pm on July 4th.    Seven engines, one dozer and one water tender were used to control.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A fire burned 1,700 acres of grass, brush and juniper southwest of Kimama on July 3rd.   The fire was reported at 8:30 AM and was contained by 7 pm.   It was controlled by 6 pm on July 4th.    Seven engines, one dozer and one water tender were used to control.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although the fire started in Gooding County the effects were felt to the north and close highways 93 and 24 to Shoshone and east of Shoshone and the fire jumped Route 26 many times.  It was a grass and brush fire started by lightning on July 9th about 5 miles south of Shoshone and grew to around 30,000 acres.   It was contained on July 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Although the fire started in Gooding County the effects were felt to the north and close highways 93 and 24 to Shoshone and east of Shoshone and the fire jumped Route 26 many times.  It was a grass and brush fire started by lightning on July 9th about 5 miles south of Shoshone and grew to around 30,000 acres.   It was contained on July 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning caused the Lagoon fire to begin around 11 pm on July 25th 2 miles west of Shoshone.   It burned grass and brush and caused some evacuations in Shoshone and Highway 75 closed for a period as well.   The fire grew to 1,412 acres and was fully contained on July 28th and controlled on July 30th.   It destroyed a lumberyard and outbuilding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning caused the Lagoon fire to begin around 11 pm on July 25th 2 miles west of Shoshone.   It burned grass and brush and caused some evacuations in Shoshone and Highway 75 closed for a period as well.   The fire grew to 1,412 acres and was fully contained on July 28th and controlled on July 30th.   It destroyed a lumberyard and outbuilding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Cave Fire, centered 12 miles southeast of Bend, burned 852 acres.
No entry
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Black Crater fire 7 miles southwest of Sisters was lightning caused and had burned 9200 acres by July 31 and continued into August. Portions of the town of Sisters were evacuated as the fire threatened structures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: No entry
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cascade Crest Complex fire started  July 23 and  included the Lake George, Black Crater, and Puzzle fires west of Sisters. It was contained after burning 21,290 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: No entry
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Black Crater Fire, west of Sisters, started in July 23 and merged into the Cascade Complex. It burned through August, charring over 21,000 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant lightning and dry vegetation caused a 2775 acre wildfire 5 miles northeast of Millican.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The lightning caused East Fire burned 2775 acres 5 miles north northeast of Millican.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The GW Fire, 13 miles west of Sisters, was started by lightning and burned 7,357 acres between August 31 and September 11.  Residents of Black Butte Ranch were evacuated on September 3 and allowed to return September 4.

The GW Fire, 13 miles west of Sisters, was started by lightning and burned 7,357 acres between August 31 and September 11. Residents of Black Butte Ranch were evacuated on September 3 and allowed to return September 4.
The Black Butte Fire was started by a lightning strike and burned 578 acres of timber 8 miles northwest of Sisters on the east slope of Black Butte.
The Rooster Rock Wildfire started August 2 at 10:44 am 6 miles south of Sisters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rooster Rock Fire burned 6100 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of Arctic air mass spread across north and central Georgia during the later half of the month.  Rainfall was well below normal during this period.  Soil and ground conditions were quite dry.  A couple of small wildfires in far north Georgia had to be contained by the Georgia Forestry Department.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Georgia Forestry Commission reported that approximately 1/10 of a forest area was burned by a human caused wildfire.  The fire was named 630F.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An overall dry first part of February combined with gusty winds led to several wildfires within United States Forest Service land.  All of the wildfires were human caused.  A wildfire, which began in the Peeples Lake area of Murray county on February 9, 2009, burned until February 11, 2009.  The fire consumed 54 acres and resulted in $15,000 in damages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The U.S. Forest Service reported that a human caused wildfire in the Peeples Lake area consumed 54 acres and resulted in $15,000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although drought conditions were dramatically improving across the state from generous winter and early spring rainfall, several wildfires were reported by the Georgia Forestry Commission, mostly across north Georgia.  All of the wildfires in the Peachtree City, Georgia forecast area were human caused.||Wild fires were reported in Chattooga, Murray, Putnam, and Walker counties.  There were actually three seperate wild fire incidents in Murray county during the month.  Total combined damages from these wild fires was estimated to be nearly $22,000.  The most significant wildfire to occur during the month was in Walker county on March 22nd, burning 6.4 acres and causing $10,000 in damages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A second fire was reported in Murray county.  This fire, Labeled Old Highway 2 No. 2, burned 0.50 acres.  The fire was human caused.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although drought conditions were dramatically improving across the state from generous winter and early spring rainfall, several wildfires were reported by the Georgia Forestry Commission, mostly across north Georgia.  All of the wildfires in the Peachtree City, Georgia forecast area were human caused.||Wild fires were reported in Chattooga, Murray, Putnam, and Walker counties.  There were actually three seperate wild fire incidents in Murray county during the month.  Total combined damages from these wild fires was estimated to be nearly $22,000.  The most significant wildfire to occur during the month was in Walker county on March 22nd, burning 6.4 acres and causing $10,000 in damages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire, labeled Rocky Flats, burned 2.0 acres.  The fire was human caused.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although drought conditions were dramatically improving across the state from generous winter and early spring rainfall, several wildfires were reported by the Georgia Forestry Commission, mostly across north Georgia.  All of the wildfires in the Peachtree City, Georgia forecast area were human caused.||Wild fires were reported in Chattooga, Murray, Putnam, and Walker counties.  There were actually three seperate wild fire incidents in Murray county during the month.  Total combined damages from these wild fires was estimated to be nearly $22,000.  The most significant wildfire to occur during the month was in Walker county on March 22nd, burning 6.4 acres and causing $10,000 in damages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Yet a third wild fire was reportd in Murray county.  This fire was labeled Old Highway 2 and burned 3.0 acres resulting in $5000 in damages.  The fire was human caused.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a very wet fall and winter, rainfall during the March and April period fell below normal in many areas, especially the north part of the state.  Wildfires were on the increase during April 2010 with several human caused wildfires reported by the Georgia Forestry Commission during the month.  Wildfires were reported in Gilmer, Chattooga, Fannin, Union, and Murray counties.  The most significant wildfire during the month was actually the result of a T9 military aircraft crash in Fannin county just east of Blue Ridge.  This incident fueled a 23 acre wild fire in the forests just east of Blue Ridge.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Georgia Forestry Commission reported a human-caused wildfire in the Haissiers Mill area (private land) burned six acres and resulted in roughly $2,000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This is a continuation of the wildfire events that began on October 16th.  This episode incorporates that third wildfire event of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Georgia Forestry Commission reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Hall Road burned 46 acres and caused $7,000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The typical pattern of afternoon summertime thunderstorms was in place, but due to the spotty nature of the rain, fuel moistures remained low.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-cased fire labeled Horseshoe Bend burned 0.1 acres and resulted in $500 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The extreme heat event began to subside somewhat on the 2nd as the upper ridge began to weaken, but hot conditions continued.  Scattered showers and thunderstorms again developed across the area, but mainly across east central Georgia where a surface trough lingered.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a lightning-caused wildfire labeled Pleasant Gap burned 1.5 acres and resulted in $15,000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure continued in control over the area, though it had shifted offshore and was now bringing in moist south to southeasterly flow.  A front was approaching the area, expected to move into north Georgia on the 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Station burned 14 acres and resulted in an unknown amount of damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak surface trough moved into north Georgia on the 22nd, and provided a focus for afternoon showers and thunderstorms to develop.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a lightning-caused wildfire labeled Iron Mtn. Chase burned 30 acres and resulted in $2,500 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme heat event was well in place beginning on the 30th.  Surface mixing provided sufficient dry air at the surface for critical relative humidity values to be reached, with dangerous fire weather conditions in place across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Emory Creek burned 1.2 acres and resulted in $5,000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Subtropical Storm Beryl continued to spin off the Southeast Coast, with a landfall expected near the Georgia/Florida border late in the day.  Scattered showers with isolated thunderstorms developed across the state during the day as winds increased due to the strengthening pressure gradient.  Because of the recent dry spell, fuel moistures were very low, but with increasing moisture as a result of Beryl, relative humidities remained just over critical thresholds for dangerous fire weather conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a lightning-caused wildfire labeled Memorial burned 42 acres and resulted in $10,000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front pushed into northwest Georgia during the morning hours of the 12th.  Very little precipitation was associated with the cold front, but winds increased behind the front to between 15 and 20 MPH and gusting to over 25 MPH, creating high fire danger conditions.  Dry high pressure moved in behind the front, with low relative humidity values creating high fire danger conditions through the 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Yeti burned 3 acres and resulted in $2500 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry high pressure was in place across the area, and a few locations especially in northwest Georgia were able to briefly experience critically low relative humidity values during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Hwy 286 burned 3.4 acres and resulted in $1000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic high pressure area was moving toward the Southeast on the 23rd.  Very weak forcing aloft allowed for a few showers to develop across central Georgia during the afternoon, but the rest of the area remained dry.  While critical fire weather conditions were not met, a wildfire did still start in north Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Hickey burned 5.9 acres and resulted in $15,000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry high pressure continued across the Southeast with above-normal temperatures.  Moisture was on the increase ahead of an approaching front, keeping dangerous fire weather conditions at bay, but a wildfire was still able to develop in north Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Tiger Tail burned 2 acres and resulted in $2400 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface high dominated the area on the 10th and 11th, with dry conditions in place.  Relative humidity values dropped below critical levels and with dry fuels, dangerous fire weather conditions developed, allowing several wildfires to burn.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Forest Service reported that a human-caused wildfire labeled Peeples Lake burned 67 acres and resulted in $20,000 in damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Throughout the spring, summer and autumn, north Georgia saw an extended period of below normal rainfall. By late summer and early fall all of north Georgia was experiencing severe, extreme or exceptional drought conditions. As summer vegetation began to die off and autumn leaves began falling from the trees, the continued extremely dry conditions led to very dangerous wildfire conditions. From early October through November, numerous wildfires erupted across north and central Georgia including 3 major wildfires covering multiple thousands of acres apiece in the north Georgia mountains. By early December, over $20 million dollars in federal funds had been spent fighting wildfires in the Chattahoochee National Forest and on surrounding federal and state lands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In the early morning hours of October 16th, lightning ignited a wildfire deep in the heart of the Cohutta Wilderness in the Chattahoochee National Forest. The ���Rough Ridge��� wildfire spread through the very remote Cohutta Wilderness and surrounding portions of the Chattahoochee National Forest, eventually consuming 27,950 acres in Fannin, Gilmer and Murray Counties. Nearly $8.5 million federal dollars were expended fighting this wildfire before it was finally declared contained on November 30th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Gusty northeast winds and low relative humidities aided the spread of two large wildfires near Lake Sam Rayburn Dam. One fire occurred in the Audobon Hills neighborhood, while the other affected areas near and southwest of the Piney Point Shopping Center. Five houses, a storage shed, an old boat storage facility, and a front-end loader were destroyed in the fire. Both fires together burned over 100 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: KJAS Radio reported two large wildfires began around 4 PM CDT near Lake Sam Rayburn Dam. One fire occurred in the Audobon Hills neighborhood, while the other affected areas near and southwest of the Piney Point Shopping Center. Five houses, a storage shed, an old boat storage facility, and a front-end loader were destroyed in the fire. Both fires together burned over 100 acres. Five regional fire departments and the Texas Forest Service fought the blazes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ongoing extreme to exceptional drought conditions across southeast Texas contributed to several large wildfires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bad Gate Wildfire burned 400 acres about 5 miles west of Gist.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme to exceptional drought conditions contributed to a wildfire in Jasper County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Over 500 acres were burned near Buna in Jasper County. Around 35 homes were evacuated due to close proximity to the fire. The only property damage reported was one barn destroyed on County Road 721.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme to exceptional drought conditions contributed to a wildfire in Jasper County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 500 acre wildfire was started in rural Jasper County near Dam B Reservoir. Timber was the primary loss. Twenty campers at Sandy Creek Park and several homes nearby were evacuated as a precautionary measure.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme to exceptional drought conditions contributed to a wildfire in Jasper County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Over 4,200 acres were burned 5 miles southwest of Lake Sam Rayburn. This fire threatened over 500 homes, and several subdivisions were evacuated. Eight camps in a hunting club were destroyed. One major pipeline and two electrical transmission lines were in the fire. Texas Forest Service estimated between 3.3 and 5.1 million cubic feet of timber were lost in this fire. Local officials believe the fire started when someone took target practice at several propane tanks in the woods.

CZ_NAME: SAGUACHE COUNTY EAST OF CONTINENTAL DIVIDE BELOW 10000 FT
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: No entry
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire ignited by lightning in the vicinity of Four Mile Creek in Saguache County burned approximately 100 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: No entry
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dry lightning ignited a fire which burned 205 acres 10 miles west of Timpas in Otero County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wind-driven grass fire forced the evacuation of residents.  The fire started around 3 p.m. along the Arkansas River near CR21 and Highway 266.  The fire burned nearly 1000 acres.  An irrigation pump house was destroyed, along with some irrigation pipe.

Two wildfires occurred in Otero County, fanned by strong winds.  One 35 acre blaze occurred near Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site.  There was no damage.  The other larger fire, south of Rocky Ford, consumed approximately 2000 acres, and forced the evacuation of seven residences.  A shed, and abandoned farm building were destroyed, along with minor damage to a bridge on State Highway 10.
A wildfire in the Apishapa River bottom spread and consumed nearly 600 acres. No structures were damaged or destroyed.
Lightning ignited the fire around 20 miles south of La Junta in Whithers Canyon near the Purgatoire River...consuming around 1000 acres.

The Salt Fire, ignited by lightning, consumed 4500 acres in southeast Otero and southwest Bent Counties. The fire burned on the north and south sides of the Purgatoire River. Hand crews and bulldozer operators, numbering around 145, worked to build fire lines. No structures were damaged and no injuries were reported.
Lightning ignited the Bear Springs Fire...on the Pinon Canyon Maneuver Site...which consumed around 35000 acres.
Wildfires burned about 500 acres across the county.

Wildfires that began during the end of November across Mayes, Okmulgee, and McIntosh Counties continued into the first few days of December.  Several additional wildfires were also started across these counties during the first few days of December as a result of dry vegetation and gusty wind.  Mayes and McIntosh Counties were approved to receive FEMA assistance for the wildfires that affected those counties during the end of November and early December.
No entry
A fire occurred along McAnally Road and spread to the east to behind the Pixie Woods area.  The fire consumed almost 7,000 acres and four barns were destroyed.

Over 1000 acres were burned in a fire in Pittsburg County and over 600 acres were burned in Latimer County by a wildfire. No structures were known to be involved in either fire.

Over 700 acres were burned in a fire in Creek County, over 800 acres were burned in Pushmataha County, over 600 acres were burned in Cherokee and Latimer Counties, and over 300 acres were burned in Haskell County. No structures were known to be involved in any of the fires.

Warm, dry, and very windy conditions, combined with dormant vegetation resulted in the rapid spread of wildfire on February 18th. Wildfires burned over 20,000 acres of land in Okfuskee County, which destroyed several outbuildings. Several thousands of acres were burned in Okmulgee County, which also destroyed outbuildings. In Pawnee County, more than 3300 acres were burned by wildfire, also destroying several outbuildings. Over 500 acres were burned in Latimer County.

The largest wildfires occurred in Haskell and Latimer Counties, where more than 400 acres were burned in each county. A large wildfire also occurred in Adair County.

Despite the recent rains, vegetation remained dormant and dry, which helped promote the spread of wildfire on the 26th when warm and windy conditions developed across the area.  A number of fires were started and quickly grew out of control during the afternoon.  The most notable fires occurred near Bristow in Creek County, near Muskogee in Muskogee County, near Scipio in Pittsburg County (a house was damaged in this fire), across western Wagoner County, and across portions of Okfuskee and Okmulgee Counties.

Very dry, hot, and breezy conditions, along with extremely dry fuels as a result of the long-term drought the region has experienced, promoted the rapid spread of several wildfires on the 3rd around Blanco in Pittsburg County. These fires combined burned at least 1100 acres before numerous fire departments, state forestry, and the National Guard could suppress them.

One of the firefighters received burn injuries and was trasported to an area hospital. This fire burned about 200 acres and was fought by fire fighters from Forestry Services and local fire departments.

A strong surface low pressure caused strong winds and a few high wind gusts across western north Texas and parts of Oklahoma. The highest wind gust in western north Texas was measured in Wilbarger county. A large wildfire also occurred in Wilbarger county aided by the strong winds and very dry conditions across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire near Grayback on the Waggoner Ranch burned approximately 10,000 acres. The fire was reported at the intersection of FM 1763 and CR 1065. Fire fighting efforts were hampered by high winds. Firefighters from 4 area fire departments, ranch personnel, the Texas Forest Service, and resources from the Wilbarger County Commissioner precincts and Texas Department of Transportation were used to fight the fire. Some structures were threatened by the fire but ultimately no structures were damaged. The fire was thought to be caused by the high winds causing electrical lines to spark.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: No entry
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire began 4 miles west of Erick during the early afternoon of November 3rd. Winds gusting to 40 mph and dry conditions helped this fire spread rapidly eventually burning an area 7 miles long and 2 miles wide. Firefighter from Beckham county, Roger Mills county, the U.S. Forestry Service and several Texas fire departments were used to fight the fire. A National Guard helicopter was also called in to dump water on the blaze. The fire destroyed one home along with several barns and abandoned farmhouses. The smoke from this fire was seen for miles and affected Interstate 40 for a time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Grass fires burned 500 acres in Garvin county and 600 acres in Beckham county on the 6th.
Grass fires burned approximately 1466 acres in Beckham county, 759 acres in Stephens county, and 300 acres in Atoka on the 16th.

A strong surface low pressure moved across the southern and central Plains causing strong sustained surface winds across the western half to two-thirds of Oklahoma with some high wind gusts. National Weather Service weather stations along with the Oklahoma mesonet measured sustained wind speeds ranging from 17 to 30 knots (20-35 mph) on November 27th into the 28th, with numerous wind gusts ranging from 39 to 56 knots(45-65 mph). Winds were initially strong from the south to west then shifted to the north and northwest behind a cold front. The winds began to decrease during the afternoon hours of November 28th as the strong surface low continued to lift away from the area. Wind damage was reported in several locations along with numerous power outages. The strong winds also combined with very dry conditions to help with the start and spread of several wildfires. Some fires may have been started by power lines arcing or even coming down in the high winds. The wildfires ranged from a few hundred acres to a few thousand acres some of which for several days. Many fire fighters and resources from the local, state, and federal levels were used to fight these fires. Many structures, hay, pasture, etc. were destroyed by the fires. Some residents were evacuated due to a few of the fires. Several people were injured at various fires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire near Velma in Stephens county burned approximately a 15 mile area. The fire began on November 27th and continued to burn into the first part of December. The fire caused the evacuation of some residents and at one point surrounded the town of 664 people. The fire also caused the closure of State Highway 7. Four firefighters suffered smoke inhalation. Several residents also received minor burns. Strong winds and dry conditions combined to cause this fire to spread quickly. About 20 fire departments assisted in fighting the fire. Overall, the fire destroyed 16 homes, including 8 mobile homes, and numerous outbuildings, including two large barns. The exact cause of the fire had not been determined but downed power lines in the strong winds may have started the fire. The property damage for this fire is estimated at one million dollars.In Cotton county, a wildfire 4 miles east and 3.5 miles north of Walters destroyed 6 homes and a few barns. The afternoon fire took 5 hours to bring under control. The property damage is estimated at $650,000.In Garvin county, two wildfires moved across the area. A large fire began 3 miles north of Elmore City on State Highway 74 at 1330 CST. The fire burned approximately 6,000 acres and was reported to be 5 miles wide at times. The fire was eventually stopped southwest of White Bead and 5 miles from Pauls Valley at around 0130 CST on November 28, 2005. A total of 100 firefighters and law enforcement personnel from 14 departments responded to the fast moving fire. Approximately 150 residents were evacuated from the area. This fire destroyed 2 houses and a mobile home along with several outbuildings in the area. The estimated property damage for this fire is $350,000. Another smaller fire was reported 5 miles northeast of Pauls Valley about a half hour after the first fire, 1400 CST. This fire burned about 500 acres and was reported to have 20 foot flames at times. The fire was eventually contained around 2000 CST. Even though this fire was smaller, it did destroy several outbuildings. The fire is thought to have been set by an electric fence charger. However, no official cause has been reported. The estimate property damage with this smaller fire is around $50,000.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: No entry
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire began near the town of Velma on November 27, 2005 and continued into the early part of December. This fire caused the evacuation of a town. Several homes and outbuildings were destroyed by the fire. This fire was eventually contained on December 3. Refer to the corresponding wildfire entry in November for further details.

Grass fires burned approximately 1466 acres in Beckham county, 759 acres in Stephens county, and 300 acres in Atoka on the 16th.

With D4 Exceptional Drought conditions ongoing across Red River Parish during the middle of October, the wildfire danger was very high.  A wildfire began in the Martin Community during the afternoon of October 15th and quickly spread to near 500 acres.  The fire consumed grassland and timberland.  The location was north of Hwy. 155 between St. Mary Church Road and LA. Hwy. 507.  Five structures were lost including one inhabited dwelling but there were no injuries.  One tractor was also lost.  The fire was 100% contained as of 7 pm on October 16th.
Very dry conditions for the last several months across northern Louisiana resulted in a very high fire danger across many parishes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire quickly spread out of control just south of Winnfield, Louisiana on October 28th.  Bull dozers were used to push the fire lines that were continually jumped by the fire.  The blaze moved from the ground to the crown of some 30-foot tall trees and quickly spread.  Tanker drops were also used to try and contain the fire and protect homes.  The blaze was contained that evening but not before 250 acres were burned with the loss of some out buildings.  Firefighters on scene estimated that 10 homes were in imminent danger but were saved by firefighting efforts.  The fire was located near Cedar Drive and Old Alexandria Road.  In addition to the out buildings, one rent house was destroyed.  One fireman suffered a minor injury as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions resulted in a wildfire that spread across Webster and Bossier Parishes in Northwest Louisiana during the afternoon of September 19th.  The fire destroyed 258 acres of timberland and resulted in one injury to a firefighter.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Agriculture and Forestry Commissioner said a Louisiana Department of Agriculture and Forestry (LDAF) District One wildland firefighter received minor injuries combating a 258-acre wildland fire in Webster and Bossier parishes on Sunday, September 19th.|The employee was treated at a local hospital emergency room for minor burns. The fire is suspected to have been caused by an outdoor trash fire in Webster Parish that spread out of control, LDAF forestry investigators said. The cause of the fire is still under investigation. The fire eventually consumed 258-acres of a ten-year-old pine plantation.  13 LDAF personnel operating one fire-detecting aircraft and four tractor-plow units responded to the emergency call about 12:10 p.m. LDAF crews contained the fire nine hours later.  No homes or structures were damaged by the fire, but the burn line came within 850 feet of a mobile home park near Doyline.  LDAF Forest Protection Branch officials estimated the fire cost more than $6,000 to contain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions and very hot temperatures and highway sparks from a tractor trailer were the ingredients needed to ignite a large fire across northern Caddo Parish.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two camp homes have been lost to a woods fire burning between Oil City and Vivan in Caddo Parish.  The northern Caddo Parish fire started early Saturday afternoon along Trees City Road, which is also LA Highway 2. The fire spread to both sides of the road. Fire crews dug trenches around the fire to try to keep it from spreading. There are some other homes in the area that were threatened by the fire.  Roads had to be blocked in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong sustained winds and wind gusts, in association with Tropical Storm Lee which made landfall across the south central and southeast Louisiana gulf coast, were felt across all of Northwest Louisiana on September 4th and 5th.  These winds, along with very low humidity values and exceptional drought conditions across Northwest Louisiana, resulted in critical wildfire threat being met across the region.  A wildfire began near Oil City, Louisiana on September 5th, consuming 3000 acres of timberland and grassland before being contained on September 6th.  Two homes were destroyed in the wildfire along with several fishing camps along Caddo Lake.  Several roads were closed including Hwy. 1, Hwy. 2, Hwy. 538, Mt. Gilead Road and Crawford Road.  A state of emergency was declared by the Louisiana governor and the National Guard was deployed.  Water was brought in to help fight the fire from nearby Caddo Lake by the Louisiana Department of Agriculture and Forestry.

Strong sustained winds and wind gusts, in association with Tropical Storm Lee which made landfall across the south central and southeast Louisiana gulf coast, were felt across all of Northwest Louisiana on September 4th and 5th. These winds, along with very low humidity values and exceptional drought conditions across Northwest Louisiana, resulted in critical wildfire threat being met across the region.  A wildfire started in extreme northern Caddo Parish near the Ida and Rodessa communities.  Nearly 300 acres were burned with these wildfires with evacuations having to be needed for residents near Hwy. 168 and State Line Road.  Three mobile homes were consumed along with three outbuildings.

The slow moving remnants of Tropical Storm Lee continued to meander across the north central Gulf Coast.  Very dry and breezy conditions continued across Northwest Louisiana which combined with exceptional drought conditions, resulted in critical fire danger continuing across Northwest Louisiana.  A wildfire began in northern Caddo Parish in the community of Vivian on September 7th.  This fire was small in size, only consuming 26 acres of timberland, but one firefighter was injured when he fell off his truck.  There were several structures involved but it was not known if any of the structures were consumed or not.
No entry
No entry
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire burned nearly 500 acres of land around Broken Arrow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Wagoner fire department fought a grass fire near Elevator Road at the Verdigris River.
A wildfire burned hundreds of acres of land in the western portion of the county.
A wildfire burned about 4000 acres of land around the Haskell area.

Despite the recent rains, vegetation remained dormant and dry, which helped promote the spread of wildfire on the 26th when warm and windy conditions developed across the area.  A number of fires were started and quickly grew out of control during the afternoon.  The most notable fires occurred near Bristow in Creek County, near Muskogee in Muskogee County, near Scipio in Pittsburg County (a house was damaged in this fire), across western Wagoner County, and across portions of Okfuskee and Okmulgee Counties.

Unseasonably warm temperatures, very low relative humidity, and gusty wind combined with drought-stricken, dormant vegetation to promote the rapid spread of a number of wildfires across eastern Oklahoma during late February 2017. The largest wildfires occurred in Latimer County where over 1800 acres burned, Pittsburg County where over 900 acres burned, Wagoner County where over 500 acres burned, and Haskell County where over 300 acres burned. These fires burned for a number of days before they were contained.
No entry
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several grass fires erupted across north Texas due to low humidities...strong winds...and the ongoing drought.  2000 acres burned in rural Jack County, and a 2 1/2 mile wide area of cedar trees burned near Ranger in Eastland County.  Another 6000 acres caught on fire in Johnson County between Godley and Joshua, destroying 24 structures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: No entry
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At least four thousand acres burned in Jack county due to a grass fire.  No buildings were reportedly damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire over 2000 acres resulted in over a dozen residential evacuations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 2,170 acre wildfire occurred in Jack County. No structures were destroyed but 12-18 residents had to be evacuated for a few hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry and windy conditions resulted in explosive fire conditions in north Texas on this day. Some wildfires were rekindled fires that had been smoldering from earlier in the week. These wildfires burned tens of thousands of acres, multiple structures, and killed cattle. Two fatalities occurred in Stoenburg as a couple tried to protect their home. Several of the fires were being fought or watched until April 11th and 12th when rain brought relief to parts of north Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearly 50,000 acres of land were burned in several wildfires that ravaged the county. It was reported that 14 homes were lost in fires that ignited near Postoak, Newport, Squaw Mountain, Antelope, Bryson, and Two Bush. The Two Bush fire consumed nearly 2200 acres of land and was started by welding. Another fire crossed into Jack County from Young County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A grass fire in Jack County consumed approximately 1,000 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A farmer accidentally ignited the Rock Creek Fire.  The fire began near Kinder Mountain Road and Rock Creek Road, and burned approximately 1,000 acres. No structures were damaged or lost in this fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several wildfires broke out on March 11th under critical fire weather conditions. In Hood County, a small wildfire burned 2 homes. The Big Trickle Ranch Fire burned over 4000 acres in Bosque and Somervell County. The most significant fire was the Enmin Fire in Jack County that burned over 7000 acres and destroyed several homes and structures. A total of 3 firefighters were injured while fighting the fires that started on this day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Enmin Fire began 2 miles southwest of Jacksboro near Eason Road and Farm Road 4. It was started by electrical wires that caught on fire. The Enmin Fire burned 7,555 acres with a total burn scar over 12 miles long. The fire was mostly contained by the evening of the 11th but continued to burn for several more days. Two homes, 5 barns, 4 sheds, and a hunting cabin were destroyed in the fire. One additional home was partially damaged. Nearly 150 homes had to be evacuated on the west side of Jacksboro. Acres of pasture land and hundreds of bales of hay were burned in the fire. One vehicle accident occurred due to low visibility from the smoke, but the occupant was not injured.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several wildfires broke out in the western counties of North Texas from April 15th-19th. It took several days to control these fires. They burned over 18000 acres of land. The largest wildfire was the Bryson Complex in western Jack and eastern Young County. Fires in Eastland County killed one firefighter and burned 6 more.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bryson Complex Fire burned a total of 7500 acres and consisted of two fires: The Rockcreek Fire that burned 5300 acres and the Shanafelt Fire that burned 2200 acres. Some of this acreage was in neighboring Young County. One fire was started by downed electrical lines. U.S. Highway 380 west of Bryson in Young County had to be closed for several hours on the 23rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Armstrong Fire began July 12th approximately 6 miles north of Bryson near FM 1191 and Berwick Road. The fire was controlled on July 14th and burned approximately 700 acres. Very hot and dry conditions this month resulted in elevated fire danger.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Armstrong Fire began July 12th approximately 6 miles north of Bryson near FM 1191 and Berwick Road. The fire was controlled on July 14th and burned approximately 700 acres. The fire was started by logging equipment. No structures or homes were lost or damaged by this fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Elevated fire weather conditions persisted for most of the month due to the extreme heat and the ongoing historic drought. Many wildfires occurred during the month burning over 40,000 acres of land, several homes, and lots of personal property. From the 6th through the 10th, there were 5 grass fires that caused damage. The largest and most damaging of these fires was the 7328-acre Cherry Homes Fire in northern Jack County. A 3840-acre fire also occurred in northern Grayson County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cherry Homes fire burned approximately 7328 acres of range land. It started approximately 13 miles northeast of Jacksboro at Cundiff Crafton Road. The fire started on the 7th from a campfire, was contained on the 10th, and controlled on the 14th. A travel trailer and a barn were destroyed in the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Elevated fire weather conditions persisted for most of the month due to the extreme heat and the ongoing historic drought. Many wildfires occurred during the month burning over 40,000 acres of land, several homes, and lots of personal property. From the 1st through the 5th, there were 6 grass fires that caused damage. The largest and most damaging of these fires was the 1701-acre Center City Fire that occurred in Mills County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Post Oak Fire began on August 1st, was contained on the 3rd, and fully controlled on the 4th. The fire started approximately 9 miles north of Jacksboro and burned 571 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Elevated fire weather conditions persisted for most of the month due to the extreme heat and the ongoing historic drought. Many wildfires occurred during the month burning over 40,000 acres of land, several homes, and lots of personal property. From the 21st through the 25th, there were 2 grass fires that caused damage. A 2600-acre fire, named the Campsey Fire, burned in northern Jack County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Campsey Fire began approximately 11 miles north of Jacksboro just west of Old Postoak Road. The fire burned approximately 2600 acres. Two local firefighters were treated for heat related illnesses while working this fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large wildfire in southwestern Choctaw County burned more than 1000 acres over a 10 mile swath.  Some of the communities near the fire were Unger, Speer and Boswell.  At least four homes were destroyed and 2 people were injured.
Grass fires occurred across rural Choctaw County to the east of Hugo.

Strong wind, low relative humidities, warm temperatures, and dormant vegetation promoted the spread of wildfire on the 20th. Around 70 wildfires were reported this day across eastern Oklahoma burning more than 4000 acres. Some of the larger wildfires occurred in Pittsburg, Latimer, Haskell, Adair, and Pushmataha Counties. ||Local fire departments along with Oklahoma Forestry Services, the Bureau of Indian Affairs and the Oklahoma Army National Guard battled those blazes, many of which threatened structures. Several outbuildings were burned but no homes were lost.

Unseasonably warm temperatures, low relative humidity, and strong and gusty southerly wind combined with drought-stricken, dormant vegetation to promote the rapid spread of a number of wildfires across eastern Oklahoma on the 30th and 31st. The largest wildfires occurred in Choctaw and Pushmataha Counties, where over 300 acres were burned. A wildfire also consumed over 150 acres in Adair County.
Wildfires burned hundreds of acres of grassland across Rogers County.  One mobile home was consumed by wildfire.
A wildfire burned hundreds of acres of land near Verdigris.
No entry
A large wildfire burned about three miles north of Okemah Lake Road.  The fire threatened homes and several fire departments responded.

Despite the recent rains, vegetation remained dormant and dry, which helped promote the spread of wildfire on the 26th when warm and windy conditions developed across the area.  A number of fires were started and quickly grew out of control during the afternoon.  The most notable fires occurred near Bristow in Creek County, near Muskogee in Muskogee County, near Scipio in Pittsburg County (a house was damaged in this fire), across western Wagoner County, and across portions of Okfuskee and Okmulgee Counties.

Strong wind, low relative humidities, warm temperatures, and dormant vegetation promoted the spread of wildfire on the 20th. Around 70 wildfires were reported this day across eastern Oklahoma burning more than 4000 acres. Some of the larger wildfires occurred in Pittsburg, Latimer, Haskell, Adair, and Pushmataha Counties. ||Local fire departments along with Oklahoma Forestry Services, the Bureau of Indian Affairs and the Oklahoma Army National Guard battled those blazes, many of which threatened structures. Several outbuildings were burned but no homes were lost.

Southerly winds of 20 to 30 mph, relative humidities below 20 percent, temperatures in the lower to middle 70s, and dormant vegetation promoted the spread of wildfire on the 11th. More than 40 wildfires were reported this day across eastern Oklahoma, burning around 8600 acres. Some of the larger wildfires occurred in Pushmataha County (1600 acres burned), Latimer County (1500 acres burned), and Le Flore County (1500 acres burned). ||Local fire departments along with Oklahoma Forestry Services, the Bureau of Indian Affairs and the Oklahoma Army National Guard battled those blazes, many of which threatened structures. Several outbuildings were burned but no homes were lost.

Very hot temperatures, low relative humidity values, and ongoing drought conditions promoted the rapid spread of a wildfire that consumed 350 acres. The fire burned 8 outbuildings and threatened 7 homes before it was controlled.

Warm, dry, and very windy conditions, combined with dormant vegetation resulted in the rapid spread of wildfire on February 18th. Wildfires burned over 20,000 acres of land in Okfuskee County, which destroyed several outbuildings. Several thousands of acres were burned in Okmulgee County, which also destroyed outbuildings. In Pawnee County, more than 3300 acres were burned by wildfire, also destroying several outbuildings. Over 500 acres were burned in Latimer County.

Unseasonably warm temperatures, strong gusty wind, low relative humidity, and drought-stricken, dormant vegetation promoted the rapid spread of several large wildfires in eastern Oklahoma during the end of March. Wildfires burned over 6300 acres in Pittsburg County, over 1800 acres in Okfuskee County, and over 400 acres in Pushmataha County from the 22nd through the 23rd.
No entry
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large fire in Granbury, Hood County, burned several acres and destroyed 30 homes.  A number of livestock were also killed in the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry and windy conditions resulted in explosive fire conditions in north Texas on this day. Some wildfires were rekindled fires that had been smoldering from earlier in the week. These wildfires burned tens of thousands of acres, multiple structures, and killed cattle. Two fatalities occurred in Stoenburg as a couple tried to protect their home. Several of the fires were being fought or watched until April 11th and 12th when rain brought relief to parts of north Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One wildfire between Lipan and Tolar burned one home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several wildfires broke out on March 11th under critical fire weather conditions. In Hood County, a small wildfire burned 2 homes. The Big Trickle Ranch Fire burned over 4000 acres in Bosque and Somervell County. The most significant fire was the Enmin Fire in Jack County that burned over 7000 acres and destroyed several homes and structures. A total of 3 firefighters were injured while fighting the fires that started on this day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The River View Trail fire burned only 6 acres approximately 7.5 miles southeast of Granbury, but it burned 2 homes to the ground. One person was taken to the hospital in conjunction with this fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several wildfires broke out on March 11th under critical fire weather conditions. In Hood County, a small wildfire burned 2 homes. The Big Trickle Ranch Fire burned over 4000 acres in Bosque and Somervell County.
