EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Windy conditions during the afternoon of October 17th spread a number of small wildfires in north Idaho. Several of the fires were caused by previously completed burn piles which were not properly extinguished.  One fire was sparked by blowing tree branches creating arcing electrical wires. This fire spread into structures and destroyed 5 automobiles and a barn. Local observations recorded wind gusts to 44 mph during this wind storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Sagle, Idaho a wildfire destroyed 5 automobiles and a barn before being brought under control.  The fire was started by arcing electrical wires from swaying trees during windy conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions over north Idaho during July and August created dry fuel conditions across the region. Lightning from occasional thunderstorms moving through the region most notably during the last week of July, caused a number of wildfires some of which grew large and long lasting requiring considerable state and federal resources to contain. These large fires were in unpopulated forest land with no structures or homes lost. Smoke from these fires and fires in surrounding states and provinces often severely degraded air quality across eastern Washington and north Idaho during the month of August.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cougar Wildfire near Hope Idaho is believed to have been started by lightning on July 28th. The fire grew and eventually burned 7,866 acres of timber. No structures of homes were lost or threatened. The cost of the firefighting resources required to contain the fire was calculated at 5.1 million dollars.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions over north Idaho during July and August created dry fuel conditions across the region. Lightning from occasional thunderstorms moving through the region most notably during the last week of July, caused a number of wildfires some of which grew large and long lasting requiring considerable state and federal resources to contain. These large fires were in unpopulated forest land with no structures or homes lost. Smoke from these fires and fires in surrounding states and provinces often severely degraded air quality across eastern Washington and north Idaho during the month of August.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Smith Creek Wildfire is believed to have been caused by lightning on July 27th. The fire consumed 1113 acres of timber in the mountains 7 miles NE of Priest Lake. No structures were lost or threatened. The cost of the resources needed to contain the fire was calculated at 299 thousand dollars.

CZ_NAME: NC&S OKANOGAN X EXTREME SE PART/EXTREME N DOUGLAS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Cameron Lake Road Fire, centered four miles south of Omak, was a lightning caused fire that burned 1,567 acres.
The Little Chopaka Fire, centered three miles west of Nighthawk, burned 4,428 acres.
The South Omak Lake Fire, centered 11 miles southeast of Omak, was a human caused fire that burned 10,500 acres.  The fire started on August 30th.
The South Omak Lake Fire, centered 11 miles southeast of Omak, was a human caused fire that burned 10,500 acres.
The Whiskey Mountain Fire occurred between Oroville and Ellisforde, and burned 1,200 acres.
The Tunk Grade Fire, centered 11 miles north of Omak, was a lightning caused fire that burned 15,540 acres.  Ten outbuildings and one structure were lost in the fire.
The Stubblefield Fire, centered 14 miles northeast of Bridgeport, had an unknown cause and burned 1,500 acres.
The Green Lake Fire, centered five miles west of Omak, had an unknown cause and burned 2,614 acres.  The fire burned into the month of August.
The Malott Fire, centered two miles northwest of Malott, was a lightning caused fire that burned 333 acres.
The Green Lake Fire, centered five miles west of Omak, burned 2,614 acres.  The fire start date was July 31st.

The Jackass Butte Fire, centered five miles southwest of Omak, was a lightning caused fire that burned 1,000 acres.  Gusty and erratic winds resulted in rapid fire spread shortly after the begin time of the event.  Three outbuildings were also destroyed by the fire.  A casino and hotel were evacuated during the fire, with 15 homes threatened as well.  Six power poles also burned resulting in the use of battery power to keep dispatch and 911 functioning.  A transmission structure was also lost during the blaze resulting in power outages in Twisp, Winthrop, Malott, and South Okanogan.  Property damage from the fire was estimated to be $20,000.
The Rattlesnake Point Fire, centered one mile southwest of Malott, was a lightning caused fire that burned 2,625 acres.

A strong dry cold front dropped south from British Columbia during the late afternoon and early evening hours.  Windy conditions and low humidities both ahead of and immediately behind the cold front resulted in new large fires over portions of the inland northwest.  The Spokane Valley Fire was human caused and destroyed 11 homes and 10 out buildings in the Dishman Hills area and burned 1,006 acres.  Conditions were very extreme when the fire started with Felts Field at 4 PM PST reported a temperature of 81 degrees, a relative humidity of 10 percent, and sustained west winds of 24 MPH gusting to 44 MPH.  A separate fire in Cheney destroyed a garage.  A state of emergency was declared by the state governor in Spokane and Ferry counties.  The strongest winds from this front channeled down the Okanogan Valley, where Oroville received a peak wind gust of 74 MPH, and Omak 59 MPH.  Numerous trees and power poles were blown down by the high winds.  There was a total of 5,000 power outages mostly around Oroville, Tonasket, and Omak.  In Tonasket, a ten inch diameter tree was downed by the winds, causing extensive damage to a carport and RV.  Power poles were also blown down by the winds in Tonasket.  Blowing dust was also common with the front passage with visibilites as low as a half mile in Omak.  Colville and areas just north of Colville also saw strong winds with gusts to 55 mph which resulted in numerous 12 inch diameter trees as well as several power lines being knocked down.  Eight thousand customers lost power in Colville.  Several trees were blown down on highway 20 west of Republic.  In Kettle Falls, wind gusts to 55 mph knocked down several tree branches. Several other large fires resulted which spread quickly by the strong winds.  These include the French Valley Fire, centered seven miles southeast of Omak, which burned 1,420 acres.  This fire had an unknown cause, which spread rapidly to the south on the 10th by strong north winds.  Fires in Stevens and Ferry Counties resulted mostly from downed power lines.  There was structural damage from the fires to a barn, shed, and home.
The Columbia River Road fire, centered nine miles west of Nespelem, was a fire of unknown cause and burned 22,155 acres.  Twenty homes and 40 outbuildings were threatened by the fire.

A wildfire of unknown cause burned approximately 310 acres just east of Malott, which closed Highway 97 for more than seven hours.  Temperatures into the 90s on the afternoon of September 1st followed by estimated winds of 10 to 20 mph during the evening hours of the 1st and morning hours of the 2nd helped spread the fire.
The Johnson Lake Fire, located six miles north of Nespelem, was a lightning caused fire that burned 955 acres.
A wildfire of unknown cause, was located six miles south of Nespelem, and burned 1,923 acres.  The exact time that the fire began and ended are unknown.
The Salmon Fire, located five miles northwest of Omak, was a human caused fire that burned 1910 acres.  The fire was not completely suppressed until September 6th 2011.
A wildfire burned 408 acres just east of Tonasket, Washington.  The fire which burned through sagebrush and scattered ponderosa pine briefly threatened thirteen homes and burned one outbuilding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Marlys Road wildfire initiated near Hanging Rocks off Highway 20, roughly 20 miles east of Tonasket, and burned to Big Boulder Lane.  The fire burned 408 acres along with one outbuilding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Salmon Fire, located five miles northwest of Omak, was a human caused fire that burned 1910 acres. The fire began on August 29th and was suppressed September 6th.

The Barber Mountain Fire, located thirteen miles northwest of Oroville, WA burned a total of 497 acres in Washington and 40 acres in British Columbia, Canada.  The fire burned through mostly grass and small brush.

The Buffalo Lake Road Fire started at 2030 on Tuesday, August 14, 2012 and grew quickly due to high winds burning approximately 7,800 acres by the evening of August 15th. The lightning caused fire eventually grew to 11,299 acres and was fully contained on Sunday August 19th.  The fire was located approximately 5 miles north of Coulee Dam, WA and burned through grass, shrubs, bitter brush, and pockets of scattered timber.  Nine homes and the communities of Elmer City and Coulee Dam were threatened. Two outbuildings (barns) were burned.

The St Mary's Mission Road Fire started Tuesday, October 2nd, at approximately 15:40 PST near the intersection of Highway 155 and St Mary's Mission Road.  The first night the wind driven fire burned approximately 5,000 acres. Two homes and eight structures were lost. The Paschal Sherman Indian School along with residents located near the historic St. Mary's Mission, were evacuated.  The St Marys Mission Road Wildfire burned 17,031 acres of brush and spotty trees approximately four miles southeast of Omak, WA.  The cause of the fire is still under investigation.

A weak dry cold front pushed down the Okanogan Valley on the 15th, which resulted in breezy northerly winds.  A prolonged period of dry weather combined with the breezy afternoon winds resulted in good conditions for rapid wildfire spread.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was a fast moving brush fire that ignited along Highway 20 just west of Okanogan.  The fire was believed to be started by a lawn mower early on the sixteenth; the time of ignition was estimated.  The fire burned through 2,000 acres before being contained on the seventeenth.  Two outbuildings were destroyed.  The fire also burnt down a wooden 115 thousand volt transmission H structure on the Loup transmission line.  This resulted in the breaker opening at the Okanogan substation, which in turn resulted in a loss of power out of the substation into the Methow Valley.  Material damage to Public Utility District assets were estimated at fewer than 20 thousand dollars and the cost of the outage was estimated to be 60 to 70 thousand dollars.  The fire also destroyed one outbuilding (estimated at 10,000 dollars), one hay baler (estimated at 4,000 dollars), one hay swather (estimated at 12,000 dollars), five miles of orchard fence (estimated at 150,000 dollars) and two hundred fruit trees (estimate at 350,000 dollars).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The largest fire in Washington State history is now the 2014 Carlton Complex. Central Washington was in drought status. The fire was started by lightning on July 14. The complex started as four fires; the Stokes Fire, The Gold Hikes Fire, the French Creek Fire, and the Cougar Flat Fire. Explosive fire activity occurred on July 16th with very hot, dry, and unstable conditions in place. Each fire then made runs over the ridgetops and grew into one fire between July 17th and July 18th as hot and windy conditions developed. The fire rapidly spread through the communities of Methow, Pateros, Carlton, and Olema, and portions of Brewster consuming approximately 325 homes, barns, outbuildings and fences, utilities, cattle and livestock, and orchards, crops, forest, and range land in its path. The fire burned 269,186 acres consisting of a combination of brush, timber and heavy fuels.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The lightning-caused fire, which began July 14, blackened 269,186 acres; leveled approximately 325 homes, 146 barns, outbuildings and fences; damaged utilities, killed cattle, wildlife and other livestock, and destroyed or damaged orchards, crops, forest and range land. Total cost to fight the fire was approximately 87 million dollars.  The fire spanned two different public zones and cost and acreage is highly uncertain per zone.

The fire burned 269,186 acres consisting of a combination of brush, timber and heavy fuels.

Total cost to fight the fire was approximately 87 million dollars.  The fire spanned two different public zones and cost and acreage is highly uncertain per zone.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This human cause wildfire burned 218,138 acres and cost over $44 million dollars to suppress.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This human cause wildfire burned 218,138 acres and cost over $44 million dollars to suppress.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This complex of wildfires ignition cause remains undetermined. The complex of wildfires originated Friday August 14,2015 and burned over 88,985 acres and cost over $21 million dollars to suppress.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This complex of wildfires ignition cause remains undetermined. The complex of wildfires originated Friday August 14,2015 and burned over 88,985 acres and cost over $21 million dollars to suppress.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This complex of lightning caused wildfires which started Friday August 14th and have burned 133,707 acres as of September 20th. This complex included the Twisp river fire which resulted in 3 firefighter fatalities on August 19,2015.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This complex of lightning caused wildfires which started Friday August 14th and have burned 133,707 acres as of September 20th.  Costs to suppress are estimated at over $46 million dollars.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This human cause wildfire burned 218,138 acres and cost over $44 million dollars to suppress.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front passage on Friday August 21st brought windy conditions and resulted in substantial blowing dust. Additionally the very hot and dry conditions and wildfire ignitions (both human caused and from lightning) over the two to three days preceding it resulted in explosive fire growth for numerous fires in Eastern Washington.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at Omak, WA reported a wind gust of 50 mph which contributed to extreme fire behavior on this day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Timm Ranch Fire, located 12 miles east of Bridgeport, WA burned 1,358 acres in Okanogan county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Official federal agency reports note that the Timm Ranch fire was human caused. Costs of suppression estimated at $30,000.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire began in the range land near the town of Okanogan during the afternoon of September 1st. The fire burned 142 acres and damaged vehicles parked in a field near a garage. One firefighter suffered severe burns when a wind gust blew the fire back on him as he was fighting the fire. He was immediately evacuated for treatment but eventually died of these burns on October 2nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Spring Coulee Fire began from an unknown cause during the afternoon of September 1st two miles west of the town of Okanogan. The fire was quickly contained after burning 142 acres of range land and damaging some vehicles. One firefighter was severely burned while fighting the fire and eventually died of his injuries on October 2nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Palouse River Fire, centered six miles east of La Crosse, had an unknown cause and burned 2,500 acres.
Lightning strikes triggered two large wildfires in Whitman County.  One fire occurred near Hooper and burned 10,200 acres.  The other fire burned near Dusty and burned 5,500 acres.
Lightning strikes triggered two large wildfires in Whitman County.  One fire occurred near Hooper and burned 10,200 acres.  The other fire burned near Dusty and burned 5,500 acres.
A wildfire was started by lightning in north Whitman County near Rock Lake, burning more than 2,200 acres.  A heavy rain shower following the fire start slowed down the fire spread.

A combination of gusty winds and low relative humidity contributed to a couple new large fire starts.  The Slide Creek Fire, centered six miles south of Colville, burned 989 acres, two homes, and one outbuilding.  The Fish Hatchery Fire, centered three miles north of Republic, burned 667 acres.  Meanwhile, several other fires briefly brought an impact to the general public.  Four miles south of Pullman, the Hatley Road Fire burned 50 acres and closed Highway 195 from milepost 15 to milepost 19.  This fire came close to several homes. Another fire in Davenport led to the Lincoln County Fair briefly being evacuated.  This fire also closed Highway 2.  Another fire occurred six miles southwest of Davenport, burning 600 acres.  The fire knocked out power to Davenport, destroyed one barn, closed Highway 28, and sporadically closed Highway 2.
This fire 26 miles south of Brewster Washington burned 2,424 acres and cost $175,000 to contain/suppress.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This fire 26 miles south of Brewster Washington burned 2,424 acres and cost $175,000 to contain/suppress.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The fire started on August 2 at 12:50pm and quickly grew due to high winds and dry conditions. It started in Garfield County, across from Granite Point, on the Snake River. The fire jumped the river to Whitman County at about 4:30pm. The fire was fought on both sides of the river; Garfield county to the south, and Whitman county to the north. The fire was approximately 10 miles northeast of Pomeroy, WA, 10 miles directly south of Pullman, and 24 miles west of Clarkston. The Snake River Fire burned 11,453 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Costs associated with suppression/mitigation of the Snake River fire were noted to be 1.6 million dollars.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: No entry
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous grass fires were triggered by lightning strikes from dry thunderstorms and existing dry conditions. All fires were relatively small, and responded to by fire departments from Woonsocket, Letcher, and Artesian.

CZ_NAME: LITTLE COLORADO RIVER VALLEY IN NAVAJO COUNTY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: No entry
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Potato Complex Fire started on June 6th, 2006, and originally consisted of four separate lightning-caused fires ten miles northwest of Heber-Overgaard, Arizona. Named for Potato Creek, the Potato complex burned in Ponderosa Pine, grass understory, Pinyon, and Juniper on the Black Mesa Ranger District of the Apache-Sitgreaves National Forest. There were 374 personnel assigned to this fire including 7 Regular Crews, 2 Camp Crews, 7 Dozers, 13 Engines, 11 Water Tenders, 2 Air Tankers, and a light Helicopter.  The fire burned about 6,300 acres with a total suppression cost of about $3.5 million.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning caused the ignition of the Outlaw 2 wildfire approximately 20 miles southwest of Kaycee on Tuesday, August 22.  The fire occurred near a famed area called Hole-in-the-Wall.  The fire spread rapidly on Wednesday, August 23, growing from an estimated 300 acres on Tuesday to approximately 10,000 acres by midday Thursday, August 24.  An estimated 12,270 acres were destroyed by the fire.  One outbuilding and a restored historic cabin dating to early Wyoming history in the 19th century were consumed by the fire.  The cost of the firefighting efforts reached $800,000.

Two large wildfires burned out of control for several hours across portions of Ellsworth and Lincoln Counties on Sunday, July 30th. The first blaze started late Sunday afternoon in Ellsworth County, just north I-70 between mile markers 207 and 208. Southerly winds of 35 mph rapidly spread the fire north into southwest Lincoln County, where it raged out of control and did the majority of its damage. One family had to be evacuated from their home. As this fire continued to spread, a second blaze ignited a few hours later just north of Sylvan Grove, near the junction of highways 181 and 18. Both blazes were eventually brought under control, and were finally extinguished by early Monday morning, but not before consuming over 1,000 acres of grassland. Utility poles, trees and fence lines were destroyed, but no major structures were lost. Fortunately, no injuries or deaths occurred.

Lightning ignited a fire near Makoshika State Park in Sand Creek about 7 miles south of Glendive.  The fire burned 33 acres of juniper, ponderosa pine and grass on Bureau of Land Management land and private land.

Lightning ignited 14 fires in Dawson County.  Most of the fires were 40 acres or less, but there were a couple of larger fires.  The largest fires were a 120 acre fire that burned conservation reserve land along County Road 238, and a 700 acre fire along County Road 130.

A wildfire fourteen miles north-northeast of Boise City Oklahoma burned an estimated five thousand acres and jumped the Cimarron River. One firefighter suffered non-burn related injuries. No damage was reported.

Lightning started a five hundred acre wildfire roughly thirteen miles south southeast of Boise City or just east of the intersection of East to West Road 339 and North to South Road 300 in extreme southern Cimarron County just north of the Texas and Oklahoma state line. No damage or injuries were reported.

Lightning initiated three fires in the vicinity of Camp Bland (Clay County), Florida on Monday afternoon, May 7th.  Strong winds quickly combined those fires into a single blaze with over 5,000 acres burning by Monday night.  The fire area extended from the Starke area to near Waldo in northeastern Alachua County.  By Tuesday 700 homes were evacuated with over 1,000 persons displaced from their homes. State Road 100 was closed from Keystone Heights to Starke and State Road 18 is closed from Hampton to State Road 100.  fanned by high winds and low relative humidity values over the next few days the fire continued to grow eventually reaching 14,626 acres. The fire remains active in the swamp without significant threat to structures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning initiated three fires in the vicinity of Camp Bland (Clay County), Florida on Monday afternoon, May 7th.  Strong winds quickly combined those fires into a single blaze with over 5,000 acres burning by Monday night.  The fire area extended from the Starke area to near Waldo in northeastern Alachua County.  By Tuesday 700 homes were evacuated with over 1,000 persons displaced from their homes. State Road 100 was closed from Keystone Heights to Starke and State Road 18 is closed from Hampton to State Road 100.  Fanned by high winds and low relative humidity values over the next few days the fire continued to grow eventually reaching 14,626 acres. The fire remains active in the swamp without significant threat to structures through the month. As of July 28th the Florida Division of Forestry still had this fire open as an active fire due to the possibility of it reigniting.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Convection helped to tame fires and aided in containment efforts this month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sante Fe Wildfire was about 5 miles WNW of Lake Geneva in Bradford County. On the 1st, the fire had burned about 5,679 acres and was 85 percent contained.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry and unseasonably warm conditions fueled brush fires. Long term drought conditions were realized across much of NE Florida.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 200 acre brush fire was 100% contained in the area of Southeast 109th Street and Southeast 38th Avenue in Hampton. The fire burned on land owned by Two Buck Hunting Club.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Fire broke out April 27th and continued into May. Roundabout On May 3rd the fire was 5,857 acres and 50 percent contained. This fire started on private land four miles west of Pearson and burned southern rough and timber as fuels. Residences and a sewage treatment center were threatened early in the month. By the 10th the fire had reached 95 percent containment with 225 personnel working the fire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fire broke out April 27th and continued into May. Roundabout On May 3rd the fire was 5,857 acres and 50 percent contained. This fire started on private land four miles west of Pearson and burned southern rough and timber as fuels. Residences and a sewage treatment center were threatened early in the month. By the 10th the fire had reached 95 percent containment with 225 personnel working the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Roundabout Swamp Fire - Atkinson County, Georgia. This fire broke out late April 27, 2007. It burned 4 miles west of Pearson, GA and 2 miles southeast of Kirkland, Georgia. 225 fire personnel, 5 Engines, and 21 Dozer/Tractor Plows, as well as state and local law enforcement & emergency services assisted with firefighting efforts. The fire burned 5,805 acres by the end of the month and was 60 percent contained.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roundabout Swamp Fire - Atkinson County, Georgia. This fire broke out late April 27, 2007. It burned 4 miles west of Pearson, GA and 2 miles southeast of Kirkland, Georgia. 225 fire personnel, 5 Engines, and 21 Dozer/Tractor Plows, as well as state and local law enforcement & emergency services assisted with firefighting efforts. The fire burned 5,805 acres by the end of the month and was 60 percent contained.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusual late-season Santa Ana event developed across Southern California in early May. The offshore winds generated record heat and very low relative humidity which led to the development of two wildfires, one near Griffith Park and one on Catalina Island.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Catalina Island wildfire burned 4,750 acres on Catalina Island. The fire, which was started accidentally by a repair crew at the KBRT transmitter tower, was fueled by warm temperatures, low relative humidity and very dry vegetation. The fire burned very close to the community of Avalon, resulting in the evacuation of over 4,000 people from the island. One home and six commercial building were destroyed. Total damage and firefighting cost was approximately $3.3 million. One minor firefighter injury was reported due to smoke inhalation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extended period of dry, gusty weather allowed a forest fire to spread rapidly in the Grassy Ridge community of Swain County during the afternoon and evening. The fire burned 9 homes in the area. More than 200 fire fighters were required to extinguish the blaze.

An extended period of abnormally dry weather and drought conditions that began in late winter of 2016, and continued through the year resulted in very dry vegetation across western North Carolina by mid-autumn. This was exacerbated by an unusually warm late summer and fall, when temperatures averaged as much as 5 degrees above normal. In these conditions, multiple wildfires ignited and spread during the first week of November, culminating in one of the worst wildfire episodes in recent western North Carolina history. Multiple large fires burned, mainly across the southern mountains, and most of these fires were not completely contained until a cold front brought much-needed rain to the area at the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Tellico fire burned more than 13,000 acres in the Nantahala area along the Macon County line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire east of Grand Coulee burned around 500 acres, burning three outbuildings, a summer home, and a pickup.  The fire also temporarily closed highway 174.
The Black Rock Fire, centered eight miles northwest of Odessa, burned 3,492 acres.

The Swanson Lake Fire, centered 17 miles west of Davenport, was a fire of unknown cause and burned 19,090 acres.  The fire caused a brief closure of Highway two from Wilbur to Davenport.  Smoke blowing across State Route 25 caused a temporary closure from Davenport north to the Columbia River.
The Concrete Plant Fire, located two miles northeast of Coulee Dam, was a fire of unknown cause that burned 600 acres.

Breezy conditions resulted in rapid fire spread from a wildfire which burned an estimated 10,000 acres eight miles east of Highway 261 near Benge.  The fire burned old abandoned buildings, and an old homestead.  The end time and property damage from this event are estimated.

A combination of gusty winds and low relative humidity contributed to a couple new large fire starts.  The Slide Creek Fire, centered six miles south of Colville, burned 989 acres, two homes, and one outbuilding.  The Fish Hatchery Fire, centered three miles north of Republic, burned 667 acres.  Meanwhile, several other fires briefly brought an impact to the general public.  Four miles south of Pullman, the Hatley Road Fire burned 50 acres and closed Highway 195 from milepost 15 to milepost 19.  This fire came close to several homes. Another fire in Davenport led to the Lincoln County Fair briefly being evacuated.  This fire also closed Highway 2.  Another fire occurred six miles southwest of Davenport, burning 600 acres.  The fire knocked out power to Davenport, destroyed one barn, closed Highway 28, and sporadically closed Highway 2.

A wildfire started around noon in Grant County about five miles north of Marlin.  Strong winds through the day carried the fire into Lincoln County before a brief period of rainfall later in the afternoon helped fire fighters put out the blaze.  The fire burned approximately 3,000 acres of sagebrush and destroyed one machine shed filled with farm equipment.

The Washington Flats Fire, located three miles northwest of Grand Coulee, was a human caused fire that burned 1100 acres of heavy sage and grass. The fire threatened some homes resulting in level one evacuations but the fire was contained before any property's were damaged.

A wildfire flared up about 17 miles southwest of Creston, WA along Highway 2.  Gusty winds on September 10th pushed the fire northeast as it rapidly grew to 8,000 acres.  The fire burned through grass and sage brush as it grew to 18,000 acres before being contained on September 14th.
The Watermelon Hill fire started in Lincoln County and was fanned by strong westerly winds east into Spokane County.  The fire was started by three individuals shooting explosive targets.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Watermelon Hill fire was wind fanned and quickly grew to 10,500 acres. One hundred homes were threatened but no homes were destroyed in the fire. Two hay barns were burned. More than 100 residents had to be evacuated throughout the area including the Fish Trap Lake Resort.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This fire of undetermined origin started 1 mile northeast of Sprague, WA. It burned 1,500 acres and cost $150,000 to contain/suppress.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This fire of undetermined origin started 1 mile northeast of Sprague, WA. It burned 1,500 acres and cost $150,000 to contain/suppress.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This fire of undetermined cause started 11 miles south of Creston, WA. It burned 542 acres and cost $40,000 to contain/suppress.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This fire of undetermined cause started 11 miles south of Creston, WA. It burned 542 acres and cost $40,000 to contain/suppress.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Elmer City Fire, initially located 1 mile North of Coulee Dam, WA, was a human caused fire. This fire burned 5,237 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Elmer City Fire burned several power poles, knocking out electric power to a few customers of Nespelem Valley Electric. The cause of the fire is still under investigation, but a power line slap (one wire touching the other due to gusty winds) is being looked at, according to officials. Latest official reports noted costs associated with suppression efforts associated with the Elmer City Fire were $600,000.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Hart fire, a human caused wildfire, initially located 13 miles north of Davenport, WA grew to 4,983 acres and was noted to be contained on August 24,2016. This fire jumped the Spokane river and started the Cayuse Mountain fire on the Spokane Indian Reservation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated costs associated with mitigation/suppression of the Hart fire was 2.9 million dollars. The Hart fire destroyed 26 outbuildings and damaged 13 more. It was noted in news stories from the region that 27 homes were lost between the two fires (the Cayuse fire and the Hart fire).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front pushed south across the Mid Atlantic during the afternoon of March 5th. While there was no precipitation associated with the front, strong gusty winds affected the region during the afternoon of March 5th and even into March 6th. These strong winds downed trees and power lines across the region, causing several thousand power outages. |Low relative humidity, strong gusty winds and drying fuels lead to critical fire weather conditions on March 5th. Several small brush fires began when strong winds brought down power lines and transformers and produced sparks.|A trailer-mounted manufactured home briefly became airborne on Interstate 81 near Weyers Cave, VA., in Augusta County, before disintegrating along a hundred-yard stretch of guardrail. Sparks from the impact burned approximately one acre of grass. While emergency workers tended to the blaze, a 1,500 pound bale of hay blew off a farm truck and rolled across the interstate. No damage was caused by the bale of hay.|Strong winds brought down a tree on top of some power lines on Boyers Road in Harrisonburg, VA. A small grass fire started from the sparks. The power pole and transformed had to be replaced|Strong winds downed power lines throughout Albemarle County and the City of Charlottesville. Georgetown Road was closed at Hydraulic Road for most of the afternoon after a downed line caused a fire. About 3,300 customers lost power due to the strong winds.|Albemarle County Fire-Rescue Officers reported about a half-dozen fires were caused by downed power lines. No injuries were reported and many of the fires were quickly contained, however one farm building off Old Lynchburg Road burned.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Albemarle County Fire-Rescue Officers reported about a half-dozen fires were caused by downed power lines. No injuries were reported and many of the fires were quickly contained, however one farm building off Old Lynchburg Road burned.|

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning ignited several clusters of wildfires in western Siskiyou county on 07/10/2007. One cluster of 30 fires became known as the Elk Complex. A Red Flag Warning for dry lightning was in effect when these fires started. The fires burned into August. 1 fatality occurred fighting the fire (non-weather related helicopter crash)in July and costs were 18.3 million dollars as of 08/04/2007, when the fire was handed over to a Type III team. 17,684 acres burned and the fire was 90% contained as of 08/04/2007. Full containment was expected by 09/15/2007.

Lightning ignited several clusters of wildfires in western Siskiyou county on 07/10/2007.  One cluster of 32 fires became known as the Elk Complex.  A Red Flag Warning for dry lightning was in effect when these fires started.   The fires burned into August.  1 fatality occurred fighting the fire (non-weather related helicopter crash) and costs were 17.4 million dollars as of 08/02/2007.  16,449 acres burned and the fire was 80% contained as of 08/02/2007.

The Boles fire started on the afternoon of 09/15/14 and spread quickly due to strong winds.  It  devastated the town of Weed in northern California.  In a matter of hours 222 structures were lost, including many homes and part of a lumber mill.  As of September 21st, the fire was 479 acres in size and was 100 percent contained.  6.2 million dollars were spent on firefighting efforts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Boles fire started on the afternoon of 09/15/14 and spread quickly due to strong winds.  It  devastated the town of Weed in northern California.  In a matter of hours 222 structures were lost, including many homes and part of a lumber mill.  As of September 21st, the fire was 479 acres in size and was 100 percent contained.  6.2 million dollars were spent on firefighting efforts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Grade Wildfire started around 1455 PDT on 08/24/16 2 miles north of Yreka California.  It was likely caused by human activity.  As of 0430 PDT on 08/31/16, the fire covered 710 acres and was 100% contained. 5 residences and 5 outbuildings were destroyed, and another outbuilding was damaged. 2.1 million dollars were spent in firefighting efforts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Grade Wildfire started around 1455 PDT on 08/24/16 2 miles north of Yreka California.  It was likely caused by human activity.  As of 0430 PDT on 08/31/16, the fire covered 710 acres and was 100% contained. 5 residences and 5 outbuildings were destroyed, and another outbuilding was damaged. 2.1 million dollars were spent in firefighting efforts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Klamathon Wildfire started on 07/05/18 at 0031 PDT by someone burning debris.   As of the last report at 22/0330 PST, the fire covered 38008 acres and was 100 percent contained.  33.5 million dollars had been expended on firefighting efforts. One death was reported and 82 structures were lost.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Klamathon Wildfire started on 07/05/18 at 0031 PDT by someone burning debris.   As of the last report at 22/0330 PST, the fire covered 38008 acres and was 100 percent contained.  33.5 million dollars had been expended on firefighting efforts. One death was reported and 82 structures were lost.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms moved across the area on 9/5/19.  Dozens of fires were initiated by lightning.  One of them was the Lime Wildfire, which was started by a lightning strike at 05/1119 PDT.  As of the last report on 22/0430 PDT, the fire was at 1872 acres and was 99 percent contained.  0 structures were lost and 9.0 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms moved across the area on 9/5/19.  Dozens of fires were initiated by lightning.  One of them was the Lime Wildfire, which was started by a lightning strike at 05/1119 PDT.  As of the last report on 22/0430 PDT, the fire was at 1872 acres and was 99 percent contained.  0 structures were lost and 9.0 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The highest winds across the southeast plains occurred around La Junta, where winds gusted to around 60 mph.  Wildfires broke out in Pueblo County, Crowley County, and Bent County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A fire, started by a cigarette, burned close to 500 acres near Ordway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire erupted west of Ordway and strong winds spread the blaze rapidly east northeastward.  Highways 96 and 71 were shut down, as 8900 acres of grassland was consumed. Twenty-four structures were destroyed west and north of Ordway. Over 150 power poles were destroyed.  The entire town of Ordway was evacuated.  Tragically, two firefighters perished when the truck they were in plummeted into a culvert, where a bridge had burned out.
A fire, caused by a discarded cigarette, consumed 300 acres of pasture in eastern Crowley County.  There was no damage to structures.

Dry conditions were enhanced by windy and unseasonably warm weather during the weekend of April 21 through April 22. As a result, wildfires occurred near Black River Falls (Jackson County), Tomah (Monroe County) and Necedah (Juneau County). All three fires were contained within a few hours and did not affect any buildings or homes.

A small central Wisconsin wildfire destroyed six buildings southeast of Necedah (Juneau County) on May 2nd. Dry conditions across central Wisconsin helped to fuel the fire that started on a warm afternoon. The fire destroyed three houses and three outbuildings. None of the houses were occupied and were only used for storage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three unoccupied homes and three outbuildings were destroyed by a small wildfire southeast of Necedah. The fire was fueled by dry conditions and started on a warm  afternoon. The fire burned about 4 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An April 13th wildfire near Necedah (Juneau County) burned over 300 acres before being extinguished by the Wisconsin DNR and four local fire departments. The fire was likely started by a passing train and then spread quickly by winds that gusted close to 30 mph. Flames from the fire approached a factory, which was evacuated as a precaution. The smoke spread over a residential neighborhood prompting officials to evacuate about 44 homes. No structures were burned, but one fire fighter was treated for smoke inhalation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire started by a passing train, burned 336 acres near Necedah. At one point, the flames approached a factory which was evacuated as a precaution. The smoke from the fire spread over a residential neighborhood, prompting officials to evacuate homes in the area. One fire fighter was treated for smoke inhalation. State Highway 80 south of Necedah was closed due to the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire in the Necedah Wildlife Refuge (Juneau County) burned 240 acres of lowland marsh regions on April 18th. While there were no injuries because of the fire, some residents near the refuge had to be evacuated for safety precautions and State Highway 80 north of Necedah was closed. The remote automated weather station on the refuge reported favorable fire conditions as the relative humidity fell to under 25% with southwest winds of 15 to 20 mph gusting as high as 39 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire burned around 240 acres of lowland and marsh region in the Necedah Wildlife Refuge on April 18th. Some residents living near the refuge had to be evacuated for safety precautions and State Highway 80 was closed north of Necedah. The remote automated weather station located on the refuge indicated the relative humidity fell to under 25% during the afternoon with southwest winds of 15 to 20 mph gusting up to 39 mph.

CZ_NAME: LOS ANGELES COUNTY COASTS INCLUDING DOWNTOWN LOS ANGELES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an upper level disturbance and strong onshore gradients produced strong and damaging winds across Southern California, especially across southern Santa Barbara county, the mountains of Ventura and Los Angeles counties and the Antelope Valley. The gusty winds knocked down trees and power lines, producing widespread power outages across sections of Los Angeles county and a damaging wildfire in the Beverly Glen area. Across the coastal waters off of Ventura, Los Angeles and Orange counties, large wind waves and a combination of large northwest and south swell produced very hazardous conditions. At Newport Beach, two individuals were swept off of a jetty and drowned as a result of the large waves. In Ventura county, two individuals were rescued off of Ventura Pier when they jumped into the water on a bet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A downed power line sparked a 50 acre wildfire in the Beverly Glen area, just northwest of Beverly Hills. This fire destroyed one mansion and damaged two other homes. No deaths or injuries were reported.

CZ_NAME: LOS ANGELES COUNTY COASTS INCLUDING DOWNTOWN LOS ANGELES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Woolsey Fire burned 96,949 acres in Ventura and Los Angeles counties, destroying over 1500 structures. The fire ignited during a strong Santa Ana wind event and the combination of gusty winds and very dry conditions allowed the fire to spread very quickly.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Woolsey Fire burned 96,949 across in Ventura and Los Angeles county. The fire ignited during a strong Santa Ana wind event. Gusty north to northeast winds (in excess of 60 MPH) and very dry conditions allowed the fire to spread very quickly. In total, the Woolsey Fire destroyed 1,643 structures (including 400 homes) and damaged an additional 364 structures. Three deaths were attributed to the fire. Two deaths occurred when an SUV was overrun by flames and the third death occurred in a destroyed home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prescribed burn by the U.S. Forest Service on the 27th blazed out of control by the 29th fueled by low relative humidity and strong west winds gusting over 40 mph. The wildfire consumed more than 1300 acres in western Baraga County until it was mostly contained by the end of the 30th. |Another fire in northwest Marquette County destroyed three structures and burned approximately 60 acres before it was brought under control on the 29th.  A downed power line on Green Garden Road in eastern Marquette County also left 60 homes without power for several hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire in Powell Township near Big Bay destroyed three structures including an abandoned VFW hall on the 29th. The fire burned approximately sixty acres before it was brought under control. |A fire-related power outage on Green Garden Road in eastern Marquette County left sixty homes without power for several hours on the 29th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm frontal passage on the 20th pushed record heat and very dry conditions across Upper Michigan. This warm front combined with wind gusts up to 50 mph to spark two large wildfires in the afternoon across Marquette and Baraga Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Black River Falls Wildfire started southwest of Ishpeming in Marquette County on the afternoon of the 20th. The wildfire was ignited when a jack pine tree branch split off the main stem from strong southerly winds and fell across a power line. The wildfire burned 811 acres, destroyed 21 residences and 12 other structures. The fire fighting efforts were led by the Michigan DNR. The wildfire was contained on the 22nd and mop up efforts continued into the 26th.  The cost for personnel and equipment to fight the wildfire was estimated at near $100,000. The total damage estimate is unknown at this time but presumed to be in the millions of dollars.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Grapevine Wildfire near Silver Lake Basin north of Ishpeming burned between 80 and 100 acres in late July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Grapevine Wildfire started on the afternoon of the 29th and burned into the 31st.  The wildfire burned between 80 and 100 acres.  Numerous local fire departments responded and help suppress the fire around its edges.  Heavy equipment was also used to build up barriers around the fire.  No structures were lost in the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major forest fire broke out near Ham Lake on May 5th due to an unattended campfire, and was called the Ham Lake Fire.  The fire spread north across the upper portions of the Gunflint Trail, and into Canada, destroying 61 homes on the Minnesota side, and slightly more smaller structures.  Property damage was estimated at 4 million dollars.  The fire was 100% contained on the U.S. side on May 19th, and had consumed more than 36,000 acres in Minnesota (75,000 acres total, including Canada).  This would make the Ham Lake Fire even larger than last July's Cavity Lake Fire, which up until now was the largest fire in the area in 100 years.

Thunderstorms sparked a wildfire early on the 24th 5 to 10 miles southeast of Malta.  Gusty winds behind a cold front allowed this fire to grow to approximately 5660 acres before being exhausted on the 26th.

A human-caused wildfire developed eight miles north of Dodson on August 25 and grew to approximately 5,500 acres.  The fire was started by an RV that had sparks of fire coming from the exhaust.  There were smaller fires along the highway from Bowdoin Wildlife Refuge into Malta, and then from Malta to Dodson.  The fire consumed mostly tall grass on private, state, and BLM lands.  Several ground-based fire crews along with aerial resources established control over the fire by the afternoon of the 26th.

Lightning sparked the Columbine Wildfire over the eastern portion of Yellowstone National Park beginning at 6:00 p.m. on Thursday, August 9.  Smokejumpers and aerial bombardment could not keep the fire contained the next day and the fire grew to over 1,000 acres.  Gusty southwest wind and dry conditions allowed the fire to grow significantly on Sunday, August 12.  The fire made additional advances east over the next three days, twice closing the East Entrance to Yellowstone National Park because of dense smoke.  Over one and one-half inches of rain fell on the fire from August 17 through August 19 considerably slowing progress of the fire.  Several resort areas just to the east of the national park boundary along U.S. Highway 14-16-20 had been threatened by the blaze.  Approximately 18,255 acres were torched.  Total acreage burned within Yellowstone National Park totaled 16,523 with the remainder being in the Shoshone National Forest.

A powerline running through a utility corridor initiated the LeHardy Wildfire three miles north of Fishing Bridge in Yellowstone National Park. The fire began at 1430MDT on Wednesday, July 30 and gusty southwest wind pushed the fire east across the road and the Yellowstone River quickly torching over 500 acres. The fire began very near the Grand Loop Road prompting closure of the road through July between Fishing Bridge and Canyon. Other than the road closure, visitor services were not impacted as the fire headed northeast into a mature lodgepole and spruce forest in an undeveloped area. Active fire behavior continued into August (see August 2008 Storm Data for more information).

Traffic on the Grand Loop Road between Fishing Bridge and Mud Volcano south of Canyon reopened to traffic at noon Friday, August 1 as the threat from the LeHardy Wildfire waned. A fire line was secured near the road, but the wildfire continued to burn actively to the northeast. Gusty wind and low humidity enabled the fire to increase by over 2,500 acres in size on Saturday, August 2. Torching and spotting were observed with a spotting distance of one-half mile. The rapid growth led to increased efforts to improve fire line on the south flank of the fire near Fishing Bridge. Fire activity decreased over the next week and crews were demobilized on Monday, August 11. Total acreage burned was about 9,300. Cost to fight the fire was estimated at around $1.35 million. More information about the origin of this wildfire is contained in the July 2008 Storm Data publication.

Lightning ignited the Arnica wildfire on Sunday, September 13 in old growth, Lodgepole timber west of Bridge Bay in Yellowstone National Park. The fire was not detected until September 23 when it was discovered to be four acres in size. Warm, dry, and windy conditions allowed the fire to grow to about 1,600 acres over the following two days. A ridge of high pressure and unseasonably warm temperatures on September 26 allowed the fire to expand to an estimated 8,300 acres in size. Additional growth on September 27 of 1,000 acres enabled the fire to burn within 3.5 miles of Lake Village. Burnt trees were brought to the ground on the Grand Loop Road between Fishing Bridge and West Thumb during the afternoon as fire swept across the road.  At its peak, the fire burned actively along a 1.5 mile stretch of the road.||Over 200 people and five helicopters actively fought the fire and protected nearby structures. Brush was cleared from around structures and hose lays and sprinkler systems were set-up at Bridge Bay and Lake Village. A change in the weather pattern brought rain, snow, and colder temperatures to the fire on September 30. Personnel were quickly demobilized and sprinklers were removed from structures. All told, the fire charred approximately 10,700 acres of land.

The Beach wildfire began on Sunday morning, July 18, and spread from one-half acre to 150 acres by the end of the day. The fire continued to spread rapidly due to gusty  west wind of 12 to 25 mph on Monday, July 19. By nightfall Monday, the fire had scorched an estimated 385 acres. Nearly 200 firefighters engaged the flames, which burned in sub alpine fir about seven miles west-southwest of Bridge Bay Campground located near the shore of Yellowstone Lake. No structures or roads were impacted by the fire. The fire was contained on Wednesday, July 28, after consuming approximately 520 acres.

The Antelope Wildfire was first spotted on Tuesday afternoon, September 14, following a lightning strike which ignited an area of grass and sage on the northeast slope of Mount Washburn in Yellowstone National Park. Unseasonably warm temperatures coupled with dry and windy conditions doubled the size of the fire on Sunday, September 19. The northwest corner of the fire initially threatened the Tower Fall area but no closures were needed. Over the course of the next week, however, the Grand Loop Road was closed in the vicinity of Tower Fall due to the wildfire. Fire growth was consistent over the next week. A ridge of high pressure over the Great Basin allowed for near-record and record warmth from September 25-28. On Tuesday afternoon, September 28, the fire surged across the Yellowstone River and up a west-facing mountain slope and boosted the fire's size by 1,300 acres. The wildfire was responsible for scorching nearly 4,100 acres by the end of September. More information on the conclusion of this wildfire is contained in the October 2010 Storm Data publication.

The Antelope Wildfire continued to burn in early October as unseasonably warm and dry conditions persisted. The fire spread to about 5,510 acres by Wednesday, October 6, after growing by over 1,000 acres during the previous three days. Very slow growth continued before snow came to Yellowstone National Park on October 24 and 25, effectively ending the fire. This was the largest fire within the park's boundaries in 2010. More information about the origin of this wildfire is contained in the September 2010 Storm Data publication.

Lightning caused the Alum Fire in a remote area south of Hayden Valley in Yellowstone National Park. The fire was first seen on Wednesday morning, August 14, and showed little growth over the following two days. However, a hot, dry airmass coupled with wind speeds of 10 to 20 mph whipped the flames on Saturday afternoon, August 17. The fire erupted from a Saturday morning size of 3 acres to an estimated 3,000 acres by the end of the day. The fire crowned in mature lodgepole pine and advanced six miles to the east-northeast in just a few hours. The hot and dry conditions continued into Sunday and the fire expanded by another 1,000 acres.||By Tuesday, August 20, the fire was close enough to threaten several tourist attractions, including Mud Volcano and LeHardy Rapids, and the Grand Loop Road. The proximity of the fire caused the closure late Tuesday afternoon of a seven and a half mile section of the road from near Mud Volcano to Hayden Valley. At one point the fire came within 200 yards of the road. The fire was estimated to be about 7,000 acres in size on August 21, when the road was re-opened to traffic. The fire topped-out around 7,100 acres in size by August 24, before beneficial thunderstorm rains dampened fire activity over the last week of August.

Started by lightning on Thursday, August 4, the Fawn Fire burned steadily through the month of August. The fire ignited about 11 miles west of Mammoth Hot Springs in a remote area of northwest Yellowstone National Park. About 2,000 acres were consumed by the end of August, with a few days seeing growth of around 400 acres. Please see the September 2016 Storm Data publication for more information about the conclusion of this wildfire.

The Maple Fire was started by lightning near the west entrance to Yellowstone National Park and was first spotted by a smoke jumper aircraft on Monday evening, August 8. The first substantial growth of the fire occurred Monday, August 15, when the blaze jumped from about 1,100 acres to approximately 5,000 acres in a single day. By Saturday, August 20, the fire was nearly 15,000 acres in size. Over the next two days the fire would explode to over 27,000 acres as gusty wind and very low humidity provided ideal conditions for rapid fire growth. The fire grew by approximately 5,000 acres on August 28 and 29, and reached nearly 38,000 acres in size by the end of August. The fire closed numerous trails and burned close to US 191 between West Yellowstone, Montana, and Madison Canyon inside the park boundary. Please see the September 2016 Storm Data publication for more information about the conclusion of this wildfire.

The Buffalo Fire was started by lightning on Saturday, August 13, about three miles northeast of Tower Junction in the northeast portion of Yellowstone National Park. The fire grew by about 1,200 acres on Tuesday, August 16, and was nearly 2,800 acres in size by Thursday, August 25. Active fire conditions on August 28 and 29 allowed the fire to reach approximately 4.500 acres in size by the end of the month. Some area closures were in effect due to the fire. Please see the September 2016 Storm Data publication for more information about the conclusion of this wildfire.

The Central Fire was started by lightning on Friday, August 26, and primarily burned in a remote area west of Lake in central Yellowstone National Park. Favorable conditions for fire growth on August 28 and 29 enabled the less than one acre fire to expand by 800 acres on Sunday, August 28, and an additional 200 acres the following day. The fire had grown to over 1,000 acres by the end of the month. Please see the September 2016 Storm Data publication for more information about the conclusion of this wildfire.

The Fawn Fire grew from about 2,000 acres to nearly 2,700 acres during the first several days of September. Little growth was exhibited after this time and the fire tallied a final total of 2,706 acres burned. Please see the August 2016 Storm Data publication for more information about the start of this wildfire.

The Central Fire began September having burned approximately 1,000 acres in late August. The fire steadily grew and doubled in size to 2,129 acres by the time it was fully contained. No structures or inhabited areas were threatened by this fire which burned in a remote area west of Lake. Please see the August 2016 Storm Data publication for more information about the start of this wildfire.

Fire growth associated with the Maple Fire was steady over the first 10 days of September. On Sunday, September 11, the fire consumed another 3,000 acres as warm, windy, and dry conditions swept across Yellowstone National Park ahead of an approaching cold front. Rain, snow, and cooler temperatures arrived in the wake of the cold front and effectively put an end to the fire. No structures were damaged or destroyed despite the fact that the Maple Fire torched 45,425 acres. This was the largest fire in Yellowstone in 2016, a year in which the acreage burned in the park was the highest since the historic summer of 1988.

The Buffalo Fire grew rapidly from around 4,500 acres on Thursday, September 1, to nearly 10,000 acres by Sunday, September 4. Slow and steady growth continued over the next week before the wind-whipped fire expanded by over 1,000 acres on Sunday, September 11. Cooler and wetter weather swept across the fire September 12 and 13. By Saturday, September 17, the fire was largely contained and no appreciable growth was seen. The fire consumed 12,693 acres. Please see the August 2016 Storm Data publication for more information about the start of this wildfire.
The Easy Street Fire, centered four miles northwest of Wenatchee, was a human caused fire that burned 5,209 acres.  One outbuilding was lost in the fire.

The Union Valley Fire, located three miles north of Chelan, was a lightning caused fire that burned 768 acres. The fire began on July 28th. Between 120 and 140 residences received level two and three evacuation notices.

The Union Valley Fire, located three miles north of Chelan, was a lightning caused fire that burned 768 acres.  The fire burned into the first day of August.  Between 120 and 140 residences received level two and three evacuation notices.
The Spanish Castle Fire, centered three miles west of Trinidad, WA, was a human caused fire that burned 2,470 acres.
The Baird Springs Fire, centered five miles northwest of Quincy, was a fire of unknown cause that burned 7,693 acres.

The Wenatchee River Complex Fire, located near Cashmere, consisted of four fires which burned 2,065 acres.  The fires were caused by several lightning strikes which occurred in the area on July 28th.  The largest fire was the Nahahum Fire at 1,947 acres which burned five miles north of Cashmere.  Numerous structures were threatened by the fire.  The other fires were all less than 100 acres in size.

The Swakane Fire, centered nine miles north of Wenatchee, was a fire of unknown cause that burned 19,291 acres.  The fire briefly closed a section of Highway 97A.  One barn was destroyed by the fire, with numerous other structures threatened.

The wildfire was human caused and started near the intersection of Colockum Road and Tarpiscan Road. The fire spread south into neighboring Kittitas County and remained west of the Columbia River. The fire continued to burn into the month of August. Numerous homes, three major power lines, a natural gas line, two wind farms, timber, water quality, wildlife habitat and range resources were all threatened at one point or another. Three primary residences and several outbuildings were burned. Two fire fighters suffered minor injuries.

The Milepost 10 wildfire was lightning caused and originated one half mile south of Malaga.  The fire burned through 5445 acres of dry grass and steep rocky slopes, cliffs, and benches west of the Columbia River near Rock Island Dam.  Heavy rain from thunderstorms on August 11th assisted firefighters but also led to flash flooding, mudslides, and road washouts disrupting access points.  Level one evacuations were ordered during the fire but no structures were lost.

The month of July was warmer and drier than normal.  Fuels across the area became receptive to fire very quickly during this time.  Breezy winds on the 27th and 28th also were a contributing factor for rapid fire spread.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wildfire was human caused and started near the intersection of Colockum Road and Tarpiscan Road.  The fire spread south into neighboring Kittitas County and remained west of the Columbia River.  The fire continued to burn into the month of August.  Numerous homes, three major power lines, a natural gas line, two wind farms, timber, water quality, wildlife habitat and range resources were all threatened at one point or another.  Three primary residences and several outbuildings were burned.  Two fire fighters suffered minor injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several weeks of warm and dry weather coupled with ongoing drought conditions from the previous winter resulted in very dry fuels around the Wenatchee Area.  Gusty winds on the evening of the 8th helped fan a grass fire some time after 2300 PDT near Chelan, WA.  The fire was small and contained after a few hours but managed to burn a motor home and farm tractor.  The cause of the fire is unknown.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A grass fire sometime after 2300 PDT Sunday evening burned a motor home and farm tractor on Wilmorth Road off Highway 97 east of Chelan, WA.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Sleepy Hollow Fire ignited at 230 PM near Wenatchee, WA Sunday Evening June 28, 2015. This urban interface fire expanded to 3000 acres and destroyed 28 structures (homes and business buildings).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sleepy Hollow Fire ignited near Wenatchee, WA Sunday Evening June 28, 2015. This urban interface fire expanded to 3000 acres and destroyed 28 structures (homes and business buildings).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Sleepy Hollow Fire burned 2,950 acres and destroyed 29 residences, 1 outbuilding and 3 commercial businesses. Four minor injuries were reported on the fire. The fire started on June 28,2015 at approximately 2:30 PM in the northwest portion of the city of Wenatchee, northwest to Monitor, WA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sleepy Hollow Fire burned 2,950 acres and destroyed 29 residences, 1 outbuilding and 3 commercial businesses. Four minor injuries were reported on the fire. The fire started on June 28,2015 at approximately 2:30 PM in the northwest portion of the city of Wenatchee, northwest to Monitor, WA.
