The Hidalgo County Sheriff's Office, Fire|Marshal's Office, Emergency Management Coordinator, Public Works and the Regional Liaison Officer for Region 3A (Lower Rio Grande Valley) responded to the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of rapidly drying fuels (grasses and brush) with very low afternoon humidity (below 15 percent) and frequent wind gusts between 20 and 25 mph allowed a grass fire to grow rapidly and burn nearly 700 acres of land near Sullivan City. Sparks from someone burning trash ignited the fire and strong winds fueled the fire. No injuries were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media reported a large grass fire near Sullivan City. Nearly 700 acres were burned, with no injuries or damaged structures reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of abnormal dryness, dry fine and medium fuels, a near flash drought day that preceded it, and near critical humidity with gusty east winds aided the development of wildfire on the Santa Ana NWR along the Rio Grande in southern Hidalgo County.  The fire was ignited by torching - embers that floated across the Rio Grande from a nearby sugar burn in northern Tamaulipas, Mexico.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local emergency management, fire departments, and the US Fish and Wildlife Service reported a 300 acre wildfire developed rapidly during the afternoon of March 7th, when embers from a sugar cane burn in northern Tamaulipas, Mexico, just south of the Rio Grande drifted into the refuge and began the process of torching brush and grass. The wildfire, aided by dry fuels, gusty east winds, and near critical relative humidity levels, continued for nearly 48 hours before being 100 percent contained.  The refuge was closed to public operations through the following weekend for safety precautions and continued clean-up activities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Gusty winds and dry conditions on April 18th contributed to a debris fire in Tuolumne County getting out of control and destroying a home. Another debris fire in El Dorado County also destroyed a home.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A debris fire in Cold Springs in Tuolumne County got out of control in windy conditions, spreading to 20 acres and destroying one home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with little or no rain spread across the area on June 21st. About 8000 lighting strikes were detected, sparking approximately 2000 wildfires across northern California. These fires destroyed numerous structures and caused multiple deaths and injuries. Evacuations were ordered for affected communities. Smoke from the wildfires caused respiratory concerns across the region. Due to the shear number of fires initiated and early season lower resource levels, many fires were not initially staffed. Many of these fires continued to burn through July and into August.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The American River Fire Complex consisted of ten fires which were located about 11 miles to the northeast of Foresthill. There was a total of 20,541 acres destroyed from late June through July. There were two residences destroyed. One firefighter injury was reported. A helicopter was damaged while delivering protective building wrap, but there were no injuries. The fire was reported 100 percent contained on July 30th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with little or no rainfall spread across interior Northern California on June 21st. Approximately 8000 lightning strikes were detected, sparking as many as 2000 wildfires across Northern California. These fires destroyed numerous structures and caused multiple deaths and injuries. Evacuations were ordered for affected communities. Smoke from the wildfires caused respiratory problems across the region. Due to a lack of resources, many fires were not initially attacked with fire crews and some fires were expected to continue to burn for the remainder of the fire season.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning strikes resulted in the development of the American River Fire Complex (located 11 miles northeast of Foresthill) and the Yuba River Complex (located 15 miles northeast of Grass Valley). Combined, the fires burned 7,142 acres, injured 12 firefighters, destroyed 1 residence, and threatened 116 additional structures. The fires had only 35 percent containment by the end of the month and are continued in the July Storm Data entry.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Knight Fire burned an area of forest along the Middle Fork of the American River.  The fire started on July 26th and was 100 percent contained by August 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were 6130 acres of forest burned in rugged terrain along the Middle Fork of the American River.  Local forest service roads were closed due to the fire, as were several campgrounds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought about 1500 recorded lightning strikes to northern California.  One lightning strike injured a woman at a sporting event in Stockton and a number of small wildfires were started across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning started a number of fires over the northern Sierra Nevada Mountains including the Telegraph Fire near Copperopolis (200 acres) and the San Antonio Fire near Arnold (5 acres), both located in Calaveras County.  The other fires were small and quickly extinguished.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Rim Fire was a wildfire that began in the Groveland Range District of the Stanislaus National Forest on August 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rim Fire was a wildfire that started on August 17th at around 3:15pm PDT in Tuolumne County. It was located in the Groveland Range District of Stanislaus National Forest. The fire grew to be the 3rd largest wildfire in California's history, at 257,314 acres. For the TOTAL FIRE EVENT: It cost approximately $127.2 million, caused 10 injuries, burned 11 residences, 3 commercial properties, and 98 outbuildings. For the month of SEPTEMBER ONLY: 34,358 more acres, additional $65.8 million, 5 additional injuries, 0 new residences, 0 new commercial properties, and 1 new outbuildings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Rim Fire was a wildfire that began in the Groveland Range District of the Stanislaus National Forest on August 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rim Fire was a wildfire that started on August 17th at around 3:15pm PDT in Tuolumne County. It was located in the Groveland Range District of Stanislaus National Forest. The fire grew to be the 3rd largest wildfire in California's history, at 257,314 acres. For the TOTAL FIRE EVENT: It cost approximately $127.2 million, caused 10 injuries, burned 11 residences, 3 commercial properties, and 98 outbuildings. For the month of AUGUST ONLY: 222,777 acres, $60 million, 5 injuries, 11 residences, 3 commercial properties, and 97 outbuildings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Rim Fire was a wildfire that began in the Groveland Range District of the Stanislaus National Forest on August 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rim Fire was a wildfire that started on August 17th at around 3:15pm PDT in Tuolumne County. It was located in the Groveland Range District of Stanislaus National Forest. The fire grew to be the 3rd largest wildfire in California's history, at 257,314 acres. For the TOTAL FIRE EVENT: It cost approximately $127.2 million, caused 10 injuries, burned 11 residences, 3 commercial properties, and 98 outbuildings. For the month of OCTOBER ONLY: approximately 179 more acres, additional $1.4 million, 0 additional injuries, 0 new residences, 0 new commercial properties, and 0 new outbuildings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire broke out near Pollock Pines around 6:37 pm on September 13th. Hot and dry conditions with southwest winds 10-20 mph caused rapid growth of the fire. The fire doubled in size to 114 square miles in a strong surge on September 17th. The fire was fully contained on October 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The King Fire destroyed 12 residences and 68 other buildings. There were 10 firefighters injured, and 97,099 acres burned by the end of the month. Hundreds of residents were evacuated. The fire was caused by arson and was estimated to have cost more than 90 million dollars for fire suppression efforts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Breezy southwest winds combined with dry fuels to intensify the development of wildfires, including the Kyburz and Wragg Fires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The fire covered 75 acres. A vehicle fire started the fire east of Whitehall, which spread to both sides of US Highway 50. The vehicle that started the fire was destroyed, and there was one minor injury to a firefighter. Highway 50 was shut down through the rest of the afternoon into the next day. There were 15 people in the area evacuated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continued drought, with periods of heat, breezy winds and low humidity increased wildfire danger through early August.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lowell Fire started on July 25th, with most fire growth and damage occurring in July. The cause is still under investigation. There were a total of 2304 acres burned, with a total of 6 firefighters injured (occurred and documented in July). Two firefighters from the US Forest Service and 2 from CAL Fire suffered burns while fighting the fire. One of the firefighters had serious burns and required further hospitalization. There were 2 structures destroyed, 1 damaged. Wildfire suppression costs were estimated to be $18 million.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme fire behavior with winds and very dry fuels combining to enhance rapidly moving fires which destroyed hundreds of homes and caused multiple deaths in the Valley and Butte Fires. The Valley Fire is considered the 3rd most destructive wildfire in California history, the Butte Fire the 7th most destructive.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were 70,868 acres were burned in the Butte Fire, the 7th most destructive fire in California history. There were 475 residences and 343 outbuildings destroyed, and 45 structures damaged. In the fire there were 2 civilian fatalities and 1 injury. The cause has tentatively been attributed to a PG&E power line coming in contact with a live tree.  Extensive damage was done to power lines and poles. PG&E has identified 505 locations where equipment needs to be fixed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire started in the Sierra Nevada Mountains at Steep Hollow Creek in the You Bet area, west of Alta, CA on July 25th at approximately 2:37 pm. The fire was not fully contained until August 10th. The cause is still under investigation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were 2304 acres burned, with a total of 6 firefighters injured. Two firefighters from the US Forest Service and 2 from CAL Fire suffered burns while fighting the fire. One of the firefighters had serious burns and required further hospitalization. There were 2 structures destroyed, 1 damaged. Wildfire suppression costs were estimated to be $18 million.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Large wildfires developed across Northern California early August during a period of high temperatures, and low humidity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Donnell Fire began on August 1, 2018, along Highway 108 in Stanislaus National Forest in Tuolumne County. The cause of the fire is unknown. The fire burned 36,450 acres, 54 structures destroyed and 81 minor structures destroyed. of them homes. Among the destroyed buildings was the historic Dardanelle Resort and Dardanelle Bridge. The fire was not fully contained until early October. There were a total of 9 injuries from the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme fire weather conditions were forecast for Oct 9 and 10 as northern California was caught between a ridge over the eastern Pacific and a trough over the Great Basin. This caused the pressure gradients to tighten over the county warning area, which lead to strong northerly and easterly winds. With these winds forecast, dry conditions in place, and fuels being primed a Red Flag Warning was issued for most of interior northern California. Fortunately no major wildfires resulted from this but a controlled burn got out of control and utility power lines did suffer from some wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On October 10 a prescribed burn, which was started on September 30, was declared a wild fire incident. Extreme fire weather conditions were forecast which led to the growth of the prescribed burn. In total 3435 acres were burned across the month of October. The Forest Service noted that 7 injuries or illnesses happened on this fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Gusty winds and dry conditions on April 18th contributed to a debris fire in Tuolumne County getting out of control and destroying a home. Another debris fire in El Dorado County also destroyed a home.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A debris fire in the town of Rescue in El Dorado County spread out of control over 15 acres. Fifty homes were threatened, with one home destroyed and one resident of that home suffering burn injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire occurred in the town of Rescue on May 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire near the town of Rescue caused the evacuation of 50 homes. No damage or injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Knight Fire started on July 26th, burning a forested area by the Middle Fork of the Stanislaus River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire started on July 26th along the Middle Fork of the Stanislaus River, near Mt. Knight, in Stanislaus County.  The fire had burned 2734 acres by the end of July and continued to burn into August.  It brought multiple local road closures and smoke to the nearby area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Building high pressure resulted in hot, above normal temperatures and generally light, dry northerly winds. Weather conditions combined with very dry fuels allowed Sand Fire incident to grow into 4,240 acres in Amador and El Dorado Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sand Fire began east of Highway 49, 5 miles north of Plymouth (south of Placerville) on the afternoon of July 25th. The fire was caused by a vehicle driving into dry vegetation, and was considered a CalFire incident. The fire burned in both Amador and El Dorado Counties, reaching 4,240 acres by the time it was 100% contained on August 2nd. It burned 20 residences, and 47 outbuildings, and there were 2 injuries reported with the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A period of heat and low humidity increased wildfire danger at the end of June.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Trailhead Fire started on June 28th and continued into early July. The cause is still under investigation. There were a total of 5646 acres burned, with a total of 3 firefighters injured. The were 2600 structures threatened, with extensive evacuations in the area around Todd Valley and Forest Hill.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A period of heat and low humidity increased wildfire danger at the beginning of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Trailhead Fire started on June 28th and continued until containment on July 18th. The cause is still under investigation. There were a total of 5646 acres burned, with a total of 3 firefighters injured. The were 2600 structures threatened, with extensive evacuations in the area around Todd Valley and Forest Hill.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and dry temperatures brought enhanced fire danger.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A rancher was badly burned in the Maria Fire on Monday, July 17th. The fire was in Calaveras County, near Mokelumne Hill. There were 117 acres burned, with numerous structures threatened, but none reported burned. The rancher had third degree burns over 90% of his body, and passed away on July 29th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several wildfires were reported in the Minot area on Saturday, April 19th, with flare-ups continuing into Sunday, April 20th when the wildfire was reported contained. 500 to 800 acres were burned. The fires started late Saturday morning with the cause unknown. Gusty south winds of 20 to 35 miles per hour, afternoon relative humidity values around 15 percent, and dormant grass and drought conditions contributed greatly to the wildfire behavior. North Dakota National Guard Blackhawk helicopters assisted the firefighting efforts by dropping water on the fires. Several structures were destroyed, and there were two minor direct injuries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wildfires were reported west and southeast of Minot, in the Trestle Valley and Eastside Estates areas respectively. Two homes, two outbuildings, and some equipment were burned or destroyed. Two firefighters suffered minor direct injuries due to heat exhaustion.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very windy conditions combined with an extremely dry airmass to promote weather favorable for wildfire development over much of the west Texas South Plains during the late afternoon hours on the 16th. ||Southwesterly winds were sustained at speeds between 25 and 35 mph over the region. An anomalous severe wind gust, however, was recorded by the Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet station in Hockley County. Witnesses attributed the gust to a well-developed dust devil that was sighted south of Levelland. ||At least three grassland fires were sparked in an airmass characterized by relative humidities around five percent in Dickens and Garza County. With the exceptionally dry air and strong winds, these fires quickly grew to consume an estimated 4,000 acres. No structures were damaged in the fires. ||The Garza County wildfire was ignited by a welder on a ranch south of Post during the afternoon hours of the 16th. By mid evening the fire had consumed more than 1,500 acres. The fire crossed Farm to Market Road 669, which was closed by local officials between Gail and Post for more than two hours. Oil lines were destroyed east of Farm to Market Road 669. Eight volunteer fire departments from surrounding communities along with air assets from the Texas Forest Service assisted in firefighting efforts. No injuries were reported. ||In addition, two large wildfires burned nearly 2,500 acres in Dickens County. These fires required firefighting operations from multiple agencies. A fire near McAdoo burned an estimated 1,800 acres. No significant damage or injuries were reported. ||All wildfires on the South Plains were contained around sunrise on the 17th, when increasing moisture levels overspread the area in the wake of a passing cold front.

The passage of an intense upper air storm system over the Southern Plains of the U.S. on the 27th caused high winds, blowing dust, and an outbreak of destructive grassland wildfires that affected portions of three states.||Locally on the South Plains of west Texas, intense southwest to westerly winds intensified rapidly in the hours around midday.  These winds resulted in widespread blowing dust across region.  Visibility at Lubbock's Preston Smith International Airport dropped to less than one-quarter mile in the dust storm.  Similar dust storm conditions undoubtedly occurred at many South Plains locales, but went unreported.  Damage brought on by the winds and resultant wildland fires were of much greater concern.||Shortly after 12:00 CST, winds caused power lines to arc in the 5600 block of 45th Street in Lubbock (Lubbock County). An urban-wildland fire quickly sparked and ran through yards and severely damaged six residences.  Three homes, two sheds, two boats, and a vehicle were destroyed.  A dog was killed, but no human casualties were reported.  Lubbock fire fighters additionally fought a fire near the 400 block of East 50th Street around 15:00 CST.  That fire, also started by wind-blown power lines, severely damaged 23 vehicles in an automotive repair lot.  ||Winds downed three power poles and lines into native grasslands southwest of Levelland (Hockley County) around 13:45 CST.  The resultant wildfire charred 5,000 acres and destroyed two homes and damaged a third.  Four vehicles and a fire engine were lost in the blaze.  ||Between 14:15 CST and 15:15 CST, at least two fires ignited in southern and western Motley County.  The Matador Complex fires grew to consume more than 41,000 acres.  U.S. Highway 62/70 was closed as the west-Matador fire, which started at a road-side park twelve miles west of Matador, rapidly spread eastward toward the town.  An army of first responders invaded Matador to evacuate its residents toward a defensible area at the Motley County High School gymnasium.  One fire fighter was treated for minor burns.  At least two homes were severely damaged or destroyed on the southern extent of the city, and many outbuildings were burned.  The community of Roaring Springs was additionally threatened without incident.||Around 15:45 CST, a wind-driven fire ignited at an airport just east of Post (Garza County).  The fire quickly developed into a massive wildland fire that consumed 9,500 acres before it was contained around 23:00 CST.  The fire destroyed a 20 foot by 30 foot telecommunications building which was valued at approximately $2 million.  A fire engine was partially burned.||Wind-driven wildfires also ignited near Spur and Afton (Dickens County) and near Aspermont (Stonewall County).  These fires collectively accounted for between 5,000 acres and 10,000 acres burned and took a number of outbuildings.  Additional and less significant fire starts were observed on the north rim of Tule Canyon near Lake MacKenzie in Briscoe County, in Bailey County, Childress County, and Hale County.  In all, at least 11 wind-driven grassland wildfires impacted the extreme Southern Panhandle and the South Plains.||The high winds experienced in the Lubbock (Lubbock County) area during the afternoon hours caused extensive roof damage to an apartment complex near 1930 Baylor Street.  One person was injured when a 30 foot by 30 foot section of the roof was blown off of the structure.  Debris, which had previously covered three apartment units, struck several cars when it landed in an adjacent parking lot.  A vehicle was additionally struck by airborne roofing material that peeled off of another Lubbock business elsewhere in the city.||A list of severe wind gusts measured by the Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet, KVII-TV Schoolnet, and Automated Surface Observing Systems follows:  |68 mph at Amherst (Lamb County),  65 mph at Lazbuddie (Parmer County), 63 mph at Hart (Castro County), 63 mph at Tulia (Swisher County), 61 mph at MacKenzie Reservoir (Briscoe County), 60 mph at Silverton (Briscoe County), 59 mph at Friona (Parmer County), 59 mph at Lubbock's Preston Smith International Airport (Lubbock County), 59 mph at Morton (Cochran County), 59 mph at Plainview (Hale County), 59 mph at Turkey (Hall County), 58 mph at Denver City (Yoakum County), and 58 mph at Graham (Garza County).  ||The winds and wildfires that impacted the South Plains region of west Texas on the 27th clearly had a significant public impact.  Although two persons were injured, no fatalities were reported.  Total economic losses were estimated near $3.5 million.

During the evening hours on May 6, several wildfires were started by lightning strikes in Dickens County. Many of these wildfires spread and combined into a single large fire known as the Dickens Complex Fire. The wildfire was contained on May 11 after spreading into King County and burning only two sheds. The total amount of land area burned was estimated to be 90,000 acres. No injuries were reported.

Very windy, dry, and unseasonably warm conditions helped fuel the spread of a wildfire this afternoon about five miles north-northwest of Dickens (Dickens County). Volunteer fire crews from Dickens, McAdoo, and Spur helped combat the fire through the early overnight hours of the 30th and prevented it from jumping US Highway 70. This fire consumed around 150 acres of open ranch land including one power pole and a section of utility line. The subsequent power outage affected all residents of Spur, McAdoo, and Dickens for about two hours.

Periods of high westerly winds developed this morning and afternoon well south of a vigorous low pressure system in eastern Colorado.  Fortunately, blowing dust was not a significant problem over the region as the strongest winds avoided the major dust source regions. By late afternoon, a narrow band of thunderstorms drifted south from the southwest TX Panhandle and resulted in a convective wind gust to 61 mph near Floydada. These storms also produced welcome soaking rains from Friona and Dimmitt southeast to Plainview. ||Late this afternoon, strong westerly winds promoted the spread of a wildfire in northern Dickens County. Preliminary evidence from the Texas Forest Service indicates two wildfires developed west of Afton before combining into a single fire that consumed at least 3100 acres. In addition to closing some rural roads, this fire prompted a voluntary evacuation of residents from Afton. Fortunately, no structures were damaged from this wildfire.

Very strong winds combined with low humidities fueled multiple wildfires across northeast Montana this afternoon.  Two of these fires grew out of control for several hours and destroyed a combined 5000 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire started 14 miles north-northwest of Vida and grew to 3500 acres before being extinguished approximately 15 miles northeast of Vida.  Two separate property owners suffered minor burns while attempting to control the fire and a total of ten outbuildings were lost.  Fencing and power poles were also damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A human caused grass fire spread quickly in the area southwest of the town of Hagerman.  The fire consumed 1000 acres before it was contained.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A human caused grass fire just southwest of Hagerman was spread by strong southwest winds and consumed 1000 acres. The wildfire destroyed a vacant mobile home, a camper trailer and 2 sheds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with little or no rain spread across the area late in the evening on June 20th. Approximately 1000 lightning strikes were detected that started numerous wildfires across northwestern California.

A fire, started earlier in the week by a lightning strike, smoldered until weather conditions were conducive to set it loose. The fire quickly spread to nearly 8,000 acres. Although the fire was not a threat to homes or property, it did do substantial timber damage within the Gifford Pinchot National Forest.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The fire covered nearly 8,000 acres, located about 11 miles north of Trout Lake, and spanned between both Skamania and Yakima counties in the Gifford Pinchot National Forest.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with little or no rain spread across the area on June 21st. About 8000 lighting strikes were detected, sparking approximately 2000 wildfires across northern California. These fires destroyed numerous structures and caused multiple deaths and injuries. Evacuations were ordered for affected communities. Smoke from the wildfires caused respiratory concerns across the region. Due to the shear number of fires initiated and early season lower resource levels, many fires were not initially staffed. Many of these fires continued to burn through July and into August.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The SHU Fire Complex in southwestern Shasta and western Tehama counties burned approximately 87,000 acres before 100 percent containment was achieved on July 28th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms with little or no rainfall spread across interior Northern California on June 21st. Approximately 8000 lightning strikes were detected, sparking as many as 2000 wildfires across Northern California. These fires destroyed numerous structures and caused multiple deaths and injuries. Evacuations were ordered for affected communities. Smoke from the wildfires caused respiratory problems across the region. Due to a lack of resources, many fires were not initially attacked with fire crews and some fires were expected to continue to burn for the remainder of the fire season.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning on June 21st started a number of fires in western Tehama and southwestern Shasta counties. These fires were combined as the SHU Complex which included the Whiskeytown Complex. By the end of June, 52,000 acres were burned with 6 firefighter injuries, 3 residences  destroyed, and 2 additional buildings damaged. There were also 230 residences and 37 commercial buildings threatened. The fires in the complex extended into the northern Sacramento Valley (CA-Z015) and into the vicinity of Lake Shasta (CA-Z013). The fires had only 15 percent containment by the end of June and are continued in the July Storm Data entry.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Hat Creek Complex and SHU Lightning Complex fires were started by lightning strikes from thunderstorms on the evening of August 1st.  Approximately 1800 lightning ground strikes were recorded in Northern California.  The Hat Creek Complex continued until containment on August 12th.  THe SHU Lightning Complex continued until containment on August 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm lightning strikes started numerous fires in Shasta County on the evening of August 1st. The Complex consisted of 40 fires, with the largest being the Gomez, Cave, Cassel, the Goose, and the Chalk fires. Dozens of homes were evacuated, and a number of area roads were closed. There were 17,623 acres of forest burned prior to containment on August 17th.  This fire complex included burned acreage in CA-Z014.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large fire developed during an extended period of hot, dry weather with gusty winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Delta Fire began on September 5, 2018, near Lakehead by Shasta Lake, in Shasta-Trinity National Forest in Shasta County. The fire was determined to be human caused. The fire burned 63,100 acres and caused evacuations through the area, with 20 structures destroyed and no injuries reported. The fire was not fully contained until October 7. The fire came close to the Carr Fire. The Delta Fire burned into the western perimeter of the Hirz Fire on September 10.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Large wildfires developed across Northern California early August during a period of high temperatures, and low humidity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Hirz Fire began on August 9, 2018, near Lakehead by Shasta Lake, in Shasta-Trinity National Forest in Shasta County. The fire was determined to be human caused. The fire burned 46,150 acres and caused evacuations through the area, but no structures were destroyed and no injuries were reported. The fire was not fully contained until September 12. The fire came close to the Carr Fire. The Delta Fire burned into the western perimeter of the Hirz Fire on September 10.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ambient temperatures around 107 degrees and excessive drought conditions were all the ingredients needed for a grass fire to get out of control in Cherokee County on the afternoon of August 17th.  Several fire departments were on the scene of a five acre fire on County Road 1615 off of Hwy 69, south of Jacksonville.  Two barns have been completely destroyed by the blaze, but no homes are involved at this time.|Texas Forest Service choppers sent out helicopters and plows to help contain the fire.|Fortunately no one was seriously injured, however, two firefighters were treated for heat exhaustion.

Strong sustained winds and wind gusts, in association with Tropical Storm Lee which made landfall across the south central and southeast Louisiana gulf coast, were felt across all of Northeast Texas on September 4th. These winds, along with very low humidity values and exceptional drought conditions across Northeast Texas, resulted in critical wildfire threat being met across the region.  A wildfire, which became known as the Henderson 502 fire, began on September 4th, 6 miles northwest of Douglass, Texas.  This fire consumed 6500 acres and was not contained until September 7th.  There were no structures consumed with this wildfire.

Strong winds, low humidity and drought conditions across Northeast Texas were all the ingredients needed for a critical wildfire threat across the region.  A wildfire began on September 10th near Alto, Texas and was not contained until September 17th.  The fire consumed 1900 acres of timberland and grassland but no structures were burned with this fire.
The dry weather continued into the third week of January. Breezy conditions and low humidities contributed to an increasing number of wildfires, but few of these fires consumed more than 100 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire 3 miles southeast of Newport consumed only about 15 acres, but the fire spread into a mobile home park. Two vacant mobile homes were destroyed, as were a bobtail truck, a dump truck, a speedboat, and a large equipment shed containing a considerable amount of equipment.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak back door cold front pushed through the region, resulting in erratic winds causing a prescribed burn to develop into a wildfire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During a prescribed burn the fire spotted over a road, so a head fire was set against that thinking it would contain it.  The fire blew up when the main fire met with the head fire, causing the fire to get hot and spot over another road onto private land.  The total acreage burned by this entire fire was 130.80 acres.  The number of acres burned outside of the prescribed burn area totaled 45.80 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure spreading into Deep South Texas behind a weak front ushered in dry air and moderate winds, especially from Jim Hogg eastward to Kenedy County but eventually dropping south into the Rio Grande Valley during the afternoon of February 11th.  The combination of warm temperatures, very low humidity, and occasionally gusty winds help spread a wild fire over a small portion of the King Ranch.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire, initially observed by 3.9 micrometer resolution infrared satellite images and NWS Doppler Radar (as smoke), spread to an estimated 300 acres along and east of Federal Highway 77 in Kenedy County, roughly 17 miles from the Willacy County line or about 6 miles south of Armstrong.  The fire was likely driven by gusty north winds 15 to 20 mph and afternoon humidity falling to between 10 and 15 percent.  It was not known if the highway was closed at any time during or after the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The general pattern of a West Texas trough of low pressure with departing high pressure into the central Gulf of Mexico, which had become fairly routine in February 2009, resulted in another day with increasing southeast 20 foot winds toward 25 mph, with higher gusts, on the 24th.  A wild fire developed over the King Ranch and spread rapidly during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wild fire grew rapidly during the afternoon across the King Ranch near Norias, approximately 70 miles south of Kingsville.  The fire, known as the Stillman S #14 fire, grew to 1,500 acres and may not have been totally contained until the next day.  There were some unconfirmed reports of Federal Highway 77 being closed near Norias.   The Texas Forest Service responded with an Air Attack (aircraft), two engines, and two dozers. Raymondville and King Ranch Fire Department responded to the blaze.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major spring storm, rotating from the Texas Panhandle through extreme north Texas and into the Mid-Mississippi Valley between March 27th and 28th created extreme weather contrasts across the state, ranging from a blizzard in Dalhart and Amarillo to searing, record heat across the Rio Grande Valley on the 27th.||By the 28th, a front has raced through most of the state, including Deep South Texas.  Behind the front, temperatures remained a few degrees above normal, but humidity crashed below 15 percent and winds continue at a moderate 15 to 25 mph from the north.  ||The combination of increasingly dry ranchland with extremely low humidity and winds gusting occasionally above 25 mph helped spread a wildfire across portions of the King Ranch on March 28th, continuing into the next day.  A second, smaller wildfire would affect nearby areas two days later.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small fire rapidly spread to at least 1500 acres on the Armstrong Ranch. While nearly all of Kenedy County is dominated by King Ranch rangeland, this fire affected Federal Highway 77, the only coastal thoroughfare connecting the Lower Rio Grande Valley with the Coastal Bend.  The highway was reported closed for a time on the 28th due to severe smoke, in an area south of Sarita near Armstrong.  ||Firefighters and other first responders from Raymondville, Kleberg County, Willacy EMS, Kenedy County Sheriff's Office, Texas Department of Transportation, and the Texas Forest Service responded to the blaze, which became known as the San Carlos Fire. At this writing, no structural damage had been reported.||A second, much smaller fire (40 acres) would develop a bit farther south, but also along Federal Highway 77, near Armstrong.  This secondary fire, known as the Cross Timbers Fire, was quickly contained but required help once again from Raymondville, Willacy County, and the Kenedy County Volunteer Fire Department.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vehicle fire soon became a conflagration that spread to more than 500 acres across portions of the King Ranch on February 14th.  The fire was aided by maximum cured fine and medium fuels from the previous 10 days of frequent hard freezes, an ice storm, and low humidity. During the event, nearby humidity readings fell to near 30 percent, with sustained estimated 20 foot winds of 10 to 15 mph with gusts to 20 mph from the southeast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle fire near the Turcotte West Gate on the King Ranch quickly spread out of control, fed by extremely cured fine fuels, fairly low humidity (estimated near 30 percent based on nearby observations at the Brooks County Airport), and estimated 20 foot southeast winds 10 to 15 mph with gusts to 20 mph at times. ||The fire traveled north while increasing to at least 600 acres in coverage.   Fire departments from Willacy and Kleberg County joined the fight, including from Rivera, Ricardo, and Kingsville (Kleberg) and Willacy/Raymondville.  The fire was contained by 6 PM as well positioned fire breaks combined with lowering winds and increasing humidity at sunset.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very dry atmosphere, increasingly dry and somewhat cured fine fuels (grasses) which were in vast quantity due to the high growth through the first nine months of 2010, and moderate winds allowed a spark from a passing train to blossom into a large conflagration on the King Ranch in Kenedy County on January 2nd.  Several smaller fires also started in the Lower Rio Grande Valley, with limited spread due to rapid containment and control.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency Management called in from Willacy County were notified of a rapidly growing wildfire in south central Kenedy County just west of Highway 77 near Rudolph.  Before it was over, more than 7,000 acres of ranchland burned.  Efforts from Willacy County Fire and Emergency Management, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, and others helped contain the fire nearly 12 hours after it began.  ||There was no property damage or known livestock injury or death; only wide swaths of grass, brush, and some mesquite burned.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fire developed at a residence along Scenic Road on the west side of Raton, NM around 500 am on February 26th. Sustained winds near 55 mph with wind gusts as high as 69 mph at the Raton Crews Airport and very dry conditions were sufficient to fan the blaze to a nearby home, a carport, and a tree down the street from the initial fire.  The first home and carport were completely destroyed and the second home was partially damaged.
A wildfire in Washoe Valley south of Reno was believed to have been caused by a lightning strike.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire covering approximately 14 acres threatened homes in the Eastlake Boulevard and Douglas Boulevard area in Washoe Valley.  The Reno Gazette-Journal reported that the fire had burned to within 200 feet of at least one of the homes.  The fire was thought to have been started by a lightning strike.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure moved through the Pacific Northwest bringing high winds to portions of western NV on the 18th. One of the most expensive and damaging fires in Reno history to date developed in southwest Reno as power lines arced in high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds caused a tree to fall on a power line sparking a rapidly spreading wildfire in southwest Reno around 0030PST. The 2,000 acre Caughlin Fire fire spread, sometimes up to 30 mph, and caused the destruction of around 30 homes during the early morning of the 18th. Over 9,000 people were evacuated from the fire area early Friday before being allowed to return Saturday. One man died while evacuating his home, a firefighter suffered second-degree burns, and 16 others were admitted to area hospitals for smoke inhalation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An open residential burn the previous weekend re-ignited as winds gusted to 40-45 mph on the afternoon of the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An open residential burn in the Topaz Ranch Estates (a couple miles north of Topaz Lake) the previous weekend re-ignited as winds gusted to 40-45 mph on the afternoon of the 22nd. The fire claimed several cars, as well as 19 structures including 2 homes. The total acreage of the fire was 7152. Fire fighting costs (not fire damage) reached more than 3 million dollars.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved from off the Oregon and Washington coast early on the 19th to the northern Rockies early on the 20th. This brought strong winds to the Reno area on the 19th, which helped fan a large wildfire just south of Reno.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds (up to 84 mph) and the improper disposal of fireplace ashes caused the rapid spread of a fire originating at the north end of Washoe Valley early in the afternoon on the 19th. Thousands of people were forced to evacuate from the swift-moving fire. Around 3100 acres were burned with 28 homes destroyed (7 damaged) and one fatality attributed to the fire. ||For information purposes only (not direct costs from wildfire), the tally of fire-fighting related costs were at least 1.5 million dollars.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two low pressure systems brought a combination of strong winds, significant rain, and high elevation snow on the 14th and 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A prescribed burn that was thought to be mopped up on October 13th flared up as high winds affected the Carson Range early on the 14th. The Little Valley Fire burned through 2,291 acres and destroyed 23 homes and 17 outbuildings. According to a Reno Gazette Journal investigation, the estimated value of 18 of the homes exceeded 26 million dollars with an independent fire consultant indicating that damages could exceed 80 million. The Little Valley RAWS measured a wind gust of 87 mph around 130 AM PDT on the 14th, close to the time of the wildfire start.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of lightning and human/unknown causes brought 5 separate wildfires to western and west-central Nevada between the 4th and 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Earthstone Fire burned over 41,000 acres (mainly north of Interstate 80) as periods of extreme fire behavior allowed it to spread between the hills east of Sparks to several miles west of Wadsworth. Interstate 80 was closed, mainly between mile markers 22 and 43 from the evening of the 3rd into early morning on the 4th. The fire was suspected to be human-caused with no lightning or downed power lines in the area. The cost to fight the fire totaled at least $3.5M.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of lightning and human/unknown causes brought 5 separate wildfires to western and west-central Nevada between the 4th and 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Winnemucca Ranch Fire east of Pyramid Highway and in Palomino Valley burned around 4800 acres. Although 58 structures were threatened at the onset of the fire, the fire only wound up destroying one mobile home and two outbuildings on Amy Road. The fire was human-caused.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Perry Wildfire started on 27 July with the cause listed as unknown/under investigation. By 6 August, it had burned 51,400 acres and was fully contained.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Perry Fire southwest of Pyramid Lake burned 51,400 acres from 27 July 1622PST to 6 August 2100PST. Three residences and 15 other structures were damaged or destroyed. The fire cost at least $2.6 million dollars to fight. Microwave road was also closed during the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Perry Wildfire started on the 27th with the cause listed as unknown/under investigation. By 5 August, it had burned 51,400 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Perry Fire southwest of Pyramid Lake burned 51,400 acres from 27 July 1622PST to 6 August 2100PST. Three residences and 15 other structures were damaged or destroyed. The fire cost at least $2.6 million dollars to fight. Microwave road was also closed during the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A longwave trough moved across the northwestern US the 13th through the 17th. This trough brought breezy conditions each afternoon to western Nevada and eastern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jasper Fire in northern Sun Valley burned 1,165 acres from 13 July 1400PST to 16 July 1700PST. Sierra Front Dispatch Center stated that one home and two outbuildings were destroyed. At one point more than 100 homes were threatened, and the Washoe County Sheriff���s Office was going door-to-door urging people to evacuate. Firefighting costs were approximately $769K USD according to the Nevada Bureau of Land Management.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm temperatures, along with dry conditions, occurred the 23rd through the end of the month. Breezy conditions occurred on the 24th and 25th, but combined effects of winds and humidity did not reach critical fire weather criteria.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Long Valley Fire started near the Red Rock exit along US Highway 395 and spread across the California/Nevada border into northwestern Nevada the 24th before being contained the 27th. The fire burned 2438 acres, and one structure was destroyed. The Federal Emergency Management Agency stated that the fire threatened 250-300 homes in and around Rancho Haven (Nevada). The fire also threatened five buildings, infrastructure, utilities, equipment, farms, ranches, and a watershed in the area. Mandatory evacuations were ordered for approximately 800 people before containment was reached. Firefighting costs were approximately $600K, according to the Nevada Bureau of Land Management.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After some precipitation during the first week of the year, a spell of dry weather began in Arkansas. Through the middle of the month, the passage of dry cold fronts brought gusty winds and low humidities, drying vegetation considerably.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire burned 140 acres in timberlands of extreme eastern Saline County. The fire occurred between Brown's Trail and Hensley Mail Route Road. Most of the fire burned low to the ground. The fire threatened five residences, but was stopped by local fire departments and the Arkansas Forestry Commission.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry weather continued into the second week of October. The lack of rainfall, low humidities, and unusually warm temperatures permitted favorable conditions for the development of wildfires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire began about a mile south of Traskwood during the morning hours of the 10th. The fire escaped containment lines during the afternoon and spread considerably, eventually burning 486 acres. At least 21 fire departments fought the fire, along with the Arkansas Forestry Commission. Equipment deployed by the Forestry Commission included eight bulldozers and four air tankers. Two additional bulldozers were provided by a timber company. As the fire grew and threatened structures, Saline County declared a disaster and requested the assistance of the Arkansas National Guard. Arkansas Governor Mike Beebe approved the use of the Guard, and a helicopter was deployed to drop water on the fire. The governor went to the fire. As the fire threatened residences, approximately 575 people were evacuated from the Traskwood, Martin Cutoff, and Holly Creek townships. The Red Cross set up a shelter at the Harmony Grove High School in Haskell. Smoke from the fire spread across Benton, Bryant, and Bauxite in Saline County, and eventually spread into the Little Rock area in Pulaski County. The fire was contained on the evening of the 10th and the evacuees returned to their homes. One old barn was damaged and power was knocked out to some areas. No injuries occurred. Forestry Commission investigators indicated that the blaze was likely started by an arsonist. Ash from the fire fell at the National Weather Service office in North Little Rock, about 35 miles from the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Springlake Road Fire 4 miles east of East End in Saline County burned 100 acres on the 30th. Sixty people were evacuated at the height of the fire, but the fire was stopped before any structures burned. Five fire departments and the Arkansas Forestry Commission fought the fire. The fire was ruled to be arson.

An attempt to burn a pile of bamboo led to a 5 acre wildfire at East End in Saline County on the 28th. Seven fire departments fought the blaze. Two firefighters suffered heat exhaustion. Because a burn ban was in effect at the time of the fire, the landowner was issued a citation with a fine of $1100.
The Round Mountain Fire began on the 24th about 3 miles southeast of Williams Junction in Perry County and burned into Saline County before being controlled on the 25th. Altogether, 330 acres burned.
The combination of very dry vegatation and gusty winds resulted in a large wildfire across Jones County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large wildfire occured 4 miles east of Hawley. The fire burned 2600 acres and destroyed 11 homes, 20 outbuildings and 10 vehicles. Also, one firefighter was injured.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Plenty of fuels, extremely dry and hot weather and breezy south winds produced near  critical fire weather conditions in early August.  As a result of these weather conditions, a few smaller size wildfires erupted across West Central Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The CR-3116 Fore was located about 3 miles east of Anson and this fire burned about 300 acres.  Some structures were threatened but none were damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Persistent hot, dry, and windy weather continued to result in critical fire weather conditions throughout the month of June.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 450 acre Nugent Fire in east central Jones County was located 10 miles northeast of Hawley.  One home was destroyed while several homes were saved.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds and low relative humidity values resulted in wildfire conditions.  A large wildfire developed in Crockett and Jones Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 2700 acre wildfire called the 335 Fire burned between Hawley and Nugent.  This wildfire was started by a homeowner burning trash.  Strong winds near 50 mph caused the fire to spread east to FM600 and County Road 338 in Jones County.  County Road 338 was closed.  Two residential structures were lost.  One was unoccupied.  One barn did burn to the ground.  A total of nine buildings were destroyed by the wildfire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very dry conditions during the first half of April 2009, combined with low relative humidities and strong winds, led to favored days of above normal and dangerous fire weather behavior.  This led to several wild fires across western Wisconsin.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A grass fire quickly became out of control in the Town of Shelby destroying several vehicles and burning 10 acres of farm fields, grass and woodlands.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A high pressure system centered over the Upper Midwest the previous two days produced very dry conditions over the area. This allowed the minimum relative humidity to fall into the 25 to 35 percent range, as reported by the automated weather observing equipment at the La Crosse and Viroqua airports in the afternoon hours of April 18th and 19th. The combination of the dry conditions and local wind effects enabled a control burn to become uncontrollable on the La Crosse County and Vernon County line on April 19th. The wildfire burned around 10 acres of grass.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A controlled burn of garbage quickly became out of control and burned 10 acres of grass.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several large wildfires broke out between February 18 and February 21 because of the rich fuels and the very dry and windy conditions.  Some of the wildfires flared up and continued through the end of the month as elevated fire danger or red flag warning conditions persisted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 1000 acre grass fire broke out in Coleman County. The grass fire was east of FM 2132 and south of Highway 153 near Talpa.  The fire was 60 percent contained at 7:40 p.m.  The fire burned one outbuilding and one vehicle.  The time the fire was fully contained is estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front brought strong northeast winds and dry air to create ideal conditions for these wildifires to develop in late September.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 1200 acre Coleman Burkett West Wildfire was located 7 miles north northwest of Burkett.  The wildfire burned areas in the vicinity of Highway 206 in northeast Coleman County.  Three homes were threatened and saved but two outbuildings were lost in the fire.  The fire was fully extinguished.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very dry and hot summer with very little precipitation and abundant fuels from the spring continued to result in ideal conditions for wildfires across portions of West Central Texas.   Two large wildfires developed in Sutton and Coleman Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Eiesenhower Wildfire burned approximately 336 acres near U.S. Highway 283 and County Road 152 or 3 miles west of Echo.  The fire was 100% contained on September 30.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very dry conditions and strong winds caused a grass fire to become out of control and burn two acres on the northeast side of Rochester in Olmsted County on April 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire burned two acres of grass on the northeast side of Rochester.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire caused by very dry conditions and strong winds burned five acres on the southwest side of Rochester in Olmsted County on April 23.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A grass fire became uncontrollable and burned roughly five acres on the southwest side of Rochester.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong pacific front produced 40-50 mph winds gusts, relative humidity values of 5-10 percent, and an extremely critical fire danger threat across South Texas on April 2nd.  Sparked power lines from the gusty winds started a wildfire in and near the community of Lagarto.  The wildfire burned 175 acres, destroying 32 mobile homes, one single-family home, and 10 vehicles in the town of Lagarto.  Two individuals received minor injuries.  Several local, state and federal resources responded.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong pacific front produced 40-50 mph winds gusts, relative humidity values of 5-10 percent, and an extremely critical fire danger threat across South Texas on April 2nd.  Sparked power lines from the gusty winds started a wildfire in and near the community of Lagarto.  The wildfire burned 175 acres, destroying 32 mobile homes, one single-family home, and 10 vehicles in the town of Lagarto.  Two individuals received minor injuries.  Several local, state and federal resources responded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Ray Point wilfire burned around 600 acres off Highway 72 East, near Ray Point. (N28 30.8038, W98 5.1743) Four homes and three outbuildings were threatened and saved. Several local and state resources responded.  This wildfire started from a road side ignition.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Ray Point wilfire burned around 600 acres off Highway 72 East, near Ray Point. (N28 30.8038, W98 5.1743) Four homes and three outbuildings were threatened and saved. Several local and state resources responded.  This wildfire started from a road side ignition.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Nails Fire in rural Live Oak County burned through 500 acres of drought-stressed fuels (N 28 42.654 X W 098 05.113).  No structures were threatened.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Nails Fire in rural Live Oak County burned through 500 acres of drought-stressed fuels (N 28 42.654 X W 098 05.113).  No structures were threatened.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire occurred near County Road 357 and the Hideaway Hills subdivision near Lake Corpus Christi. The wildfire burned 200 acres, destroying 2 homes and 1 vehicle. The wildfire forced the evacuation of 90 residents. The wildfire occurred on a day with extreme fire danger conditions due to northwest winds gusting to between 40 and 50 mph and relative humidity values near 10 percent.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire occurred near County Road 357 and the Hideaway hills subdivision near Lake Corpus Christi. The wildfire burned 200 acres and destroyed 2 homes and 1 vehicle. The wildfire forced the evacuation of 90 residents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire occurred through brush on a dry lake bed on the northern reaches of Lake Corpus Christi. The wildfire burned almost 800 acres and threatened a few homes in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire occurred through brush and dead trees in a dry lake bed area on the northern reaches of Lake Corpus Christi. The fire burned almost 800 acres and threatened a few homes in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of very dry conditions and gusty winds produced a wildfire in Throckmorton County.
Persistent hot, dry, and windy weather continued to result in critical fire weather conditions throughout the month of June.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Matthews Ranch Wildfire was located 18 miles southwest of Throckmorton and was started by an electrical short.  The fire burned about 3,024 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Critical Fire Weather Conditions occurred on April 25 across much of West Central Texas as a dryline brought southwest to west winds of 20 to 25 mph, relative humidity levels below 20 percent, and temperatures in the 90s.  Isolated thunderstorms ignited a large wildfire in Kimble County on April 26.  A few of these fires continued through the end of April.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This wildfire burned about 7,000 acres and it was 100 percent contained.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Persistent hot, dry, and windy weather continued to result in critical fire weather conditions throughout the month of June that featured numerous intense, deep burning fires resulting in significant downwind spotting that lasted for days and weeks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lambs Head Wildfire was located just west of the intersection of U.S. Highways 283 and 183 or about 13 miles west of Woodson.  The wildfire was started by an electrical short.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Persistent hot, dry, and windy weather continued to result in critical fire weather conditions throughout the month of June.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The JRM Wildfire was about 5 miles east of Throckmorton.  The fire was started by lightning and burned approximately 7,000 acres.  Twelve buildings were threatened but one outbuilding was lost.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry and windy conditions resulted in explosive fire conditions in north Texas on this day. Some wildfires were rekindled fires that had been smoldering from earlier in the week. These wildfires burned tens of thousands of acres, multiple structures, and killed cattle. Two fatalities occurred in Stoenburg as a couple tried to protect their home. Several of the fires were being fought or watched until April 11th and 12th when rain brought relief to parts of north Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 3000 acre wildfire near Breckenridge threatened an apartment complex resulting in evacuations. This wildfire spread from near HWY 183 on the north side of the city to SH 67 on the northeast side of the city. It was reported to be 4 miles long by 1 mile wide. Another wildfire also burned part of the northwestern corner of the county, west of the old Fort Davis. This fire had spread into the county from Throckmorton County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Possum Kingdom Fire Complex consisted of four separate wildfires that merged into one large complex due to critical fire weather conditions and windy days. The four fires were the Possum Kingdom West Fire, the Possum Kingdom East Fire, the Hohertz Fire, and the Jackson Ranch Fire. In all, 126,734 acres were burned by this complex, 167 homes and 2 churches were destroyed, and another 124 outbuildings were lost. Most of the destroyed homes were on the south and west sides of Possum Kingdom Lake, and 90% of Possum Kingdom State Park was torched. In addition, several heads of cattle were killed by the fires and many more were burned or injured. The estimated damage from these fires was over $150 million, and the Texas Forestry Service estimated the cost to fight the fire was over $11 million.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jackson Ranch Fire began in southeast Stephens County, approximately 4 miles east of La Casa. On April 17th, this fire caused the evacuation of the towns of Caddo and Strawn. On April 19th, it became a part of the PK Complex Fire. In all, 126,734 acres were burned by this complex of four fires, 167 homes were destroyed, 2 churches were destroyed, and another 124 outbuildings were lost. The Jackson Ranch Fire burned an estimated 6,687 acres of land.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Possum Kingdom Fire Complex consisted of four separate wildfires that merged into one large complex due to critical fire weather conditions and windy days. The four fires were the Possum Kingdom West Fire, the Possum Kingdom East Fire, the Hohertz Fire, and the Jackson Ranch Fire. In all, 126,734 acres were burned by this complex, 167 homes and 2 churches were destroyed, and another 124 outbuildings were lost. Most of the destroyed homes were on the south and west sides of Possum Kingdom Lake, and 90% of Possum Kingdom State Park was torched. In addition, several heads of cattle were killed by the fires and many more were burned or injured. The estimated damage from these fires was over $150 million, and the Texas Forestry Service estimated the cost to fight the fire was over $11 million.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Possum Kingdom West fire began in Stephens County near FM 1148 and FM 3253. However, strong winds on critical fire weather days also drove this fire into Palo Pinto and Young County. On the 18th, it made a fast run towards Graham in Young County resulting in evacuations for the town of Bunger. The fire also caused several hundred people to be evacuated around PK Lake. It scorched 90% of the 1500 acre Possum Kingdom Lake State Park on April 17th, but no structures were lost at the park. On April 15th, this fire merged with the Hohertz Fire in Palo Pinto County and the fires were renamed the PK Complex. On April 17th, the PK East Fire in Palo Pinto County was added to this complex, and on April 19th, the Jackson Ranch Fire in Stephens County also burned into the complex. In all, 126,734 acres were burned by this complex of four fires, 167 homes were destroyed, 2 churches were destroyed, and another 124 outbuildings were lost. The PK West Fire burned the most acres and may have burned over 80,000 acres. This fire burned 52 homes in Sportsman World, 37 homes at Gaines Bend, and 24 homes in Hog Bend. Several mobile homes on the west side of the lake near FM 1148 and FM 1287 were burned. This fire also burned the 100-year-old Cedar Springs United Methodist Church west of Palo Pinto. At least 22 known heads of cattle were killed by this fire and several more were injured.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several wildfires broke out in the western counties of North Texas from April 15th-19th. It took several days to control these fires. They burned over 18000 acres of land. The largest wildfire was the Bryson Complex in western Jack and eastern Young County. Fires in Eastland County killed one firefighter and burned 6 more.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Hubbard Creek Fire burned 800 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several wildfires broke out in the western counties of North Texas from April 15th-19th. It took several days to control these fires. They burned over 18000 acres of land. The largest wildfire was the Bryson Complex in western Jack and eastern Young County. Fires in Eastland County killed one firefighter and burned 6 more.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mossy Rock Ranch Fire began 8.5 miles southwest of Caddo and burned approximately 850 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The CR 156 Fire began July 26th approximately 16 miles south of Breckenridge near Highway 183. The fire was first contained on July 28th after burning a total of 4321 acres. Two homes, two deer shelters, a vehicle, and an outbuilding were lost in the fire. On August 4th, this fire reignited and consumed another 614 acres for a final total of 4935 acres. The fire was finally completely controlled on August 14th. Very hot and dry conditions during both of these months resulted in elevated fire danger.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The CR 156 Fire began July 26th approximately 16 miles south of Breckenridge near Highway 183. The fire was first contained on July 28th after burning a total of 4321 acres. Two homes, two deer shelters, a vehicle, and an outbuilding were lost in the fire. On August 4th, this fire reignited and consumed another 614 acres for a final total of 4935 acres. The fire was finally completely controlled on August 14th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The CR 156 Fire began July 26th approximately 16 miles south of Breckenridge near Highway 183. The fire was first contained on July 28th after burning a total of 4321 acres. On August 4th, this fire reignited and consumed another 614 acres for a final total of 4935 acres. During the rekindle, another home, vehicle, a barn, and several more outbuildings were lost. This brought the total homes burned by the fire to three. The fire was finally completely controlled on August 14th. Very hot and dry conditions during both of these months resulted in elevated fire danger.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The CR 156 Fire began July 26th approximately 16 miles south of Breckenridge near Highway 183. The fire was first contained on July 28th after burning a total of 4321 acres. Two homes, two deer shelters, a vehicle, and an outbuilding were lost in the fire. On August 4th, this fire reignited and consumed another 614 acres for a final total of 4935 acres. During the rekindle, another home, vehicle, a barn, and several more outbuildings were lost. The fire was finally completely controlled on August 14th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry weather in the middle part of the month of October allowed for conditions to be ripe for wildfires to begin. Several fires occurred in the western half of north Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Fuller Fire burned an estimated 1,000 acres across Stephens County. The fire was concentrated along Stephens County roads 324 and 325. A few residences were evacuation for precautionary measures, but the fire did not threaten any homes. The fire was extinguished by rainfall during the afternoon of October 23rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large brush fire consumed 388 acres northwest of Ellsinore, about midway between U.S. Highway 60 and Highway H. Conditions were ripe for such a fire due to the summer and fall drought. Very low relative humidity on consecutive afternoons dried fine fuels such as leaves and grass. Green vegetation that normally slows the rate of fire spread in the summer was dormant due to killing frosts in October.

Low humidity, strong winds, and dry conditions fanned a couple large wildfires. The first fire was just off U.S. Highway 60 about midway between Ellsinore and Van Buren. This fire consumed about 120 acres. A second larger fire consumed 334 acres along the Butler/Ripley County border, four or five miles north of Fairdealing.
Low humidity, strong winds, and dry conditions were blamed for a large wildfire about a mile south of Van Buren. The fire burned about 124 acres.

A forest fire about five miles north of Ellsinore burned 115 acres. The fire occurred due to severe drought conditions, gusty winds, and very low relative humidity. Rainfall the previous day had little effect on the dry conditions.
A lack of rainfall, combined with periodic low humidities and breezy conditions, created conditions favorable for wildfires in the middle of December.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire 1 mile north of Boswell destroyed 215 acres of forest.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Favorable conditions for wildfires continued into late March, with continuing dry vegetation and periodic spells of windy weather and low humidities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire 1 mile west of Dolph burned 928 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought continued into April over most of Arkansas. Periodic episodes of low humidities and very gusty winds led to conditions favorable for wildfires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire 2 miles east of Boswell burned 246 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snowfall on the 9th was followed by very dry air, bringing conditions conducive to wildfires during the middle of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire 2 miles north of Pineville burned 258 acres. No structures burned.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire destroyed a home on Bradley Branch Rd.

Drought conditions resulted in very dry fuels across most of Southwest Arkansas through the early portion of September.  Dry fuels and winds resulted in a large fire near Dierks, Arkansas that burned 570 acres of timberland.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A timber fire Sunday burned 570 acres northeast of Dierks, Arkansas, says the Arkansas Forestry Commission.  The timber fire was reported about 1:30 p.m. Sunday. Four airplanes and about 12 bulldozers were used to contain the fire. Five rural fire departments also assisted the forestry service in controlling the fire.  Six Arkansas Forestry Commission bulldozers responded to the fire along with two contracted single-engine air tankers that dropped water over the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ambient temperatures around 105 degrees in the afternoon, southwest winds near 10 mph with gusts approaching 20 mph, and very low relative humidity values combined with severe drought conditions across Southwest Arkansas.  A wildfire started in Howard County 3 miles west of Mineral Springs and burned 181 acres.  A firefighting place crashed near Hot Springs, Arkansas on route to the fire.  The pilot was not killed but seriously injured.
Very low relative humidity values, gusty winds at times, and ambient temperatures around 105 degrees resulted in a fire that consumed nearly 300 acres in Howard County, Arkansas.

Drought conditions resulted in a fire that got out of control across portions of Southwest Arkansas during the afternoon hours on Wednesday, September 15th.  This fire burned 244 acres of land near Taylor, Arkansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A fire fueled by extreme drought conditions burned about 244 acres of timber late Wednesday in Lafayette County, Arkansas, according to the Arkansas Forestry Commission.  The fire was about 10 miles northwest of Taylor on a pine tree plantation.  No one was hurt in the blaze, and no homes were damaged.  Fire departments in the county battled the fire with the help of a single-engine airplane used to drop water. Four forestry service bulldozers and two bulldozers from Deltic Timber were also used to suppress the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Near drought conditions across portions of Southwest Arkansas and hot temperatures resulted in a large fire getting out of control across Lafayette County, Arkansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large fire, burned 163 acres of grassland and timberland 5.5 miles southeast of Bradley, Arkansas.  There were no report of structures that were burned or injuries in relation to the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Despite rain over much of the state in the period from the 23rd through 26th, vegetation dried out enough to permit the development of wildfires at the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire 12 miles south of Hampton burned 115 acres. No structures were lost.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large wildfire 7.3 miles south of Hampton in Calhoun County burned 491 acres on the 13th.
A lack of rainfall and hot weather made conditions favorable for wildfires in early July. A wildfire 6.7 miles northeast of Calion in Calhoun County burned 150 acres on the 5th.
Despite rain over much of the state in the period from the 23rd through 26th, vegetation dried out enough to permit the development of wildfires at the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire 3 miles southeast of Sitka burned 174 acres. No structures were lost.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Favorable conditions for wildfires continued into late March, with continuing dry vegetation and periodic spells of windy weather and low humidities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire 3 miles south of Ash Flat burned 478 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snowfall on the 9th was followed by very dry air, bringing conditions conducive to wildfires during the middle of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire 4 miles south of Wirth burned 126 acres. No structures were lost.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low humidities and gusty winds made conditions favorable for wildfires late in February. On the 29th, a wildfire 4 miles northeast of Evening Shade in Sharp County burned 150 acres.
The Grange Fire was started by lightning 5 miles east of Cave City in Sharp County on the 15th. Altogether, 232 acres burned.

Dry weather, low humidities, and occasional gusty winds made conditions favorable for wildfires. On the 22nd, a fire 1 mile north of Cave City in Sharp County burned 105 acres, most of which was grassland. Then, on the 26th, a fire 6 miles southeast of Cave City in Sharp County burned 200 acres, most of which was grassland.

Dry weather, low humidities, and occasional gusty winds made conditions favorable for wildfires. On the 22nd, a fire 1 mile north of Cave City in Sharp County burned 105 acres, most of which was grassland. Then, on the 26th, a fire 6 miles southeast of Cave City in Sharp County burned 200 acres, most of which was grassland.
A small wildfire destroyed property in Baxter County northwest of Mountain Home.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small wildfire about 2 miles northwest of Mountain Home on County Road 493 destroyed a mobile home and a bobtail truck. The residents of the mobile home escaped unharmed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continued dry weather and periodic windy periods were favorable for wildfires in the middle part of March.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire 3 miles east of Norfork burned 258 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snowfall on the 9th was followed by very dry air, bringing conditions conducive to wildfires during the middle of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire 3 miles east of Norfork burned 230 acres. No structures were lost.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the 1st and 2nd, a wildfire 2 miles south of Norfork in Baxter County burned 126 acres.

Dry weather, low humidities, and occasional gusty winds made conditions favorable for wildfires. On the 20th, a fire 3.3 miles south-southeast of Norfork in Baxter County burned 205 acres, most of which was grassland.
Gusty winds resulted in a controlled burn to become a wildfire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A controlled burn at a farm became a wildfire when breezy winds developed and blew embers beyond the planned burn area.  A 100 foot by 50 foot area of baled hay burned up, and a number of vehicles and farm implements were destroyed.  Winds gusts in the west-central valleys of Colorado were measured at 20 to 25 mph.  A firefighter incurred minor injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A downed power line started a wildfire in southwest Colorado near Norwood, which was propelled by very strong winds and dry conditions. This fire began in May and persisted for several days through the beginning of June. Please see the May 2010 Storm Data Publication for additional information.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 2:30 pm on the afternoon of Saturday, May 22, strong winds downed a power line which sparked a wildfire near the border of San Miguel and Montrose Counties along Good Enough Road. The fire spread rapidly with dry conditions and very strong southwest winds in place. Highway 145 was closed for a period of time on May 5th due to the fire.  Portions of the San Miguel River were also closed due to the wildfire hazard. The fire continued for several days and eventually burned through roughly 2,500 acres of the Uncompahgre National Forest and nearly 430 acres of BLM land. There were no injuries or personal property damage reported, but the estimated cost of fighting the fire was $1,500,000. This fire began in May, so please see the May 2010 Storm Data Publication for additional information.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A downed power line started a wildfire in southwest Colorado near Norwood, which was propelled by very strong winds and dry conditions. The fire persisted for several days and burned into the month of June. Please see the June 2010 Storm Data Publication for additional information.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 2:30 pm on the afternoon of Saturday, May 22, a downed power line sparked a wildfire near the border of San Miguel and Montrose Counties along Good Enough Road. The fire spread rapidly with dry conditions and very strong southwest winds in place. Highway 145 was closed for a portion of time on Saturday due to the fire, and portions of the San Miguel River were also closed due to hazardous trees in the area. The fire continued for several days and eventually burned through roughly 2,500 acres of the Uncompahgre National Forest and nearly 430 acres of BLM land. There were no injuries or damages reported, but the estimated cost of the fire is $1,500,000. The fire continued into the month of June, so please see the June 2010 Storm Data Publication for additional information.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike ignited a wildfire about 8 miles northeast of Gateway.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Turner Gulch Fire began due to lightning ignition about 8 miles northeast of Gateway and grew to 150 acres before it was contained in mid September.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike ignited a wildfire 12 miles northwest of Nucla.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bull Draw Fire began due to lightning ignition about 12 miles northwest of Nucla and grew to 36,520 acres before it was contained in mid October.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike ignited a wildfire about 8 miles northeast of Gateway.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Turner Gulch Fire began due to lightning about 8 miles northeast of Gateway and grew to 150 acres before it was contained in mid September.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike ignited a wildfire about 12 miles northwest of Nucla.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bull Draw Fire began due to lightning about 12 miles northwest of Nucla and grew to 36,520 acres before it was contained in mid October.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike ignited a wildfire about 7 miles northeast of Nucla.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Tabeguache Fire began due to lightning ignition about 7 miles northeast of Nucla and grew to approximately 500 acres before it was contained.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike ignited a wildfire about 12 miles northeast of Norwood near Sanborn Park.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Tarantula Fire began due to lightning ignition about 12 miles northeast of Norwood and grew to a total of 112 acres before it was contained.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike ignited a wildfire about 12 miles northwest of Nucla.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bull Draw Fire began due to lightning ignition about 12 miles northwest of Nucla and grew to 36,520 acres before it was contained in mid October.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike ignited a wildfire about 12 miles northwest of Nucla.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bull Draw Fire began due to lightning about 12 miles northwest of Nucla and grew to 36,520 acres before it was contained in mid October.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tractor ignited a cornfield south of Osseo in Trempealeau County in the early evening hours of April 17th. The wildfire killed one individual and injured two others. Winds had increased to 15 mph with gusts up to 25 mph in the area that afternoon and evening.  This combined with dry weather conditions the preceding two days enabled the wildfire to become uncontrollable.
