EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire fatally wounded one person and injured two others in a cornfield south of Osseo in Trempealeau County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An elderly man died from burns sustained trying to extinguish a grass fire near Ettrick (Trempealeau County). The fire occurred during the morning of April 20th and was started by a burning pile of garbage. The automated weather observing equipment at the La Crosse (La Crosse County) airport indicated the relative humidity was around 35% with a southwest wind gusting to near 20 mph at the time of the fire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An elderly Ettrick man died after sustaining burns trying to put out a grassfire. The fire started as a result of a burning pile of garbage. The automated weather observing equipment at the La Crosse airport indicated the relative humidity was around 35% with a a southwest wind gusting to around 20 mph at the time of the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions combined with winds gusting to 30mph and low relative humidity to allow a wild fire near Galena, Kansas to burn out of control for several hours. The fire burned around 100 acres of off Schermerhorn Road and destroyed a couple of mobile homes. One resident was injured and taken to the hospital for smoke inhalation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 100 acre wildfire destroyed several mobile homes and injured one resident.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry and breezy weather along with an ongoing drought in the area help spread a large grass fire which damaged a mobile home and destroyed a shed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large grass fire quickly spread and consumed about 100 acres of mostly rural areas just east of Galena near the Kansas and Missouri state line. A mobile home suffered minor damage and a shed was completely destroyed. Fire departments from Galena and Baxter Springs in Kansas and Carl Junction in Missouri responded to the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tight pressure gradient caused strong gusty winds across southeast Kansas and resulted in at least one grass fire to rapidly spread and become out of control.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong gusty winds over 50 mph led to a rapidly spreading grass fire near Galena. The fire was started by a fallen power line that had been blown down due to the winds. The fire burned approximately 500 acres and destroyed at least three outdoor structures and one car.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low humidity, strong winds, and dry conditions fanned a couple large wildfires. The first fire was just off U.S. Highway 60 about midway between Ellsinore and Van Buren. This fire consumed about 120 acres. A second larger fire consumed 334 acres along the Butler/Ripley County border, four or five miles north of Fairdealing.

A high pressure system centered over the Upper Midwest the previous two days produced very dry conditions over the area. This allowed the minimum relative humidity to fall into the 25 to 35 percent range, as reported by the automated weather observing equipment at the La Crosse and Viroqua airports in the afternoon hours of April 18th and 19th. The combination of the dry conditions and local wind effects enabled a control burn to become uncontrollable on the La Crosse County and Vernon County line on April 19th. The wildfire burned around 10 acres of grass.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A controlled burn of garbage quickly became out of control and burned 10 acres of grass.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry and gusty east to southeast winds on the 18th contributed to the rapid growth of two wildfires that afternoon.  The Meridian Boundary Fire and Range 9 Fire would both be among the most significant wildfires of the spring wildfire season.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Range 9 Fire started on the 18th as a controlled burn on an artillery range on Camp Grayling, a National Guard facility.  The fire got out of control after 230 pm as winds picked up.  Most of the 1100 acres burned were grassy areas on the Camp Grayling grounds.  However, a portion of the fire crossed the military installation's property line near the Manistee River in Blue Lake Township, destroying four seasonal homes.  The fire was under control by late evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lack of rainfall and low humidities allowed for the development of two significant wildfires, one on the 22nd and one on the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire about a mile southwest of Cross Roads burned 120 acres of timber. Some of the trees that were destroyed had been replanted following a tornado on May 2, 2008. Nine residences were evacuated because of the proximity of the fire, but none of the structures burned. Six fire departments and the Arkansas Forestry Commission fought the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry weather, occasional gusty winds, and low humidities continued to create conditions favorable for wildfires in the latter part of October.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire burned 221 acres near the Orion community in northeast Grant County. Although some homes were threatened by the fire, aggressive firefighting prevented any structures from being lost. The Arkansas Forestry Commission used three air tankers and five bulldozers in the firefighting effort. Numerous fire departments were also on the scene, including departments from Grant, Saline, Pulaski, and Jefferson counties. The fire was believed to have been started by a resident burning trash. A burn ban was in effect at the time and a citation was issued to the homeowner.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very dry weather in September continued into October. Dry vegetation, along with low humidities and periodic episodes of gusty winds, contributed to the spread of wildfires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire burned 177 acres 2 to 3 miles south of Monticello, between Old Troy Rd. and New Light Rd. Seven volunteer fire departments and the Arkansas Forestry Commission fought the fire. No structures burned.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lack of rainfall and very low humidities were contributing factors to a large wildfire in southeast Arkansas on the 18th and 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire consumed 1,013 acres northwest of Troy, in the area around Upper Gates Mainline Rd. and Lower Gates Mainline Rd. Most of the trees were pines, belonging to a large timber company. The trees were one to 30 years old. At times, the flames reached as high as 100 feet. No structures burned. The Arkansas Forestry Commission used two air tankers and 11 bulldozers to fight the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continuing drought conditions led to conditions favorable for wildfires in southern Arkansas during early May.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire 5 miles south of Wilmar burned 115 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Lacey Fire began on the 14th 8 miles southwest of Monticello in Drew County and continued until the 15th. Altogether, 1410 acres burned. Ten fire departments, Arkansas Forestry Commission crews from eight counties, three aircraft, and 13 fire plows fought the fire. At the height of the fire, about 45 people were evacuated from the Possum Valley community, and a 24-inch natural gas line was threatened. In the end, only timber was lost to the fire.

Extreme drought, fairly low relative humidities, and occasional brisk breezes, created conditions favorable for wildfires. The Singleton Creek Fire began on the afternoon of the 17th 6.4 miles southeast of Hermitage in Bradley County. The fire was controlled on the morning of the 19th. Altogether, 1573 acres burned, making this, by far, the largest wildfire so far this year in Arkansas. Also, it was the largest wildfire in Bradley County in 13 years. Most of the area burned belonged to a large timber company. The Ten Mile Creek Fire began on the afternoon of the 19th 1.8 miles southeast of Wilmar in Drew County. During the evening of the 19th, a few residents were evacuated on S. Allis Rd. and the fire forced the closing of U.S. 278 near Wilmar. The fire eventually burned up to the edge of Wilmar. It was controlled on the morning of the 20th, after burning 495 acres. Four structures at deer camps were destroyed.

A long term drought created dry surface fuels across southeast Georgia. The Arabia Bay Wildfire was first reported to the NWS in Jacksonville on November 10th in northern Clinch county. The fire started in a peat swamp and grew to approximately 500 acres in size by November 14th.  The Arabia Bay fire grew to 2710 acres by the end of the month and was ongoing but 100% contained.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Arabia Bay wildfire burned within a peat swamp for most of the month of November. The fire grew from 500 acres on Nov. 14th to 700 acres on the 15th. On the 19th, the fire was approximately 1170 acres. On the 23rd the fire had grown to 2688 acres and was about 75% contained. By the 25th, the fire was 100% contained and had reached 2710 acres in size. The fire had produced significant amounts of smoke over a large portion of southern Georgia and north Florida. This smoke and fog indirectly resulted in an injury to a Sheriff's Officer due to a traffic accident.||Heavy ash and smoke were reported near the fire, and depending on the wind regime, some days very heavy smoke impacted Atkinson and Bacon counties  (north of the fire site). Smoke was the major impact from the fire as property was not threatened. There were no injuries reported to the NWS that were fire related. There were several road closures due to smoke near the fire. ||The fire burned through the end of the month and into December. The NWS Jacksonville provided daily site specific fire weather forecasts, spot forecasts and ran Hysplit runs and disseminated this data to the GEMA Area Coordinator as well as created a web site for fire response officials to reference. ||On Nov. 23rd, the total cost spent on fire control was $230,672. This amount does not include property damage to swampland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry and warm conditions enabled the Arabia Bay wildfire complex in a peat swamp to reignite in northwest Clinch county. The fire burned through the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Arabia Bay wildfire complex reignited with the first reported to NWS Jacksonville on March 18th. The fire burned about 400 to 500 acres from the 18th to the 22nd. The combination of fog and smoke caused periodic road closures of Highways 221 and 441 near Homerville. ||On the 24th, the fire had reached 1500 acres. Highway 441 was closed from the Atkinson County line to Homerville. State Road 122 was closed from State Road 168 to Highway 441. ||On the 25th, the fire had reach 4000 acres. The southeast boundary of the fire was 1 mile from Homerville and threatened numerous structures. Evacuations occurred. U.S. Highway 441 was still closed north of Homerville. Georgia Road 122 east of U.S. Highway 441 to Cogdell Road was also closed. ||Early on the 27th the fire was 12,975 acres which included portions of the Berry Patch community and the city of Homerville. Many residential and commercial structures were threatened and evacuations continued. ||Around 7 pm EDT on March 27th, the fire was 45 percent contained. Residents who evacuated on March 26th were allowed to return to home. ||Early on the 29th, the Arabia Bay fire has burned 12,484 acres and was still about 45 percent contained.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A period of very dry and hot weather led to numerous mostly small grass fires across north Alabama. One of these grass fires became larger on the weekend of the 18th - 20th in Franklin county charring between 250 and 300 acres of land alone.  Another fire burned several acres in the Gurley area as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One large grass fire developed in Franklin county on the east side of CR 83 and jumped to the west side of the highway on Saturday, September 18th, 2010. It then continued onward for another 9 to 10 hours, burning through timberland and farmland. Three structures were lost to the flames before Volunteer firefighters were able to put the fire out.  Officials estimate between 250 and 300 acres of land were damaged by this blaze.  ||Another smaller grass fire developed at 3 pm on Tuesday, September 21st.  It damaged at least another 75 acres before it was contained.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions and gusty winds helped a wildfire rapidly spread near the town of Littleville. Nearly 500 acres were burned.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large wildfire burned nearly 500 acres near the Twin Pines subdivision in Littleville which is very close to the Franklin/Colbert county line. Gusty winds helped the fire spread. Relative humidity lowered to between 25-35 percent during the afternoon. No structures were impacted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions continued into early November. Low humidities and periodic breezy weather created conditions favorable for wildfires. Rain later in the month caused the threat of wildfires to diminish considerably.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire 16 miles northwest of Clinton burned 1004 acres. The fire was in a very remote area and no structures were lost.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continued dry weather and periodic windy periods were favorable for wildfires in the middle part of March.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire 10 miles northwest of Clinton burned 736 acres. Eighteen fire departments and the Arkansas Forestry Commission fought the fire. Four single-engine air tankers were used in the fire fight. Three residences, four outbuildings, and 10 cars were destroyed. Some of the cars were antique vehicles. Two firefighters suffered smoke inhalation and were treated at the scene. The Forestry Commission determined that this fire was arson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Clinton Fire began near Cleveland in Conway County and eventually spread into Van Buren County. The fire burned 110 acres. Three firefighters were treated for heat exhaustion. At least five fire departments and the Arkansas Forestry Commission fought the fire.
The Claude Schoolhouse Fire 10 miles southwest of Clinton on the 28th burned a total of 300 acres in Van Buren and Conway counties.

Dry conditions continued into early November. Low humidities and periodic breezy weather created conditions favorable for wildfires. Rain later in the month caused the threat of wildfires to diminish considerably.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire about a mile west of Leslie burned 331 acres. No structures were lost.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continued dry weather and periodic windy periods were favorable for wildfires in the middle part of March.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire 3 miles southeast of Snowball burned 238 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continued dry weather and periodic windy periods were favorable for wildfires in the middle part of March.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire 6 miles south of Canaan burned 200 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continued dry weather and periodic windy periods were favorable for wildfires in the middle part of March.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire 6 miles west of Leslie burned 101 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continuing drought conditions, along with periodic low humidities and gusty winds created conditions favorable for wildfires during the first part of March.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire 4 miles south of Snowball burned 236 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continuing drought conditions, along with periodic low humidities and gusty winds created conditions favorable for wildfires during the first part of March.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire 2 miles southeast of Snowball burned 162 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A recent lack of rainfall, low humidities and gusty winds made conditions favorable for wildfires late in early March. On the 1st, a wildfire 1.5 miles north of Pindall in Searcy County burned 114 acres.

A recent lack of rainfall, low humidities and gusty winds made conditions favorable for wildfires late in early March. On the 1st, a wildfire 3 miles southwest of Leslie in Searcy County burned 367 acres.

A recent lack of rainfall, low humidities and gusty winds made conditions favorable for wildfires late in early March. On the 2nd, a large wildfire began 2 miles southeast of Cozahome in Searcy County. The fire was not controlled until the 5th. Altogether, 1032 acres burned.
Low humidities and gusty winds made conditions favorable for wildfires late in February. On the 25th and 26th, a wildfire 5 miles southeast of Snowball in Searcy County burned 232 acres.
The Snowball Fire 4 miles southeast of Snowball in Searcy County burned 308 acres on the 17th and 18th.

A lack of rainfall, low humidities, and periodic gusty winds made conditions favorable for wildfires from the 13th through the 15th. On the 13th, the Boxley Church Fire began 14 miles west of Jasper in Newton County. It was controlled the next day after burning 311 acres. On the 14th, the Moscow Love Fire 4 miles southwest of St. Joe in Searcy County burned 340 acres. On the 14th, the Boat Mountain East Fire began 3.8 miles west of Western Grove in Newton County. It was controlled the next day after burning 568 acres.
A wildfire in Searcy County on the 4th destroyed 109 acres of timber 4 miles north of Witts Springs.

The Fourmile Canyon Wildfire, northwest of Boulder, broke out Monday morning.  It  originated from an unattended fire pit at a local residence.  The wildfire quickly consumed 5 1/2 square miles or 3,500 acres the first day, and forced the evacuation of over 3,000 residents.  Erratic 45-mph gusts sent the fire in two directions at times. Very dry weather conditions preceded the fire.  The combination of strong winds, low relative humidities and dry fuels allowed the wildfire spread rapidly through the steep, heavily forested terrain.  The flames were reportedly 20 to 50 feet in length.  Towns within the burn area included Salina, Wallstreet and Gold Hill.  The dry conditions coupled with gusty winds ranging from 45 to 64 mph persisted for several more days.  ||Fire managers used as many as 700 firefighters and support personnel from 35 agencies and seven air tankers to battle the wildfire.  A total of 6,181 square acres or approximately 10 square miles were burned.  The Fourmile Canyon Wildfire was the most destructive fire in Colorado history in terms of the damage to personal property.  It destroyed 171 homes with an estimated cost of 217 million dollars.

Gusty south winds, along with very dry conditions, developed ahead of an approaching cold front. When a wildfire was started at Camp Williams by machine gun fire, the winds helped the fire to rapidly spread into the neighboring community of Herriman, destroying multiple homes and forcing an evacuation of the neighborhood.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Utah National Guard took target practice on their machine gun firing range at Camp Williams on the afternoon of September 19th. Shrapnel from this exercise ignited brush around the area and, with the help of wind gusts generally in the 30-40 mph range and relative humidity values between 5 and 10 percent, the fire quickly spread. This wildfire eventually threatened the nearby town of Herriman, specifically the subdivisions of The Cove at Herriman Springs and the High Country Estates II, resulting in the mandatory evacuation of an estimated 5,000 people in over 1,600 homes. By the time the fire was stopped and contained, it had burned over 4,300 acres, completely destroying 3 houses and damaging at least 400 other houses. Several people were injured due to the fire, primarily police officers and firefighters responding to the blaze, with the most common injury being smoke inhalation. The listed end time is when the fire was 100% contained.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions persisted across Utah through the end of June. This led to several more wildfire ignitions at the end of the month, some of which caused property damage or injuries. Note that most of these fires continued into July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rose Crest Fire began on July 29th in Herriman, Utah. The fire was started when a car was parked on a very dry field; the heat from the car ignited the grass, and the fire quickly spread into the residential neighborhood. The fire forced the evacuation of nearly 1,000 residences, and eventually burned 612 acres before it was 100% contained on July 2nd. 4 residences were destroyed, 8 other residences sustained moderate to heavy damage, and 30 non-residential buildings were destroyed. In addition to these property damages, the fire suppression cost a total of $540,000. Note that this event continued into July, and monetary property damages will be listed on the July report.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Many of the wildfires that began in late June continued into July, burning thousands of acres and causing millions of dollars in damage. Note that this episode began in June.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rose Crest Fire began on July 29th in Herriman, Utah. The fire was started when a car was parked on a very dry field; the heat from the car ignited the grass, and the fire quickly spread into the residential neighborhood. The fire forced the evacuation of nearly 1,000 residences, and eventually burned 612 acres before it was 100% contained on July 2nd. 4 residences were destroyed, 8 other residences sustained moderate to heavy damage, and 30 non-residential buildings were destroyed. In addition to these property damages, the fire suppression cost a total of $540,000. Note that this event began in June, and monetary property damages listed on this report are for the entire month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With very dry fuels, a very dry air mass, and an increasing southwesterly flow as a low pressure system remained near the Pacific Coast, conditions across Utah became perfect for explosive fire growth. The winds were severe at times across northwest Utah, and any fires that started spread very quickly. Several of these wildfires caused property damage or injuries, and one caused a fatality. Note that some of these fires continued into July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell onto a power line in West Jordan, Utah, igniting a field. This fire quickly spread into nearby homes, burning two houses. In addition, a third home suffered significant smoke damage, and the fire damaged a fence and a gazebo. One firefighter suffered heat exhaustion while battling the blaze, which was put out later that day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With very dry fuels, a very dry air mass, and an increasing southwesterly flow as a low pressure system remained near the Pacific Coast, conditions across Utah became perfect for explosive fire growth. The winds were severe at times across northwest Utah, and any fires that started spread very quickly. Several of these wildfires caused property damage or injuries, and one caused a fatality. Note that some of these fires continued into July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A fire started in a field in Draper, Utah, damaging one home and threatening two others. The fire burned through 150 feet of wooden fencing, and caused light damage to a garage and a vehicle at one of the homes, before being contained 25 minutes later.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong and windy storm system moved through Utah beginning April 14, and the winds caused widespread damage across the state. This damage included a fatal pileup accident on Interstate 80 and a destructive wildfire in central Utah that was fueled by the winds. In addition, the storm brought heavy snowfall to both the mountains and valleys of northern Utah.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A fallen power line ignited a brush fire in the Avenues area of Salt Lake City, which quickly grew to 100 acres due to strong winds. Ten homes were evacuated near 700 North and I Street. Firefighters were able to quickly contain the blaze, keeping it from reaching any of the homes, but one home suffered heat damage in the outside patio area, and a second house suffered smoke damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small wildfire occurred in the Salt Lake City metropolitan area, when grassland near the Jordan River caught fire. This fire threatened homes and caused some local damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A human-caused grass fire erupted in Murray, along the Jordan River in the Hunter Woods area. The fire threatened several homes, but firefighters were able to stop the blaze before it reached the residences. A few homes did receive smoke damage from the fire, and approximately 1,200 feet of vinyl fencing was destroyed. The fire also destroyed a walking bridge in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On July 19, an arsonist intentionally set fire to a field in Tooele. Fanned by strong wind gusts, the fire was pushed to a nearby neighborhood, destroying and damaging several homes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An arsonist intentionally set fire to a field in Tooele on the night of July 19. The fire spread quickly into a nearby neighborhood due to gusty winds, with gusts generally in the 25-35 mph range. By the time firefighters had controlled the blaze by the morning of July 20, the fire had destroyed 10 homes and caused significant damage to 8 other homes. In addition, about eight cars and at least five outbuildings were destroyed. The fire also consumed trees and vinyl fences. Ten people were treated at the hospital for smoke inhalation, and at least three of those were first responders. One person was treated for a head injury from a fall related to the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A human caused fire developed during the afternoon of September 15 in Herriman. The fire destroyed two homes before being contained that evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A juvenile playing with fireworks sparked a fire in Herriman on the afternoon of September 15. Due to windy conditions and low relative humidity, the fire spread quickly, eventually burning more than 100 acres, destroying two homes, and causing the temporary evacuation of some nearby neighborhoods before being contained during the evening. One firefighter and four police officers were treated for smoke inhalation and heat exhaustion while helping fight the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong gradient wind gusting to around 40 mph, low relative humidity, and very dry grasses contributed to two wildland fires spreading into populated portions of southeastern Pawnee County. A home and several outbuildings were burned by the fires.

Strong wind, low relative humidities, warm temperatures, and dormant vegetation promoted the spread of wildfire on the 20th. Around 70 wildfires were reported this day across eastern Oklahoma burning more than 4000 acres. Some of the larger wildfires occurred in Pittsburg, Latimer, Haskell, Adair, and Pushmataha Counties. ||Local fire departments along with Oklahoma Forestry Services, the Bureau of Indian Affairs and the Oklahoma Army National Guard battled those blazes, many of which threatened structures. Several outbuildings were burned but no homes were lost.

Very windy and dry conditions along with near record temperatures and vegetation that was dry and stressed due to ongoing drought conditions resulted in the rapid spread of a wildfire west of Keystone Lake. This fire consumed more than 1500 acres. More than 20 fire departments, Oklahoma Forestry personnel, and an Oklahoma National Guard helicopter worked this fire, which threatened at least 25 homes.

Warm, dry, and very windy conditions, combined with dormant vegetation resulted in the rapid spread of wildfire on February 18th. Wildfires burned over 20,000 acres of land in Okfuskee County, which destroyed several outbuildings. Several thousands of acres were burned in Okmulgee County, which also destroyed outbuildings. In Pawnee County, more than 3300 acres were burned by wildfire, also destroying several outbuildings. Over 500 acres were burned in Latimer County.

Strong wind, low relative humidity, unseasonably warm temperatures, and drought-stricken, dormant vegetation promoted the rapid spread of wildfires on April 30th across northern Creek and Pawnee Counties. More than 800 acres were burned by these wildfires, forcing the evacuation of about 40 residences. The fires continued through May 1st.

Strong wind, low relative humidity, unseasonably warm temperatures, and drought-stricken, dormant vegetation promoted the rapid spread of wildfires on April 30th across northern Creek and Pawnee Counties. These wildfires continued through May 1st and burned over 800 acres, forcing the evacuation of about 40 residences.
A lack of rainfall, combined with periodic low humidities and breezy conditions, created conditions favorable for wildfires in the middle of December.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire 3 miles southwest of Gurdon destroyed 107 acres in the forest.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably warm weather, coupled with low humidities and continuing dry conditions led to the spread of many wildfires over the weekend of the 29th and 30th. The Arkansas Forestry Commission aided in the suppression of 87 wildfires which burned a total of 1730 acres. No homes were lost to the fires, but 34 were threatened.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire about 4 miles northwest of Okolona burned 142 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry weather, low humidities, and gusty winds made conditions favorable for wildfires in early September. A wildfire 8 miles southeast of Amity in Clark County burned 140 acres on the 5th.
The Gurdon 1 Fire near Gurdon in Clark County burned 160 acres on the 29th. Four fire departments and the Arkansas Forestry Commission fought the fire.
The Gurdon 2 Fire about 6 miles east of Gurdon in Clark County burned 200 acres on the 1st. Two fire departments and the Arkansas Forestry Commission fought the fire.

The Amity Fire occurred on the 4th 6.2 miles northeast of Amity in Clark County and then spread into Hot Spring County. Altogether, 350 acres burned. A number of fire departments, the Arkansas Forestry Commission, and the U.S. Forest Service fought the fire, which was started by a hay baling machine. Six farm buildings, the hay baler, and a tractor were destroyed.

The Rose Hill Fire was started by lightning 2 miles northwest of Whelen Springs in Clark County on the 13th and continued until the 14th. Altogether, 852 acres burned. A few homes were evacuated at the height of the fire.

The DeGray Fire 8 miles northwest of Caddo Valley in Clark County burned 100 acres on the 4th. Several fire departments, the Arkansas Forestry Commission, the the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers fought the fire.

CZ_NAME: NORTHERN SANGRE DE CRISTO MOUNTAINS ABOVE 11000 FT
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning sparked a fire which burned slowly, then erupted on the 17th and rapidly spread from the Sangre de Cristo Mountains east of the Great Sand Dunes into Custer County.  The fire continued to burn into July, and has consumed nearly 6300 acres.

CZ_NAME: NORTHERN SANGRE DE CRISTO MOUNTAINS ABOVE 11000 FT
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike caused the Hayden Pass wildfire on July 8th, and the wildfire continued to smoulder until August 10th. The wildfire was mainly on USFS wilderness land, high up in the northern Sangre de Cristo Mountains. The wildfire consumed over 16,000 acres, and for a time threatened properties to the east and north, including Coaldale. Approximately 400 properties were under mandatory evacuation for several days. The wildfire only destroyed one unoccupied structure. The estimated cost to fight the wildfire was $10.4 million.  See Inciweb for more details, Http://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/4849/ .

CZ_NAME: NORTHERN SANGRE DE CRISTO MOUNTAINS ABOVE 11000 FT
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike caused the Hayden Pass wildfire on the 8th, and the wildfire continued to smolder at the end of the month.  The wildfire was mainly on USFS wilderness land, high up in the northern Sangre de Cristo Mountains.  The wildfire consumed over 16,000 acres, and for a time threatened properties to the east and north, including Coaldale. Approximately 400 properties were under mandatory evacuation for several days.  The wildfire only destroyed one unoccupied structure.  The estimated cost to fight the wildfire was $10.4 million.  See Inciweb for more details, Http://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/4849/ .
Lightning sparked a wildfire in the Holly Shelter Game Land.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning sparked a wildfire in the Holly Shelter Game Land.  On June 20th, the fire grew rapidly on gusty northwest winds, 100 degree heat, and an ongoing severe drought.  Several homes in the Traders Neck and Castle Bay developments near Hampstead were evacuated briefly, but no structures were damaged.  The fire grew to over 31,000 acres in the undeveloped Holly Shelter swamp, and continued to burn into July.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In June, lightning sparked a wildfire in the Holly Shelter Game Land.  The fire continued burning into July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Juniper Road wildfire continued to burn into July.  With the aid of significant rains on July 24-26th, the fire was 95% contained when command was transferred to a local Incident Management Team on July 31st.  The fire burned a total of 31,140 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A person burning debris started a wildfire in Hampstead, beginning near 348 Cross Creek Drive.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire burned 450 to 500 acres between Cross Creek Drive and Hoover Road. There were no structures damaged except a bridge on a logging road.  Eight plows and seven aircraft were assigned to the fire that spread quickly and took hours to get under control.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Debris caught on fire near the Holly Shelter Gameland.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On a very dry and windy day, debris caught fire in a wooded area near the Holly Shelter Gameland.  The fire did not burn any structures, but it did burn 1533 acres.  Total estimated cost to suppress the fire was $45,500.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very dry, hot, and breezy conditions, along with extremely dry fuels as a result of the long-term drought the region has experienced, promoted the rapid spread of a wildfire near Gravette and Maysville on the 5th. The fire burned two chicken houses, a barn and a vehicle. One of the fireman fighting the fire was transported to a local hospital with heat exhaustion. Local fire departments, Arkansas State Forestry, and the National Guard battled this wildfire that burned at least 900 acres before it was controlled.
Low relative humidity values in combination with hot temperatures in advance of a cold front, contributed to the spread of a wildfire in southeast Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Forest Service official reported that a wildfire had consumed 350 acres of land, 3 miles south-southwest of Walthourville, Georgia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm temperatures in combination with low relative humidity values and breezy conditions, resulted in conditions favorable for wildfire starts in southeast Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Georgia Forestry Commission reported that the Elim Church Road Wildfire started near Ludowici, Georgia on March 24, and burned 4035 acres prior to being contained on March 31.  The wildfire led to evacuations of the Long County State Prison, a Long County Nursing Home, and numerous residences.  Several shelters were set up for those forced to evacuate.  The wildfire also resulted in the temporary closure of Highway 84 from near Jesup, Georgia to Elim Church Road near Ludowici, Georgia, the temporary closure of Long County Schools, as well as the destruction of 10 structures, 3 of which were occupied homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire quickly spread near Gum Branch in Long county Georgia under hot and dry conditions. Near critical relative humidity and dry fuels allowed the fire to continue for about 24 hours before it was contained.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An emergency manager and the Georgia Forestry Commission reported a wildfire approximately 600 acres large.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low relative humidity values and breezy northeast winds in the wake of a cold front, contributed to the spread of a wildfire in southeast Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Georgia Forestry commission reported that a wildfire had consumed 750 acres of land, 1 mile west-southwest of Ludowici, Georgia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ambient temperatures near 107 degrees, relative humidity values near 20 percent and drought conditions were the ingredients needed for a grass fire which quickly burned out of control across Bowie County during the afternoon of August 6th.  The wildfire...while only 50 acres in size, consumed two homes, a barn and a storage building.  The fire started near County Road 2148.  The United States Forest Service used helicopters to drop large containers of water on the fire.

Very breezy conditions, warm temperatures and low humidity values were the ingredients needed for the rapid spread of a wildfire in Bowie County, Texas near the town of Dekalb.  The fire was reportedly started by the use of a cutting torch near a heavily wooded area near Hwy. 259 and C.R. 2735.  Strong winds caused the fire to spread rapidly with near 1000 acres of timberland and grassland consumed.  Ten separate fire departments were called in to battle the blaze.  There were reports of injuries to Texas Forest Service personnel who were burned while battling the fire.

Strong sustained winds and wind gusts, in association with Tropical Storm Lee which made landfall across the south central and southeast Louisiana gulf coast, were felt across all of Northeast Texas on September 4th and 5th.  These winds, along with very low humidity values and exceptional drought conditions across Northeast Texas, resulted in critical wildfire threat being met across the region.   A wildfire began in Bowie County on September 5th near Simms, Texas.  It was determined that this fire was started by an electrical line.  This fire, while small in size, threatened 3 structures and burned one barn.  Agencies on the scene included Fire Departments from Simms, Dekalb, New Boston, Maud.  The Red Cross was on the scene along with the Bowie County Sheriff's Office and the Red River Army Depot Fire Department.  The fire only burned 50 acres near County Road 4239 and was contained on the same day.

Strong winds, low humidity and drought conditions across Northeast Texas were all the ingredients needed for a critical wildfire threat across the region.  A wildfire began near Maud and Douglassville, Texas on September 11th.  This fire consumed 160 acres of timberland and threatened several homes near the two communities.  Two brush trucks, and one tender truck was called into help fight the blaze including Fire Departments from Douglassville, Marietta, Bryans Mill and Naples.  Three plows were needed as well as one helicpoter and one plane.

Excessive heat and severe drought conditions were all the ingredients needed to cause a grass fire to get out of control in Bowie County.  In the Wake Village community, a local family are counting their losses after a brush fire burned up more than 10 acres of family-owned land.  Two homes were consumed by the flames. |No family living in the area was harmed by the fire, but the loss of a special collection has led to some heavy hearts.  The fire destroyed a classic car collection owned by a local family in which 30 cars were destroyed.  The value of the cars were estimated at $150,000.  Two firefighters suffered heat exhaustion while trying to battle the fire.

Ambient temperatures near 110 degrees, very low relative humidity values, winds near 10 mph with higher gusts and drought conditions were the ingredients needed for a very large grass fire across Titus County in Northeast Texas.  The fire, nearly 1058 acres in size, was located near the community of Talco, Texas.  The Forest Service was called in to help control the fire.  The fire threatened 17 homes and 75 outbuildings but only one small building was lost.  One fire fighter was taken to a local hospital because of heat exhaustion.  A heavy helicopter was brought in to drop water on the fire.

Arsonist started three separate fires in the Mark Twain National Forest which merged into one massive wildfire which burned 5000 acres in southern Dent County. Dry and windy conditions along with abundant fuel on the ground helped contribute to increased intensity and extreme fire behavior.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Arsonist started three separate fires in the Mark Twain National Forest which merged into one massive wildfire which burned 5000 acres in southern Dent county. Dry and windy conditions along with abundant fuel on the ground helped contribute to increased intensity and extreme fire behavior. No homes or structures were damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dry cold front passed through on the evening of the 18th. Strong westerly winds combined with low relative humidity and low fuel moisture to cause the development of wildfires across portions of Maryland.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire over 100 acres in size was reported near Laurel Maryland. Smoke from the fire caused the closure of Interstate 95 in both directions just south of Route 198. Many motorists complained of irritated and itchy eyes. Visibility was reduced due to the smoke.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous wildfires were reported in at least 5 counties in northwest Iowa during the four day period. Warm and dry weather, strong winds, and dry vegetation due to extended dry weather preceding this time contributed to the fires starting and spreading. The fires affected grassland and cropland, including baled hay.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous fires damaged grassland and crops. The fires were all small, with the most fires reported on Thursday October 6th. The amount of crop damage was not known.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous wildfires were reported in at least 5 counties in northwest Iowa during the four day period. Warm and dry weather, strong winds, and dry vegetation due to extended dry weather preceding this time contributed to the fires starting and spreading. The fires affected grassland and cropland, including baled hay.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous fires damaged grassland and crops. The fires were all small, with the most fires reported on Thursday October 6th. The amount of crop damage was not known.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous wildfires broke out in northwest Iowa during the late morning and afternoon of September 29th. The fires started and spread under conditions of strong winds, low relative humidity, and dry vegetation due to a preceding extended period of dry weather. The fires affected grassland and crops. Two fires destroyed buildings on farmsteads, in one case killing cattle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At least 3 wildfires consumed several acres each of grass and cropland in the eastern part of the county. The largest fire, east of Hartley, spread to a farmstead and destroyed a home and a pickup truck, then spread across the county line into Clay County near State Highway 18. The amount of crop damage from the fires was not known.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several farm fires and grass fires were reported during the afternoon in Osceola, O'Brien, Clay, and Buena Vista Counties under very dry conditions and strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous farm and grass fires were reported in the county, especially near Hartley where the local fire department received many calls. Very dry vegetation and weather contributed to the starting of the fires, and strong winds resulted in the fires sustaining and spreading. Some of the fires were started by combines during harvest, until official requests were issued to stop harvesting until winds decreased.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire started near the Appling-Wayne county line on March 24th. A period of dry and warm conditions promoted fire growth.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire developed about 10 miles SSE of Surrency in Appling County. Around 5 pm EDT, a broadcast station in Savannah relayed that the fire was about 200 acres big and had destroyed 1 home and 2 barns. The cost of damage was estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Mary Field Plantation wildfire was in Waverly, and on the 25th it had burned about 2,500 acres. The fire was mostly in marsh or old rice fields. At the time, it was about 20 percent contained. Three homes were threatened. ||On the 27th, the fire was still about 2,500 acres large and only 20 percent contained. ||Early on the 29th, the fire was southwest of Kingsland and still had burned about 2,500 acres. The fire was 85 percent contained and continued in mainly marsh areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mary Field Plantation wildfire was in Waverly, and on the 25th it had burned about 2,500 acres. The fire was mostly in marsh or old rice fields. At the time, it was about 20 percent contained. Three homes were threatened.||On the 27th, the fire was still about 2,500 acres large and only 20 percent contained.||Early on the 29th, the fire was southwest of Kingsland and still had burned about 2,500 acres. The fire was 85 percent contained and continued in mainly marsh areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong wind, low relative humidities, warm temperatures, and dormant vegetation promoted the spread of wildfire on the 20th. Around 70 wildfires were reported this day across eastern Oklahoma burning more than 4000 acres. Some of the larger wildfires occurred in Pittsburg, Latimer, Haskell, Adair, and Pushmataha Counties. ||Local fire departments along with Oklahoma Forestry Services, the Bureau of Indian Affairs and the Oklahoma Army National Guard battled those blazes, many of which threatened structures. Several outbuildings were burned but no homes were lost.

Very dry, hot, and breezy conditions, along with extremely dry fuels as a result of the long-term drought the region has experienced, promoted the rapid spread of a wildfire in southern Adair County on the 4th. This fire burned about 400 acres before being extinguished by multiple fire departments and Oklahoma Forestry Services units.

Hot temperatures, low relative humidity, and gusty wind resulted in the spread of two large wildfires in Adair County. State and local agencies responded to these wildfires, which burned more than 400 acres.

Unseasonably warm temperatures, strong gusty wind, low relative humidity, and very dry vegetation promoted the rapid spread of several wildfires in eastern Oklahoma on the 17th. The largest fires were in Haskell and Adair Counties, where fires burned about 300 acres each before they were contained. Other notable fires were in Sequoyah and Cherokee Counties, where fires burned about 150 acres. None of these fires damaged any property. The fires were contained on the 18th.

Unseasonably warm temperatures, low relative humidity, and strong and gusty southerly wind combined with drought-stricken, dormant vegetation to promote the rapid spread of a number of wildfires across eastern Oklahoma on the 30th and 31st. The largest wildfires occurred in Choctaw and Pushmataha Counties, where over 300 acres were burned. A wildfire also consumed over 150 acres in Adair County.

Unseasonably warm temperatures, very low relative humidity, and gusty wind combined with drought-stricken, dormant vegetation to promote the rapid spread of a number of wildfires across eastern Oklahoma on the 30th and 31st of January 2017. The largest wildfires occurred in Haskell and Latimer Counties, where more than 400 acres were burned in each county. A large wildfire also occurred in Adair County.

Unseasonably warm temperatures, very low relative humidity, and gusty wind combined with drought-stricken, dormant vegetation to promote the rapid spread of a number of wildfires across eastern Oklahoma during early March 2017. The largest wildfires occurred in Pittsburg County where over 1600 acres burned, Muskogee County where over 1400 acres burned, Le Flore County where over 1200 acres burned, Creek County where over 800 acres burned, Sequoyah and Adair Counties where over 400 acres burned, Delaware County where over 300 acres burned, and Cherokee County where over 200 acres burned.

Unseasonably warm temperatures, very low relative humidity, and gusty wind combined with drought-stricken, dormant vegetation to promote the rapid spread of a number of wildfires across eastern Oklahoma during late March 2017. The largest wildfires occurred in Cherokee County where over 5000 acres burned, Adair County where over 2200 acres burned, Pittsburg and Sequoyah Counties where over 1000 acres burned, Delaware County where over 600 acres burned, and Latimer County where over 500 acres burned.

Unseasonably warm temperatures, very low relative humidity, and gusty wind combined with drought-stricken, dormant vegetation to promote the rapid spread of a number of wildfires across eastern Oklahoma during early February 2017. The largest wildfires occurred in Haskell County where over 5200 acres burned, Latimer County where more than 1800 acres burned, Le Flore County where over 1400 acres burned, Pittsburg County where over 700 acres burned, and Adair County where over 300 acres burned. These fires burned for a number of days before they were contained.

Gusty wind, low relative humidity, and unseasonably warm conditions combined with dry and dormant vegetation to promote the rapid spread of wildfire on March 4th through the 8th across eastern Oklahoma. More than 1000 acres burned in Pittsburg County, more than 900 acres burned in Latimer County, more than 600 acres burned in Cherokee and Delaware Counties, more than 500 acres burned in Haskell County, and more than 200 acres burned in Le Flore, Pushmataha, and Adair Counties during that several day period.
A wildfire in eastern Comanche County burned 700 acres, and one north of Cisco in Eastland County burned 500 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire between Comanche and Dublin, in the far eastern portions of Comanche County, burned approximately 700 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm temperatures in combination with low relative humidity values, resulted in conditions favorable for wildfire starts in southern South Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The South Carolina Forestry Commission reported a 125 acre wildfire near Pineland Estates Road and Zig Zag Road, 3 miles northeast of Pineland, South Carolina.  The fire reportedly involved one home and a shed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm temperatures in combination with low relative humidity values, resulted in conditions favorable for wildfire starts in southern South Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The South Carolina Forestry Commission reported a 160 acre wildfire 9 miles north-northeast of Hardeeville, South Carolina.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several large wildfires developed due to very dry conditions and gusty winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire consumed around 500 acres of grass and light woodlands near the town of Lawton.  A camper was reported as consumed during the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Windy and dry conditions combined with plentiful and very dry fuels resulted in wildfires across West Central Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This wildfire originated after a controlled burn went out of control.  Multiple agencies fought this fire that began on February 15.  The wildfire burned approximately 2000 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This wildfire was ignited by lightning about 14 miles northwest of Sweetwater.  Once the fire was ignited, it was fueled by critical fire weather conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thirty-two homes, oil infrastructure and wind turbines were threatened on this lightning-caused fire 13 miles northwest of Sweetwater. Two structures were lost but the type of structures were unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A grassland wildfire developed as a result of very dry, warm air and plentiful fuels.
Plenty of fuels, dry air, and wind created ideal conditions for wildfires for late July.  Also, an isolated thunderstorm produced a few lightning strikes across West Central Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Regency Fire in San Saba County burned approximately 302 acres.  It was located near Spring Creek Cemetery on County Road 133.  Several homes were threatened but were saved by firefighters.  This fire was 100 percent contained.  The times are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of dry fuels and fire weather conditions led to a large fire in San Saba County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Havelah Complex Wildfire was formed by two brush fires in hilly terrain near County Road 310, approximately 18 miles southwest of San Saba.  The burn area was estimated to be around 2079 acres.  The fire was started by lightning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several large wildfires broke out from August 19 through the 22nd.  As the rains ended in early July, hardly any rain fell through late August.  Plenty of the vegetation that blossomed from the wet spring, quickly dried, and fueled the wildfires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Log Cabin Wildfire started from a vehicle driving in tall grass approximately 14 miles south of Richland Springs or about 10 miles north of Pontotoc.  The fire burned roughly 3400 acres and 12 homes were threatened.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures and very little rain in July led to ideal wildfire conditions in August.  Two large wildfires developed in McCulloch and San Saba Counties as dried fuels were in abundance from the spring rains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Brady Mountain Wildfire began on August 14 and was 100 percent contained on August 16.  This fire burned 1357 acres in southwest San Saba County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first of two upper air storm systems to impact the Southern Plains on the consecutive days of the 25th and 26th brought a localized and brief bout of high wind and contributed to three significant wildfires on the west Texas South Plains.||Critical fire weather associated with the system's passage overspread the region by late morning, and a 4,000 acre wildfire quickly spread ten miles west-northwest of Tahoka (Lynn County) around 09:00 CST.  By 13:10 CST, a brief severe wind gust up to 59 mph was recorded by the Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site near Tahoka (Lynn County).  Neither the fire nor the wind resulted in significant damage.||Additional fires ignited in grasslands immediately north of Paducah (Cottle County) and north-northeast of Tokio (Terry County) between 13:00 CST and 15:25 CST.  These fire consumed 1,500 and 300 acres respectively.  Although neither fire resulted in damages, the Paducah fire did threaten several homes before it was contained.

A surface trough across eastern New Mexico and surface high pressure across the Mississippi River Valley contributed to a tight surface pressure gradient.  This gradient allowed for strong southerly winds of 20 to 25 MPH to develop during the afternoon hours.  Relative humidity values ranged from the low teens east of the Pecos River, to the single digits west of there.  A Red Flag Warning was issued for the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A complex of fires, known as the Cannon Fire, burned 63,427 acres in Pecos County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Near record high temperatures and relative humidity values of 5 percent or less were present across the Permian Basin and Trans Pecos area.  Strong winds aloft mixed down to the surface resulting in wind speeds near 30 to 40 MPH with gusts to 50 MPH across the region.  A Red Flag Warning and a Wind Advisory were in effect.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This fire, known as the Champion Fire, burned 1,000 acres in Mitchell County.  Six homes were threatened and saved.  Three homes were destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Near record high temperatures and relative humidity values of 5 percent or less were present across the Permian Basin and Trans Pecos area.  Strong winds aloft mixed down to the surface resulting in wind speeds near 30 to 40 MPH with gusts to 50 MPH across the region.  A Red Flag Warning and a Wind Advisory were in effect.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This fire, known as the Pleasant Farms Fire, burned 4,000 acres in Ector County.  Several homes were threatened, and one home was destroyed.  This fire eventually merged with the C-Bar fire in Crane County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low relative humidity values combined with breezy southwest surface winds above 20 mph to produce critical fire weather conditions across the Permian Basin of Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Named the Bate's Field Fire, this fire burned 3200 acres and threatened 300 homes, a power plant and a water treatment plant.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Critical Fire Weather Conditions occurred on April 25 across much of West Central Texas as a dryline brought southwest to west winds of 20 to 25 mph, relative humidity levels below 20 percent, and temperatures in the 90s.  Isolated thunderstorms ignited a large wildfire in Kimble County on April 26.  A few of these fires continued through the end of April.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Oasis Pipeline Fire 11 miles south of Junction burned approximately 9445 acres and it was 80 percent contained.  There were 11 structures destroyed, including 1 home. Also, 3 vehicles and 1 bulldozer were destroyed, along with numerous power poles and fence line. In addition, 20 head of cattle were lost.  Commercial airtankers and four MAFFs tankers helped slow the spread of the fire that came within four miles south of  Junction.  This fire was started by lightning on April 26.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Plenty of fuels, extremely dry and hot weather and breezy north winds caused by Tropical Storm Lee produced near critical fire weather conditions in late August.  The stronger winds resulted in larger wildfires across parts of West Central Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Big Draw Wildfire continued into September.  This fire had 50 foot flame lengths and short distance spotting early in its lifetime.  Numerous volunteer fire departments responded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Critical Fire Weather Conditions occurred on April 25 across much of West Central Texas as a dryline brought southwest to west winds of 20 to 25 mph, relative humidity levels below 20 percent, and temperatures in the 90s. Isolated thunderstorms ignited a large wildfire in Kimble County on April 26 called the Oasis Pipeline Wildfire. This wildfire continued into the month of May.  The Scott Ranch Wildfire near Barnhart Texas also continued from late April into early May.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Oasis Pipeline Fire 11 miles south of Junction burned approximately 9445 acres and it was 100 percent contained by midnight on May 10. There were 11 structures destroyed, including 1 home. Also, 3 vehicles and 1 bulldozer were destroyed, along with numerous power poles and fence line. In addition, 20 head of cattle were lost. Commercial airtankers and four MAFFs tankers helped slow the spread of the fire that came within four miles south of Junction. This fire was started by lightning on April 26.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few wildfires that started in late August continued into early September.  The combination of hot temperatures, the availability of fuels, and winds created the conditions for these fires to either continue or develop.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 400 acre Cedar Truck Wildfire Complex consisted of more than 34 different fire starts across portions of Kimble County in late August.  One secondary structure was lost in this complex.  The fire complex was 100 percent contained.  The Cedar Truck Complex, apparently named for the vehicle that sparked 34 separate fires while driving along a 24-mile stretch of highway. Firefighters saved 13 homes threatened by the fire complex, which was burning just west of Fort McKavett.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of hot temperatures, abundant fuels, and very little rain in July, created ideal fire weather conditions.  Because of these conditions, a large wildfire was able to expand across Kimble County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The KC1121 Wildfire developed as a prescribed burn went out of control about 10 miles east of Telegraph.  As of 8PM CDT on August 2nd, about 200 acres had burned.  On the morning of August 4, the wildfire expanded to an estimated 675 acres.  The wildfire was extinguished by August 7.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Critical Fire Weather Conditions occurred on April 25 across much of West Central Texas as a dryline brought southwest to west winds of 20 to 25 mph, relative humidity levels below 20 percent, and temperatures in the 90s.  Isolated thunderstorms ignited a large wildfire in Kimble County on April 26.  A few of these fires continued through the end of April.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Taylor Fire located 6 miles east of Eden burned 654 acres. Seven fire departments responed to this brush and grass fire. The fire is 100 percent contained.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures and very little rain in July led to ideal wildfire conditions in August.  A large wildfire developed in northeast Concho County as dried fuels were in abundance from the spring rains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Horse Creek Ranch Wildfire burned about 6623 acres in northeastern Concho County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds and falling humidity behind a cold front were blamed for either causing or aggravating wildfires that broke out in several North Carolina counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wildfires near Ruffin in Rockingham County required every fire department in the county to be called out. Winds at Rockingham County Airport (KSIF) AWOS gusted as high as 38 mph during the afternoon and relative humidity fell to under 15 percent for several hours. Several barns and other structures were burned.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong south winds fanned the flames of a fast-moving field fire that threatened at least 20 homes on the eastern edge of West Frankfort. The fire burned about 100 acres of land that was formerly on a coal mine. Five residences were temporarily evacuated as flame heights reached about 20 feet. About a dozen local fire departments along with the U.S. Forest Service battled the blaze. Illinois Route 149 was shut down for a while in case the fire jumped the roadway.
Dry, west winds of 20 MPH or greater were present west of a dryline aiding in minimum relative humidity values from 10 to 15 percent.  A  Red Flag Warning was in effect for the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This fire, known as the Price Fire, burned 3,373 acres in Glasscock County.  Fifty pump jacks, twelve or more tank batteries, and one home were threatened and saved.  Miles of polypipe and utility poles were burned.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire in Kendall County between Boerne and Comfort was spread by southerly winds that gusted between 25 and 30 mph. Temperatures were near 100 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Green Cedar fire burned 140 acres including an RV park on Interstate 10. One structure and seven recreational vehicles were destroyed by the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm temperatures in combination with breezy southwesterly winds, resulted in conditions favorable for wildfire starts in southern South Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The South Carolina Forestry Commission reported that a wildfire burned 100 acres near Walterboro, South Carolina.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ambient temperatures in excess of 100 degrees across Southeast Oklahoma, very low relative humidity values, drought conditions and strong northeasterly winds in association with Tropical Storm Lee making landfall in south central Louisiana were all the ingredients needed for critical wildfire danger across the region.  A wildfire started near Broken Bow, Oklahoma during the morning of September 2nd and was not contained until the morning of September 5th.  The fire consumed 446 acres of timberland and grassland in McCurtain County, Oklahoma.  There were no reports of structures burned.

Very warm temperatures, low humidity values and drought conditions were the ingredients needed for the rapid spread of a wildfire that started near the Fomby community, south of Millwood Lake Dam in Little River County, Arkansas.  This fire consumed 124 acres of timberland and grassland before it was contained.

Warm temperatures, very low relative humidity and near drought conditions were the ingredients needed for the development of a wildfire in Little River County, Arkansas, approximately 4 miles northwest of Foreman, Arkansas.  The fire destroyed 112 acres of timberland and grassland before it was contained.

Strong sustained winds and wind gusts, in association with Tropical Storm Lee which made landfall across the south central and southeast Louisiana gulf coast, were felt across all of Northeast Texas on September 4th and 5th. These winds, along with very low humidity values and exceptional drought conditions across Northeast Texas, resulted in critical wildfire threat being met across the region.  A wildfire began in Upshur County 8 miles north northwest of Gilmer, Texas.  This fire was called the Toad Road Fire.  It began on September 5th and was not contained until September 8th.  The fire consumed 388 acres of timberland and grassland off Llama Road and Lizard Road.  The fire spread across County Road 2454 and consumed 3 homes before it was contained.

Strong winds, low humidity and drought conditions across Northeast Texas were all the ingredients needed for a critical wildfire threat across the region.  A wildfire began on September 13th near the Rhonesboro community west of Gilmer, Texas.  This fire consumed 350 acres of timberland and grassland and consumed 15 structures including 12 homes.  Numerous evacuations were made with shelters having to be set up in Gilmer, Texas.  The fire started on FM. 1002 and near Hwy. 154.  More than 10 fire departments were called in to help battle the wildfire with total containment declared on September 15th.

Strong sustained winds and wind gusts, in association with Tropical Storm Lee which made landfall across the south central and southeast Louisiana gulf coast, were felt across all of Northeast Texas on September 4th. These winds, along with very low humidity values and exceptional drought conditions across Northeast Texas, resulted in critical wildfire threat being met across the region.  A wildfire began on September 4th, 8 miles northeast of Gilmer, Texas in what was called the Clemanis Fire.  The fire consumed more than 500 acres of timberland and grassland before it was contained on September 7th.  There were no reports of any structures consumed in the fire.

Strong sustained winds and wind gusts, in association with Tropical Storm Lee which made landfall across the south central and southeast Louisiana gulf coast, were felt across all of Northeast Texas on September 4th. These winds, along with very low humidity values and exceptional drought conditions across Northeast Texas, resulted in critical wildfire threat being met across the region.  A wildfire, which became known as the Diana Fire, began 4 miles west of Diana, Texas on September 4th.  The fire consumed 2324 acres of timberland and grassland until it was contained on September 17th.  A total of 692 homes were evacuated with 3 homes consumed and 5 outbuildings.  There was one injury to a firefighter while fighting the blaze.

Strong sustained winds and wind gusts, in association with Tropical Storm Lee which made landfall across the south central and southeast Louisiana gulf coast, were felt across all of Northeast Texas on September 4th.  These winds, along with very low humidity values and exceptional drought conditions across Northeast Texas, resulted in critical wildfire threat being met across the region.  A wildfire, known as the Old Magnolia Complex, began in Gregg County on September 4th and was not completely contained until September 17th.  The fire burned 4,909 acres with numerous agencies called in to battle the wildfire.  Evacuation orders were made with the American Red Cross setting up shelters for the evacuees in Jefferson, Texas.  Three vehicles were burned as well as one business.  Two helicopters were called in to make water bucket drops and four Single Engine Air Tankers (SEAT's) made several retardant drops.

Strong sustained winds and wind gusts, in association with Tropical Storm Lee which made landfall across the south central and southeast Louisiana gulf coast, were felt across all of Northeast Texas on September 4th. These winds, along with very low humidity values and exceptional drought conditions across Northeast Texas, resulted in critical wildfire threat being met across the region.  A wildfire, which became known as the Moore Fire, began 4 miles southwest of Gladewater consuming 1556 acres of timberland and grassland near Hwy. 135.  Twenty homes were destroyed along with 15 outbuildings.  A 20 year old woman and her 18 month old daughter died in a house fire on Lincoln Springs Road off Old Gladewater Road.  One man was in the home and escaped with minor burns.  One firefighter was injured when a tree fell over on him.  The fire was not contained until September 13th.

The Bastrop County Complex Wildfire started on September 4 behind Tropical Storm Lee and a cold front that brought strong northerly winds. The peak wind at Austin Bergstrom International Airport was 36 mph. The fire was not completely contained at the end of the month and had burned 34,068 acres. It destroyed 1669 homes and 40 commercial buildings. Two people were killed by the fire. This fire destroyed more homes than any other single fire in Texas history. These totals include the acreage and destruction from the Union Chapel fire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bastrop County Complex Wildfire started on September 4 behind Tropical Storm Lee and a cold front that brought strong northerly winds. The peak wind at Austin Bergstrom International Airport was 36 mph. The fire was not completely contained at the end of the month and had burned 34,068 acres. It destroyed 1669 homes and 40 commercial buildings. Two people were killed by the fire. This fire destroyed more homes than any other single fire in Texas history. These totals include the acreage and destruction from the Union Chapel fire.  The fire started in two separate locations just to the north of the city of Bastrop and quickly grew to one fire, destroying much of the Bastrop State Park.  Investigation concluded that the fire started as a result of downed powerlines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Hidden Pines wildfire started on October 13 near Buescher State Park north of Smithville. The fire eventually consumed 4,582 acres before being contained on October 24. One hundred forty-three (143) homes were threatened and 64 were destroyed, two were damaged, and 77 were saved. Twenty-two (22) commercial properties were threatened and seven were destroyed and 15 were saved. Two hundred-thirteen (213) outbuildings were threatened and 70 were destroyed and 143 were saved. One hundred thirty-seven (137) vehicles were threatened with 69 destroyed and 68 saved. Twenty-one (21) recreational vehicles (RVs) were threatened and five were destroyed and 16 were saved. Four hundred (400) homes were evacuated during the course of the fire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Hidden Pines wildfire started on October 13 near Buescher State Park north of Smithville. The fire eventually consumed 4,582 acres before being contained on October 24. One hundred forty-three (143) homes were threatened and 64 were destroyed, two were damaged, and 77 were saved. Twenty-two (22) commercial properties were threatened and seven were destroyed and 15 were saved. Two hundred-thirteen (213) outbuildings were threatened and 70 were destroyed and 143 were saved. One hundred thirty-seven (137) vehicles were threatened with 69 destroyed and 68 saved. Twenty-one (21) recreational vehicles (RVs) were threatened and five were destroyed and 16 were saved. Four hundred (400) homes were evacuated during the course of the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fire began in Lincoln County when a combine ignited the fire while harvesting soybeans. A Red Flag Warning was in effect where strong winds helped spread the fire quickly and burning an estimated 40 square miles of acres that encompassed corn and soybean crops. A home and barn, along with a number of farm machinery damaged or destroyed as the fire spread from northern Lincoln County into Logan County to near the town of Stapleton. As the fire approached the city emergency crews closed Highway 83 and a mandatory evacuation of the community. One landowner was hospitalized due to inhalation as fire crews worked through the night to control hot spots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A fire began in Lincoln County when a combine ignited the fire while harvesting soybeans. A Red Flag Warning was in effect where strong winds helped spread the fire quickly and burning an estimated 40 square miles of acres that encompassed corn and soybean crops. A home and barn, along with a number of farm machinery damaged or destroyed as the fire spread from northern Lincoln County into Logan County to near the town of Stapleton. As the fire approached the city emergency crews closed Highway 83 and a mandatory evacuation of the community. One landowner was hospitalized due to inhalation as fire crews worked through the night to control hot spots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Pilot Knob Fire and Robinette Fire both began on August 20th, were contained on August 22nd, and finally controlled on October 11th. Both fires burned on the Fort Hood military base approximately 6 miles from each other. The Pilot Knob Fire burned a total of 1500 acres, and the Robinette Fire burned a total of 6180 acres. No damage was done by these fires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pilot Knob fire burned 1500 acres on the Fort Hood military base. This fire was located on the firing range, approximately 6 miles away from the Robinette Fire, and was started by training exercises on the range. The fire began on August 20th, was contained on August 22nd, but was not fully controlled until October 11th. No damage occurred with this fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Pilot Knob Fire and Robinette Fire both began on August 20th, were contained on August 22nd, and finally controlled on October 11th. Both fires burned on the Fort Hood military base approximately 6 miles from each other. The Pilot Knob Fire burned a total of 1500 acres, and the Robinette Fire burned a total of 6180 acres. No damage was done by these fires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Robinette Fire began on August 20th, was contained on August 22nd, but was not fully controlled until October 11th. It started near the East Range Road impact area and burned 6180 acres. This fire was located only 6 miles from the Pilot Knob Fire. No damage occurred with this fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Five grass fires in Coryell County began in the latter part of August and burned into September. The Coryell Complex, Horseshoe Bend Fire, and Jack Mountain Fire were all contained during September. The Pilot Knob Fire and Robinette Fire were not contained until October. Damage estimates for these fires can be found with their initial entries in the August Storm Data report.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Coryell Complex was a group of 11 grass fires that were accidentally started on August 28th, contained on September 1st, and fully controlled on September 14th. A total of 1635 acres burned. The largest fire burned approximately 1400 acres. Damages estimates for this complex of fires can be found with the initial entry in the August Storm Data report.

The Coryell Complex, Horseshoe Bend Fire, and Jack Mountain Fire were all contained during September. The Pilot Knob Fire and Robinette Fire were not contained until October. The fire began on August 20th, was contained on August 22nd, but was not fully controlled until October 11th. No damage occurred with this fire.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Horseshoe Bend Fire began on August 26th, was contained on September 2nd and fully controlled on September 4th. The fire burned 525 acres. Damages estimates for this fire can be found with the initial entry in the August Storm Data report.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions and above normal temperatures across the region left the area susceptible to grass fires during the early part of September. A few grass fires caused damage between the 10th and 15th. A large grass fire in Montague County burned 5000 acres and another large fire in Coryell County burned 1023 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Ireland Fire burned 1023 acres. The fire began near CR 102 and FM 932 and threatened the community of Ireland. One abandoned home was destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions and above normal temperatures across the region left the area susceptible to grass fires during the early part of September. Several small grass fires caused damage between the 6th and 9th, and on the 6th, an elderly man was killed when a grass fire spread to his mobile home. The Dam Fire in Hill County ignited on the 8th, burning 580 acres on the south side of Lake Whitney and 9 homes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Levita Fire burned 60 acres on an exotic game ranch along CR 101, approximately 3 miles west of Levita. One structure was lost in this fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Five grass fires in Coryell County began in the latter part of August and burned into September. The Coryell Complex, Horseshoe Bend Fire, and Jack Mountain Fire were all contained during September. The Pilot Knob Fire and Robinette Fire were not contained until October. Damage estimates for these fires can be found with their initial entries in the August Storm Data report.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jack Mountain Fire began on August 30th and was controlled September 14th. The fire began in the Jack Mountain impact area on Fort Hood and burned approximately 3700 acres. The fire was believed to have been started by artillery training exercises, and the only damage reported was to two power poles. Damages estimates for this fire can be found with the initial entry in the August Storm Data report.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Elevated fire weather conditions persisted for most of the month due to the extreme heat and the ongoing historic drought. Many wildfires occurred during the month burning over 40,000 acres of land, several homes, and lots of personal property. From the 26th through the 31st, there were 9 grass fires that caused damage. Most of these fires continued to burn into September. On the 30th, the 101 Fire began in Palo Pinto County near Possum Kingdom Lake. This fire burned 39 homes in the Cliffs and Gaines Bend subdivisions and another 9 recreational vehicles. In Coryell County, a 525-acre fire burned in the far eastern portions of the county, a 1635-acre fire burned near Evant, and another 3700-acre fire burned on the grounds of Fort Hood. A 400-acre fire in Wise County burned 5 homes, and a 2314-acre fire burned 3 homes in Anderson County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Coryell Complex was a group of 11 grass fires that were started approximately 4 miles southeast of Evant along US Highway 84 and FM 183. The 11 fires eventually merged into 5 fires that were managed as a complex. A vehicle towing a barbecue pit was believed to have started the fires which began on August 28th, was contained on September 1st, and fully controlled on September 14th. A total of 1635 acres burned. The largest fire burned approximately 1400 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Elevated fire weather conditions persisted for most of the month due to the extreme heat and the ongoing historic drought. Many wildfires occurred during the month burning over 40,000 acres of land, several homes, and lots of personal property. From the 16th through the 20th, there were 11 grass fires that caused damage. Two large fires were started on the Fort Hood Military Base artillery training area. A grass fire in Hunt County burned a junkyard for boats and tires, and other fires burned homes in Dallas and Tarrant counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Robinette Fire started 11 miles north-northwest of Killeen on the Fort Hood military base. It started near the East Range Road impact area and burned 6180 acres. The fire began on the 20th, was contained on the 22nd, but was not fully controlled until October 11th.

The fire was believed to have been started by artillery training exercises, and the only damage reported was to two power poles.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Horseshoe Bend Fire began on August 26th in far eastern Coryell County near the Leon River. The fire was contained on September 2nd and fully controlled on September 4th. The fire burned 525 acres. One firefighter suffered mild heat exhaustion and another suffered an ankle injury. A bulldozer owned by the Texas Forestry Service was burn in this fire.
