The fire began on the 20th, was contained on the 22nd, but was not fully controlled until October 11th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Moonglow Wildfire started in Leander on September 5 behind a cold front that brought strong northerly winds to South Central Texas. The fire burned 300 acres and destroyed 11 homes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Moonglow Wildfire started in Leander on September 5 behind a cold front that brought strong northerly winds to South Central Texas. The fire burned 300 acres and destroyed 11 homes and damaged 9 others.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and dry conditions throughout South Central Texas were perfect fuel for a quick moving grass fire in Leander that burned 30 acres.  The fire destroyed 15 mobile homes and 19 vehicles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A grassfire developed on Horseshoe Drive in Leander and quickly spread through a mobile home park.  The fire destroyed 15 mobile homes and damaged 5 others.  There were a total of 19 vehicles destroyed.  A total of 30 acres burned.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Big Oak wildfire broke out in southern Bexar County between Pleasanton Road and US Highway 281. Sixteen acres burned which destroyed 6 stuctures including 4 homes and 16 vehicles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Big Oak wildfire broke out in southern Bexar County between Pleasanton Road and US Highway 281. Sixteen acres burned which destroyed 6 stuctures including 4 homes and 16 vehicles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A brush fire in the 3100 block of Owenwood Dr. burned 40 acres and destroyed two structures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brush fire in the 3100 block of Owenwood Dr. burned 40 acres and destroyed two structures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and dry conditions across the region on the 2nd and 3rd resulted in elevated fire weather conditions. A few fires started on these days but several more fires began on the 4th and 5th behind a strong cold front. The cold front moved through the region on the 4th bringing strong and gusty north winds with it.  On the 5th, humidity values fell dangerously low. A Red Flag Warning was issued for parts of the area on the 4th and 5th. Over the holiday weekend, over two dozen wildfires ignited with several of the fires causing damage. The largest complex of fires was in Limestone County where five fires burned 7500 acres and 7 homes. The Concord-Robbins Fire in Leon County burned 31 homes and 4689 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 600-acre grass fire burned in southwest Hopkins County near the Miller Grove area. The fire began near FM 1567 and burned pastureland and woodland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions prevailed for the first half of February, when several agencies had to respond to wildfires. A few of the wildfires caused structure damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Approximately 40 acres of ranchland were burned in Hopkins County, between Brashear and Greenview. No structures were affected.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire 2.25 miles east of Holly Grove in Monroe County burned 120 acres on the 11th.

Dry conditions and above normal temperatures across the region left the area susceptible to grass fires during the early part of September. A few grass fires caused damage between the 10th and 15th. A large grass fire in Montague County burned 5000 acres and another large fire in Coryell County burned 1023 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 15-acre fire near SH 31 and Highway 175 in Athens moderately damaged 2 unoccupied mobile homes and also caused minor damage to two other occupied mobile homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions and above normal temperatures across the region left the area susceptible to grass fires during the early part of September. Several small grass fires caused damage between the 6th and 9th, and on the 6th, an elderly man was killed when a grass fire spread to his mobile home. The Dam Fire in Hill County ignited on the 8th, burning 580 acres on the south side of Lake Whitney and 9 homes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Texas DEM reported a 4-acre grass fire on FM 3062 near Malakoff burned 4 rows of storage buildings.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Texas DEM reported a 6-acre fire at FM 314 and CR 3603 south of Brownsboro damaged a structure.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: According to the Texas DEM, 8 fires erupted along Highway 31E near CR 3710 between Athens and Murchison. These fires were likely started by a travel trailer. The fires burned 100 acres and heavily damaged a barn and one other structure.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: According to the Texas DEM, a one-acre fire on CR 4343 near LaRue damaged a large shop.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An 18-acre grass fire along FM 314 south of Brownsboro heavily damaged a house. This fire was started along the roadway from a discarded cigarette. The fire was quickly contained on the 3rd but not fully controlled until the 14th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 1-acre fire in a subdivision near Farm to Market 753 and County Road 1111 burned a storage structure. The location is approximately 6 miles southwest of Athens.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 10 acre grass fire on CR 2804 near Eustace damaged a barn.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 10 acre grass fire on CR 2804 near Eustace damaged a barn. The fire started as a controlled burn but grew out of control.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures well above 100 degrees, drought conditions and low afternoon relative humidity resulted in a wildfire in Nevada County, Arkansas during the afternoon of August 22nd. This fire consumed 129 acres of grass and timberland.  There were no reports of structures burned or injuries with this fire.

As the temperatures rose across north Texas, so did the threat for wildfires and the wildfire activity increased beginning around the middle of the month. Six significant wildfires occurred between the 17th and 20th with five of the six fires causing damage. One large fire along the Dallas/Ellis county line destroyed a home and damaged 12 others.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 230 acre blaze burned from approximately Waxahachie in Ellis County to DeSoto in Dallas County. In Ellis County, one home and 5 vehicles were destroyed and 12 other homes were damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Elevated fire weather conditions persisted for most of the month due to the extreme heat and the ongoing historic drought. Many wildfires occurred during the month burning over 40,000 acres of land, several homes, and lots of personal property. From the 16th through the 20th, there were 11 grass fires that caused damage. Two large fires were started on the Fort Hood Military Base artillery training area. A grass fire in Hunt County burned a junkyard for boats and tires, and other fires burned homes in Dallas and Tarrant counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A grass fire damaged a group of vacant manufactured homes off Jimmy Lane in Combine. One home was destroyed and five others were badly damaged. Only one of the homes was occupied at the time. A few vehicles and some sheds were also burned in the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions prevailed for the first half of February, when several agencies had to respond to wildfires. A few of the wildfires caused structure damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A fire began in the 15000 block of Budeudy, in unincorporated Dallas County. The fire began at the location of two mobile homes, and quickly spread to consume approximately ten acres. In addition to two mobile homes, one storage shed was impacted as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 5-acre grass fire in Robertson County destroyed 3 abandoned structures and damaged 1 other structure. Very hot and dry conditions this month resulted in elevated fire danger.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A grass fire near Pump Station Road and Highway 79 burned 5 acres. The fire destroyed 3 abandoned structures and damaged 1 other structure.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions and above normal temperatures across the region left the area susceptible to grass fires during the early part of September. Several small grass fires caused damage between the 6th and 9th, and on the 6th, an elderly man was killed when a grass fire spread to his mobile home. The Dam Fire in Hill County ignited on the 8th, burning 580 acres on the south side of Lake Whitney and 9 homes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Texas DEM reported a 70-80 acre fire at J.W. Martine Road near US Highway 79 in the Elliott community burned 20 round bales of hay and a full hay barn.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Elevated fire weather conditions persisted for most of the month due to the extreme heat and the ongoing historic drought. Many wildfires occurred during the month burning over 40,000 acres of land, several homes, and lots of personal property. From the 16th through the 20th, there were 11 grass fires that caused damage. Two large fires were started on the Fort Hood Military Base artillery training area. A grass fire in Hunt County burned a junkyard for boats and tires, and other fires burned homes in Dallas and Tarrant counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A half acre grass fire near FM 979 in Calvert burned two abandoned houses.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A continued heat wave and drought conditions made conditions favorable for wildfires during the first part of August. The Forked Mountain Fire began on the 7th in the Ouachita National Forest. The fire, in Perry County, eventually burned 180 acres.
Very dry weather and a heat wave made conditions very favorable for wildfires in late July. A wildfire 8 miles southwest of Hollis in Perry County burned 215 acres on the 30th.
The Round Mountain Fire began on the 24th about 3 miles southeast of Williams Junction in Perry County and burned into Saline County before being controlled on the 25th. Altogether, 330 acres burned.

The Casa Fire was started by lightning 2 miles northwest of Casa in Perry County on the 13th and continued until the 15th. Altogether, 820 acres burned. A house, some outbuildings, a boat, and several vehicles were lost in the fire. A portion of Arkansas 155 was closed during the fire. At the height of the fire, homes in the town of Casa were evacuated, as well as homes in the communities of Homewood and Rose Creek. Yell and Conway counties assisted Perry County with the evacuations.
A continued heat wave and drought conditions made conditions favorable for wildfires during the first part of August. A wildfire near Kingsland burned 129 acres in Cleveland County on the 8th.
Seasonably warm and dry conditions help produce conditons suitable for wildfire growth and development.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A several acre area of burning grassland and slough produced a pyrocumulus cloud and brief fire whirls.  One of the fire whirls and its associated rotating updraft plume  briefly extended as a contiguous vortex from near the surface to the cloud base, constituting a very weak and non-damaging fire tornado.  the fire whirl was located about 5 miles north of the community of Loma.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry weather, low humidities, and gusty winds made conditions favorable for wildfires in early September. A wildfire near the Pope/Conway County line west of Jerusalem burned 107 acres on the 4th and 5th.

The Clinton Fire began near Cleveland in Conway County and eventually spread into Van Buren County. The fire burned 110 acres. Three firefighters were treated for heat exhaustion. At least five fire departments and the Arkansas Forestry Commission fought the fire.
The Claude Schoolhouse Fire 10 miles southwest of Clinton on the 28th burned a total of 300 acres in Van Buren and Conway counties.
The Lutherhill wildfire started on September 5 behind a cold front that brought strong northerly winds. The fire burned until September 9 and consumed 2700 acres. The fire destroyed 14 homes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lutherhill wildfire started on September 5 behind a cold front that brought strong northerly winds. The fire burned until September 9 and consumed 2700 acres. The fire destroyed 14 homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A volunteer firefighter was badly burned fighting a large grass fire on Tobias Rd. near Cordes Rd. in Ellinger on March 10th. He died on March 23rd from his injuries at a hospital in San Antonio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A volunteer firefighter was badly burned fighting a large grass fire on Tobias Rd. near Cordes Rd. in Ellinger on March 10th. He died from his injuries on March 23rd at a hospital in San Antonio.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and dry conditions across the region on the 2nd and 3rd resulted in elevated fire weather conditions. A few fires started on these days but several more fires began on the 4th and 5th behind a strong cold front. The cold front moved through the region on the 4th bringing strong and gusty north winds with it.  On the 5th, humidity values fell dangerously low. A Red Flag Warning was issued for parts of the area on the 4th and 5th. Over the holiday weekend, over two dozen wildfires ignited with several of the fires causing damage. The largest complex of fires was in Limestone County where five fires burned 7500 acres and 7 homes. The Concord-Robbins Fire in Leon County burned 31 homes and 4689 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 3000-acre fire in western Limestone County began approximately 20 miles east of Waco. This fire burned one home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and dry conditions across the region on the 2nd and 3rd resulted in elevated fire weather conditions. A few fires started on these days but several more fires began on the 4th and 5th behind a strong cold front. The cold front moved through the region on the 4th bringing strong and gusty north winds with it.  On the 5th, humidity values fell dangerously low. A Red Flag Warning was issued for parts of the area on the 4th and 5th. Over the holiday weekend, over two dozen wildfires ignited with several of the fires causing damage. The largest complex of fires was in Limestone County where five fires burned 7500 acres and 7 homes. The Concord-Robbins Fire in Leon County burned 31 homes and 4689 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Prairie Hill Fire burned 3000 acres around the community of Prairie Hill. This fire was started by downed power lines. The fire was contained on the 4th but not fully controlled until the 14th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions and above normal temperatures across the region left the area susceptible to grass fires during the early part of September. Several small grass fires caused damage between the 6th and 9th, and on the 6th, an elderly man was killed when a grass fire spread to his mobile home. The Dam Fire in Hill County ignited on the 8th, burning 580 acres on the south side of Lake Whitney and 9 homes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Dam Fire on the south edge of Lake Whitney burned 580 acres near the Hill/Bosque County line. Nine homes and 25 outbuildings were lost in the fire. This fire began on the roadside next to SH 22 but the cause was unknown. One firefighter was treated for smoke inhalation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions prevailed for the first half of February, when several agencies had to respond to wildfires. A few of the wildfires caused structure damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A grass fire began near the city of Itasca, between Hill County road 4228 and State Highway 81. This fire damaged farm and ranch land, but no structure damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire originated in Juneberry 3 Township of Roseau County, Minnesota, on the afternoon of the 5th. Strong winds on the 6th and 7th helped spread the wildfire into large and dangerous proportions. By the time the fire was contained, it had affected a good portion of the western quarter of Roseau County. The fire burned about 56 square miles, or 36,000 acres. Most of the area burned was grassland on various wildlife management areas.

Elevated fire weather conditions persisted for most of the month due to the extreme heat and the ongoing historic drought. Many wildfires occurred during the month burning over 40,000 acres of land, several homes, and lots of personal property. From the 6th through the 10th, there were 5 grass fires that caused damage. The largest and most damaging of these fires was the 7328-acre Cherry Homes Fire in northern Jack County. A 3840-acre fire also occurred in northern Grayson County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 500-acre fire started near West Moonlight Drive and Losik Road in Robinson. The fire forced the closure of the northbound lane of I-35 but otherwise no structures were damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front that was moving across the region. These thunderstorms produced mostly wind damage across the eastern half of the CWA. The most significant damage was reported in Collin County where a mobile home was rolled onto its top. In addition to the thunderstorm winds, very strong winds behind the front continued into the following day. Sustained winds of 20 to 30 mph were common with wind gusts over 50 mph in some locations. These winds caused many power outages across the region and some additional minor damage. Also, the strong winds fueled 2 grass fires which caused some property damage in Bell and McLennan Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds fueled a grass fire which spread to a mobile home in the town of Gholson. The home was destroyed and one resident suffered smoke inhalation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry vegetation resulting from summer drought across north and central Texas led to a few grass fires across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A grass and brush fire burned approximately 150 acres about half a mile west of New Dallas Highway in Lacy Lakeview, TX. There were no injuries and no known structures were damaged, but 50 or so firefighters from at least 9 different fire departments were used to battle the fire and bring it under control.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions and above normal temperatures across the region left the area susceptible to grass fires during the early part of September. Several small grass fires caused damage between the 6th and 9th, and on the 6th, an elderly man was killed when a grass fire spread to his mobile home. The Dam Fire in Hill County ignited on the 8th, burning 580 acres on the south side of Lake Whitney and 9 homes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small grass fire on the 1300 block of Travis Lane in the city of Kaufman killed an elderly man. The grass fire spread to a nearby mobile home, engulfing the home in flames. Two other family members at the residence were injured.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Elevated fire weather conditions persisted for most of the month due to the extreme heat and the ongoing historic drought. Many wildfires occurred during the month burning over 40,000 acres of land, several homes, and lots of personal property. From the 1st through the 5th, there were 6 grass fires that caused damage. The largest and most damaging of these fires was the 1701-acre Center City Fire that occurred in Mills County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small 5-acre fire in the 7800 block of Silverado Loop in Kaufman burned a home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and dry conditions across the region on the 2nd and 3rd resulted in elevated fire weather conditions. A few fires started on these days but several more fires began on the 4th and 5th behind a strong cold front. The cold front moved through the region on the 4th bringing strong and gusty north winds with it.  On the 5th, humidity values fell dangerously low. A Red Flag Warning was issued for parts of the area on the 4th and 5th. Over the holiday weekend, over two dozen wildfires ignited with several of the fires causing damage. The largest complex of fires was in Limestone County where five fires burned 7500 acres and 7 homes. The Concord-Robbins Fire in Leon County burned 31 homes and 4689 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 440-acre fire at FM 148 and CR 2613 near Lively destroyed one home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Under extreme drought conditions, a series of wildfires started in northwest Jasper County near the Ebenezer community. Over 1,600 acres burned, 20 homes were evacuated, and Highway 63 was closed. The flames were 150 feet tall. One indirect fatality occured on August 28th when a 38 year old firefighter crashed his ATV into a Texas Park & Wildlife truck when he was trying to notify of an approaching wildfire. In Tyler County, a series of wildfires northeast of Colmesneil 767 acres, some of which was on a commercial pine plantation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In a series of wildfires in the same location, over 1,600 acres burned, 20 homes were evacuated, and Highway 63 was closed. An indirect fatality occurred on August 28th when a firefighter was killed after he lost control of an ATV and crashed into a Texas Parks & Wildlife truck.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and dry conditions across the region on the 2nd and 3rd resulted in elevated fire weather conditions. A few fires started on these days but several more fires began on the 4th and 5th behind a strong cold front. The cold front moved through the region on the 4th bringing strong and gusty north winds with it.  On the 5th, humidity values fell dangerously low. A Red Flag Warning was issued for parts of the area on the 4th and 5th. Over the holiday weekend, over two dozen wildfires ignited with several of the fires causing damage. The largest complex of fires was in Limestone County where five fires burned 7500 acres and 7 homes. The Concord-Robbins Fire in Leon County burned 31 homes and 4689 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five fires in Freestone County erupted on the 4th. The fires burned a total of 7500 acres. According to the Limestone Office of Emergency Management, 7 homes and 18 outbuildings were burned by these fires. The largest fire was located near Teague and the fire were contained the morning of the 7th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Pedernales Bend Wildfire started in Travis County on September 4 behind Tropical Storm Lee and a cold front that brought strong northerly winds. The peak wind at Austin Bergstrom International Airport was 36 mph. The fire burned into Hays County and eventually consumed 6500 acres and destroyed 67 homes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pedernales Bend Wildfire started in Travis County on September 4 behind Tropical Storm Lee and a cold front that brought strong northerly winds. The peak wind at Austin Bergstrom International Airport was 36 mph. The fire burned into Hays County and eventually consumed 6500 acres and destroyed 67 homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon of January 30th four grass and brush fires started near Wimberley. The Ledgerock, 8080,  Balke, and Woodcreek Fires were managed as the 2325 Wildland Fire. Weather on the 30th was clear and dry with relative humidity between 25% and 30% and winds from the south-southeast at 8-11 mph. Some homes were evacuated as a precaution, but no structures were damaged. The fire eventually consumed 750 acres before being contained on January 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon of January 30th four grass and brush fires started near Wimberley. The Ledgerock, 8080,  Balke, and Woodcreek Fires were managed as the 2325 Wildland Fire. Weather on the 30th was clear and dry with relative humidity between 25% and 30% and winds from the south-southeast at 8-11 mph. Some homes were evacuated as a precaution, but no structures were damaged. The fire eventually consumed 750 acres before being contained on January 31st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous wildfires broke out in northwest Iowa during the late morning and afternoon of September 29th. The fires started and spread under conditions of strong winds, low relative humidity, and dry vegetation due to a preceding extended period of dry weather. The fires affected grassland and crops. Two fires destroyed buildings on farmsteads, in one case killing cattle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several wildfires consumed several acres each of grass and cropland in the county. At least 3 of the fires were in the Lake Park area. Most of the crop damage from the fires was to soybeans. The amount of crop damage was not known.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Stoney Point Fire (originally called the Stoner Point Fire) began on the evening of the 13th in the Ozark National Forest about 8.4 miles west-southwest of Ozone in Johnson County. The fire was controlled on the afternoon of the 21st after burning 200 acres.
The Bee Ridge Fire about 5 miles northeast of Ozone in Johnson County began on the 5th and eventually burned 189 acres in the Ozark National Forest.
The Hess Knob Fire was started by lightning 5 miles northeast of Hagarville in Johnson County in the Ozark National Forest on the 1st and was contained on the 6th. Altogether, 1438 acres burned.

The Hudson Springs Fire near Clarksville in Johnson County on the 6th and 7th burned 91 acres. About 40 homes were evacuated during the fire. One mobile home was destroyed. The cause of the fire was a faulty air conditioning unit in the mobile home.

A recent lack of rainfall, low humidities and gusty winds made conditions favorable for wildfires late in early March. On the 4th, a wildfire 18 miles north-northwest of Harrison in Boone County burned 110 acres.

High pressure offshore brought warm southwesterly flow over southern New England.  Above normal temperatures combined with low dewpoints resulting in relative humidity levels in the 15 to 25 percent range.  These conditions along with gusty winds at times contributed to the spread of a fire in meadowlands in Dedham.  Firefighters were unable to determine the initial cause of the fire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearly 100 acres of meadow land burned on the Dedham-Boston line near Route 128.  No injuries or structural damage were reported.  Below normal rainfall over the previous 3 to 6 months resulted in dry grasses which fueled the fire.  Most of the flames were extinguished by 8:30pm EST, but firefighters remained on the scene through the night watching for hot spots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extraordinarily dry conditions combined with winds gusting to 25 to 30 mph to produce conditions ideal for fire spread.  A brush fire in Brimfield moved into an area of blown down debris from the June 1, 2011 tornado and became difficult to control.  In addition, a thunderstorm blew through the area while firefighters were attempting to control the blaze.  For their safety, firefighters were called off the fire until the storm passed.  The fire eventually burned about 50 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brush fire ignited around noon in extraordinarily dry conditions.  The fire moved into an area of blown down debris from the June 1, 2011 tornado and spread quickly.  No structures were destroyed but numerous houses were threatened.  Firefighting operations continued into the morning of April 5 with numerous fire departments from both Massachusetts and Connecticut.  A Black Hawk helicopter from the Army National Guard assisted with water drops.  A total of 50 acres burned.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A brush fire on Tekoa Mountain near Westfield, Massachusetts started on March 8, 2016 and spread quickly thanks to very dry weather in the previous days and weeks.  Weather on March 8th and 9th was favorable for fire fighters with light winds and relative humidity values around 50%.  Despite this, the fire spread to nearly 70 acres before fire fighters were able to contain it.  One of the reasons for the quick fire spread was the lack of hydrants or water lines in the vicinity, requiring fire fighters to carry in water on their backs.  By 2pm on March 9, fire fighters deemed the fire 90 percent contained.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brush fire on Tekoa Mountain near Westfield, Massachusetts started on March 8, 2016 and spread quickly thanks to very dry weather in the previous days and weeks. Weather on March 8th and 9th was favorable for fire fighters with light winds and relative humidity values around 50%. Despite this, the fire spread to about 60 acres before fire fighters were able to contain it. One of the reasons for the quick fire spread was the lack of hydrants or water lines in the vicinity, requiring fire fighters to carry in water on their backs. By 2pm on March 9, fire fighters deemed the fire 90 percent contained.  The area of the fire was very remote and no structures were in the area of the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A relatively small fire in Wilmington forced some evacuations, but was quickly contained.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire occurred near the Louise Wells Cameron Art Museum, forcing evacuation of the museum and 15 homes. One shed caught fire. The fire was contained in about five hours, but smoldered for another two weeks. Approximately 60 acres were burned.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire in the Mountain Springs area of northwest Lonoke County burned 4 acres on the 4th. A mobile home, two barns, and several vehicles were destroyed. Investigators indicated that the use of fireworks caused the fire. Lonoke County was under a burn ban at the time which prohibited the use of fireworks. Three people were arrested and charged with felony criminal mischief.
The Black Rock Fire burned a total of 18,300 acres in June and July.  The Truxton Canyon RAWS was destroyed on June 28th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Black Rock Fire began on June 27th, and continued into July.  The Truxton Canyon RAWS was destroyed by the fire on June 28th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Black Rock Fire burned a total of 18,300 acres in June and July.  The Truxton Canyon RAWS was destroyed on June 28th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Black Rock Fire continued into July, and was fully contained on July 6th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Below normal rainfall in the late winter and early spring months combined with an extended period of unseasonably warm, dry conditions across the region in early April set the stage for some of the most significant wildfires in Virginia's history.  Back-to-back windy, dry, cold frontal passages following a 14-day period of only five percent of normal rainfall and temperatures 15 to 20 degrees above normal leading up to the Easter weekend, set the stage for a complex of five major wildfires across west central and northern Virginia, three of which occurred within the Blacksburg, VA County Warning Area (CWA).  Consequently, the complex of fires were appropriately named the Easter Complex fires.  The fires grew significantly on the 10th when sustained winds of 25 mph with gusts of 40 to 48 mph were observed across the region.  This fire, known as the Rich Hole Fire, affected Bath, Alleghany, and Rockbridge counties.  It was the largest wildfire in Virginia's history and threatened the city of Covington at times near Interstate-64.  The fire burned over 15,000 acres of land, mostly owned by the United States Forest Service and was believed to have been human-caused.  Costs to contain the fire were nearly $2 million and rehabilitation treatment costs were over $60,000.  There were no structures lost and no injuries or deaths from this wildfire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This fire was known as the Rich Hole Fire affecting Bath, Alleghany, and Rockbridge counties in west central Virginia.  This was the largest single wildfire in Virginia's history.  The fire affected the George Washington National Forest and the Rich Hole Wilderness area.  The cause of the fire was believed to have been human.  The fire burned for nine days and burned 15,454 acres, of which 14,960 was federal land and 494 was private land.  No structures were burned.  Suppression costs were $1.622 million and rehabilitation costs were $60,355.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Below normal rainfall in the late winter and early spring months combined with an extended period of unseasonably warm, dry conditions across the region in early April set the stage for some of the most significant wildfires in Virginia's history.  Back-to-back windy, dry, cold frontal passages following a 14-day period of only five percent of normal rainfall and temperatures 15 to 20 degrees above normal leading up to the Easter weekend, set the stage for a complex of five major wildfires across west central and northern Virginia, three of which occurred within the Blacksburg, VA County Warning Area (CWA).  Consequently, the complex of fires were appropriately named the Easter Complex fires.  The fires grew significantly on the 10th when sustained winds of 25 mph with gusts of 40 to 48 mph were observed across the region.  Consequently, the complex of fires were appropriately named the Easter Complex fires.  This fire, known as the Barbour Creek Fire, affected Craig and Alleghany counties.  The fire burned over 7,000 acres of land, mostly owned by the United State Forest Service.  Costs to contain the fire were nearly $2 million and rehabilitation treatment costs were nearly $90,000.  There were no structures lost and no injuries or deaths from this wildfire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This fire was known as the Barbours Creek Fire, affecting Craig and Alleghany counties.  The fire affected the Jefferson National Forest and Barbours Creek Wilderness area.  The cause of the fire was believed to have been human.  The fire burned for eleven days and burned 7,402 acres, of which 7236 was federal land and 166 was private land.  No structures were burned.  Suppression costs were $1.668 million and rehabilitation costs were $86,693.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Below normal rainfall in the late winter and early spring months combined with an extended period of unseasonably warm, dry conditions across the region in early April set the stage for some of the most significant wildfires in Virginia's history.  Back-to-back windy, dry, cold frontal passages following a 14-day period of only five percent of normal rainfall and temperatures 15 to 20 degrees above normal leading up to the Easter weekend, set the stage for a complex of five major wildfires across west central and northern Virginia, three of which occurred within the Blacksburg, VA County Warning Area (CWA).  Consequently, the complex of fires were appropriately named the Easter Complex fires.  The fires grew significantly on the 10th when sustained winds of 25 mph with gusts of 40 to 48 mph were observed across the region.  This fire, known as the Alleghany Tunnels Fire, affected just Alleghany county.  The fire was believed to have been caused by a railroad crew sanding the tracks within the George Washington National Forest.  This fire burned over 11,000 acres of land, mostly owned by the United States Forest Service.  Costs to contain the fire were nearly $1 million and rehabilitation treatment costs were nearly $30,000.  There were no structures lost and no injuries or deaths from this wildfire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This fire, known as the Alleghany Tunnels Fire, affected just Alleghany county.  The fire was believed to have been caused by a railroad crew sanding the tracks within the George Washington National Forest.  This fire burned over 11,000 acres of land, mostly owned by the United States Forest Service.  Costs to contain the fire were nearly $1 million and rehabilitation treatment costs were nearly $30,000.  There were no structures lost and no injuries or deaths from this wildfire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning strikes from a line of thunderstorms ignited The Duck Lake Wildfire 14 miles north of Newberry and the Pine Creek North Wildfire in the Seney National Wildlife Refuge on the evening of the 20th. ||Strong south winds gusting over 30 mph on the 24th quickly fanned the Duck Lake Wildfire and caused it to spread rapidly toward the Lake Superior shore forcing mandatory evacuations for people in the Pike Lake, Bodi Lake, Culhane Lake and Little Lake Harbor areas. The 21,069 acre wildfire, the third largest in modern Michigan history, burned 136 structures (including one store and one motel) before it was fully contained in mid-June. ||The Pine Creek North Wildfire spread to 3500 acres by the 25th but was 95 percent contained by the 28th.  The Marshland Wildlife Drive, Fishing Loop, Pine Ridge Nature Trail and many interior roads within the refuge were all closed due to the fire.  The cost of resources to fight the fire was estimated to be around $600,000.  No injuries or deaths were reported from the fire.  ||Due to the wildfires and extreme fire danger, Governor Rick Snyder declared a state of disaster in both Luce and Schoolcraft counties on the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning from thunderstorms ignited the Pine Creek North Wildfire on the evening of the 20th.  The fire spread to 3500 acres by the 25th but was 95 percent contained by the 28th.  The Marshland Wildlife Drive, Fishing Loop, Pine Ridge Nature Trail and many interior roads within the refuge were all closed due to the fire.  The cost of resources to fight the fire was estimated to be around $600,000.  No injuries or deaths were reported from the fire.  Governor Rick Snyder declared a state of disaster in Schoolcraft County on the 25th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An 80-year old man was killed when his controlled burn got out of control due to gusty winds. Also, a large grassfire burned approximately 750 acres in Denton County; including 2 barns.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A grassfire burned approximately 750 acres between Pilot Point and Celina in Denton County. The fire began south of FM 455 near Tischler and Riley Road from a tractor that was cutting wheat. Two barns were destroyed in the fire, and two homes were also damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry and windy conditions behind a cold front led to elevated fire danger on Monday January 22, resulting in several grass fires across North Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Denton Fire and Rescue reported a 200 acre wildfire near the Highway 377 and Cross Timbers intersection in the city of Roanoke, TX.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry and windy conditions behind a cold front led to elevated fire danger on Monday January 22, resulting in several grass fires across North Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported that 1,000 acres had burned near Willow Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extremely dry conditions and drought conditions helped with the development and spread of multiple wildfires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Farm equipment sparked a wildfire called the Martin fire near Chadwick in the Mark Twain National Forest. The fire burned approximately 1200 acres and damaged one home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Skibstad Wildfire started on the evening of July 25th and originated 8 miles southeast of Columbus near Highway 421 and grew to 3000 acres during the overnight hours. Officials believed the fire started when a fire in a building spread to the surrounding area. Stillwater County officials ordered evacuations for homes in the Shane Creek area south of the fire. However, no homes or buildings were destroyed as a result of the fire. Fire crews and 45 engines from Sweet Grass, Yellowstone, Stillwater and Carbon Counties along with state DNRC firefighters fought the blaze. Two helicopters and two air tankers were used in fighting the fire. The fuels for the fire were timber, grass and sage. Total personnel used to fight the fire was 234 and the total area burned was 3,354 acres. The fire was contained on July 29th around 8 PM.

The Rosebud Wildfire originated 10 miles southwest of Roscoe, Montana on Tuesday, August 28th, at approximately 1:08 pm. The fire burned 2,397 acres and was 100% contained on Saturday, September 1st at arroximately 5 pm. The fuels consisted of grass and understory pine and grass with intermixed aspen. ||Mandatory evacuations were ordered for approximately 20 residences along Getaway Trail five miles south of Roscoe. Although one outbuilding was reported to have burned, no houses were destroyed. Total personnel consisted of about 195 people, 30 engines, a pair each of bulldozers and water tenders, three helicopters, one heavy air tanker and two small engine tankers. The cause of the wildfire remains under investigation. More detailed information can be found at www.inciweb.org.

The Rosebud Wildfire originated 10 miles southwest of Roscoe, Montana on Tuesday, August 28th, at approximately 1:08 pm. The fire burned 2,397 acres and was 100% contained on Saturday, September 1st at approximately 5 pm. The fuels consisted of grass and understory pine and grass with intermixed aspen.||Mandatory evacuations were ordered for approximately 20 residences along Getaway Trail five miles south of Roscoe. Although one outbuilding was reported to have burned, no houses were destroyed. Total personnel consisted of about 195 people, 30 engines, a pair each of bulldozers and water tenders, three helicopters, one heavy air tanker and two small engine tankers. The cause of the wildfire remains under investigation. More detailed information can be found at www.inciweb.org.
Many locations across northern Arizona experienced a dry winter and a dry spring. This allowed for an active fire season as fuels were already below average at the beginning of the fire season.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire was reported near Wide Ruins at about 10 acres. Fire crews were on-site for at least 5 days.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions and strong winds helped fuel brush fires which completely destroyed one house near Lebanon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brush fire resulting from dry conditions and gusty winds completely destroyed a house near Lebanon before being brought under control.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extremely dry conditions worsened by the on going drought lead to multiple wildfires around the Missouri Ozarks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Arson was blamed for a wildfire that burned approximately 300 acres near Lebanon. One outbuilding was destroyed. This information came from the Missouri Department of Conservation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong and gusty wind, warm temperatures, low relative humidity values, and dormant grasses and vegetation promoted the spread of a wildfire that burned over 300 acres south of Keys, Oklahoma. Another wildfire burned over 375 acres southeast of Jay, Oklahoma. Oklahoma Forestry Services, Cherokee Nation, and local volunteer fire departments fought the wildfires.

Strong westerly wind gusting up to 55 mph behind a pacific cold front, combined with unseasonably warm conditions and low relative humidity, promoted the rapid spread of wildfire across northeastern Oklahoma during the afternoon and evening hours of November 11th. Large wildfires burned portions of Osage, Washington, Delaware, and Nowata Counties. The wildfire that affected Washington and Nowata Counties burned an estimated 26,000 acres, including two homes and numerous outbuildings. The towns of Lenapah and Delaware in Nowata County were evacuated during the evening due to the approaching wildfire. Wildfires in Osage County burned about 14,000 acres, and a wildfire in Delaware County burned over 300 acres, including several outbuildings.

Unseasonably warm temperatures, very low relative humidity, and gusty wind combined with drought-stricken, dormant vegetation to promote the rapid spread of a number of wildfires across eastern Oklahoma during early March 2017. The largest wildfires occurred in Pittsburg County where over 1600 acres burned, Muskogee County where over 1400 acres burned, Le Flore County where over 1200 acres burned, Creek County where over 800 acres burned, Sequoyah and Adair Counties where over 400 acres burned, Delaware County where over 300 acres burned, and Cherokee County where over 200 acres burned.

Unseasonably warm temperatures, very low relative humidity, and gusty wind combined with drought-stricken, dormant vegetation to promote the rapid spread of a number of wildfires across eastern Oklahoma during late March 2017. The largest wildfires occurred in Cherokee County where over 5000 acres burned, Adair County where over 2200 acres burned, Pittsburg and Sequoyah Counties where over 1000 acres burned, Delaware County where over 600 acres burned, and Latimer County where over 500 acres burned.

Gusty wind, low relative humidity, and unseasonably warm conditions combined with dry and dormant vegetation to promote the rapid spread of wildfire on March 4th through the 8th across eastern Oklahoma. More than 1000 acres burned in Pittsburg County, more than 900 acres burned in Latimer County, more than 600 acres burned in Cherokee and Delaware Counties, more than 500 acres burned in Haskell County, and more than 200 acres burned in Le Flore, Pushmataha, and Adair Counties during that several day period.

A wildfire developed in western Lauderdale County on the afternoon of the 18th north of Waterloo.  A second fire developed on the 19th northeast of Waterloo near County Road 90.  One trailer home was destroyed by this wildfire.  The larger wildfire scorched over 700 acres.  On the 20th, gusty southeast winds of 20 to 30 mph combined with unseasonably warm temperatures in the middle 80s contributed greatly to the fire's spread.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two wildfires developed in western Lauderdale County on the afternoon of the 18th and on the 19th.  The first fire developed north of Waterloo. A second fire developed on the 19th northeast of Waterloo near County Road 90. One camper trailer home was destroyed by this wildfire. The larger wildfire became as large as 600 acres on the 20th as gusty southeast winds of 20 to 30 mph combined with unseasonably warm temperatures in the middle 80s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large grass fire occurred over northern Hettinger and southern Stark counties on March 19th. Up to 5,000 acres were burned and two farmsteads were destroyed. One of the farmsteads was abandoned and the other was occupied. One landowner was treated for burns at a hospital and a deputy sheriff was treated for smoke inhalation. The fire caused a traffic accident on highway 22 and there were no injuries in that accident. There was no loss of life. The fire was driven by strong southerly winds up to 45 miles per hour, along with low relative humidities of ten to 15 percent.||There were three grass fires in Williams County that same day. One, southwest of Williston, near Trenton, burned 1,700 hay bales.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three grass fires were fought in Williams County with one, southwest of Williston, near Trenton, burning 1,700 hay bales. No injuries or deaths were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fire started by lightning on August 28th grew to 420 acres and destroyed 2 homes about 20 miles west of Montpelier.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A fire started by lightning on August 28th grew to 420 acres and destroyed 2 homes about 20 miles west of Montpelier.  Several temporary evacuations were ordered in the mountainous terrain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Bald Knob Fire 4.5 miles southeast of Bald Knob in White County burned 140 acres on the 3rd.

Vegetation that was mostly dormant, gusty winds, and low humidities made conditions favorable for wildfires on the 16th. Two fires exceeded 100 acres. In White County, the White No. 1 Fire burned 150 acres 6 miles southwest of Searcy. In Stone County, the Iron Mountain Fire burned 123 acres 1 mile west of St. James.

The Dugan fire was a wildfire that originated 2 miles south of Ekalaka in Carter County  on Friday, September 14th at approximately 10:00 pm. At this time, the cause of the fire remains unknown. The wildfire fuels involved were grass, shrubs and Ponderosa Pine timber in rough, steep coulees. The fire burned 10,675 acres and was 100% contained on Wednesday, September 19th at approximately 6:00 pm. The cause of the fire at this time remains unknown and is under investigation. The fire destroyed an estimated three outbuildings and an uninhabited trailer but no homes. However, the fire did burn the Ekalaka Park Campground, destroying a handful of picnic tables. About 200 people were assigned to the fire, along with 25 engines, three helicopters, three graders and a pair of dozers. More detailed information can be found at www.inciweb.org.
Extremely dry conditions and drought conditions helped in the development of and spread of multiple wildfires across the Missouri Ozarks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Farm equipment caused a spark which started a wildfire near Lamar. This fire burned approximately 200 acres. No homes or structures were damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire near Lamar was started by someone burning debris which became difficult to control due to elevated fire weather conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire near Lamar was started by someone burning debris which became difficult to control. The fire burned approximately 800 acres. Four outbuildings and four homes were threatened.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The dry weather was blamed for a wildfire that burned for several hours in the town of Adams in Jefferson County. It is unknown how the fire started around 1:30 p.m. Over 100 fire fighters worked to put out the brushfire which burned two- to three-thousand acres in the vicinity of County Roads 75 and 76 before being extinguished.

Thursday evening high based thunderstorms produced lightning that ignited four wildfires in Keith County and one in Arthur County. The wildfires burned about 60,000 acres of mainly grasslands, but also threatened dozens of summer houses, town houses, condominiums and rental cabins near the Bayside Golf Club on the southwest shore of Lake McConaughy during the Eagle Canyon Hideaway Fire. One wildfire in northeast Keith County spread into southwest McPherson County. The wildfires were contained overnight where loss of grasslands for grazing could exceed 500 thousand dollars.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning strikes ignited four wildfires in Keith County that burned grassland and timbers overnight and were contained on the 3rd by noon time. The wildfires occurred at the Eagle Canyon Hideaway that burned up to 3,000 acres of grassland and timber, at the Otter Creek area that burned up to 40,000 acres, at the Ackley Valley on the Hawthorn Ranch that burned up to 6,000, and at the Glen Echo area that burned an estimated 7,500 acres. The Glen Echo wildfire spread into southwest McPherson County before containment.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire fanned by high winds caused a fire to quickly spread southeast, crossing Interstate 80 and then burning for an additional 12 miles southeast into northeast Perkins County. The wildfire reached up to 1.5 miles wide. The wildfire destroyed two occupied homes, one abandoned home and various outbuildings were destroyed as well. in addition to building structures the wildfire destroyed several pieces of farm implements, while several power poles and culverts were damaged. The area burned was estimated at 10,000 acres of farm flat and rolling hills.  Three firemen developed eye problems with one treated for an unknown illness. The wildfire led to evacuation orders for those in the path of the wildfire from east of Paxton to the south edge of the Keith-Perkins County Line in the southeast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire started about one mile north of Interstate 80 near Paxton that was fanned by high winds. The high winds caused the wildfire to quickly spread southeast, crossing Interstate 80 and then burning for an additional 12 miles southeast into northeast Perkins County. The wildfire reached up to 1.5 miles wide. The wildfire destroyed two occupied homes, one abandoned home and various outbuildings were destroyed as well. In addition to building structures the wildfire destroyed several pieces of farm implements, while several power poles and culverts were damaged. The area burned was estimated at 10,000 acres of farm flat and rolling hills. Three firemen developed eye problems with one treated for an unknown illness. The wildfire led to evacuation orders for those in the path of the wildfire from east of Paxton to the south edge of the Keith-Perkins County Line in the southeast.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms formed on the evening of March 28th across the eastern Nebraska Panhandle. As they moved east, they produced a downburst over portions of Garden County which led to damage.  As the thunderstorms moved east, they touched off a wildfire in far eastern Arthur County.  Aided by strong northerly winds, the fire burned over 35,000 acres of range land in eastern Arthur, western McPherson and eastern Keith Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dry lightning started a fire 13 miles east of Arthur around 830 PM MST. The fire quickly spread south aided by strong northerly winds. By the morning of the 29th, around 30000 acres of range land was burned over eastern Arthur, western McPherson and eastern Keith counties.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thursday evening high based thunderstorms produced lightning that ignited four wildfires in Keith County and one in Arthur County. The wildfires burned about 60,000 acres of mainly grasslands, but also threatened dozens of summer houses, town houses, condominiums and rental cabins near the Bayside Golf Club on the southwest shore of Lake McConaughy during the Eagle Canyon Hideaway Fire. One wildfire in northeast Keith County spread into southwest McPherson County. The wildfires were contained overnight where loss of grasslands for grazing could exceed 500 thousand dollars.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike ignited the McKeage wildfire on the 2nd and was contained by noon time on the 3rd. The fire burned an estimated 7,500 acres of grassland and timber.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms formed on the evening of March 28th across the eastern Nebraska Panhandle. As they moved east, they produced a downburst over portions of Garden County which led to damage.  As the thunderstorms moved east, they touched off a wildfire in far eastern Arthur County.  Aided by strong northerly winds, the fire burned over 35,000 acres of range land in eastern Arthur, western McPherson and eastern Keith Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dry lightning started a fire 13 miles east of Arthur around 830 PM MST.  The fire quickly spread south aided by strong northerly winds.  By the morning of the 29th, around 30000 acres of range land was burned over eastern Arthur, western McPherson and eastern Keith counties.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme temperatures coupled with an low humidity, increased winds, and an ongoing drought led to several large wildfires across parts of Oklahoma. Some of the fires burned numerous structures. A cold front entered the region late on the 4th, resulting in slightly cooler temperatures and an end to critical fire weather conditions by the 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wildfire began near county street 2860 southeast of Ninnekah. The fire consumed at least two homes and burned approximately 15 square miles of land. No damage estimates were available. The exact time that the fire was extinguished is unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Amidst windy and dry conditions, grass fires burned 780 acres in Grady county on the 29th.
Amidst windy and dry conditions, grass fires burned 300 acres in Grady county and 500 in Atoka county on the 8th.

Extreme temperatures coupled with an low humidity, increased winds, and an ongoing drought led to several large wildfires across parts of Oklahoma. Some of the fires burned numerous structures. A cold front entered the region late on the 4th, resulting in slightly cooler temperatures and an end to critical fire weather conditions by the 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wildfire began near North Luther road and northeast 150th street. The fire moved quickly northward and burned several structures in and around the Luther area. The fire moved into southeast Luther. Damage estimates were unavailable. The exact time the fire was extinguished is unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme temperatures coupled with an low humidity, increased winds, and an ongoing drought led to several large wildfires across parts of Oklahoma. Some of the fires burned numerous structures. A cold front entered the region late on the 4th, resulting in slightly cooler temperatures and an end to critical fire weather conditions by the 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire began near 120th street and McGuire road northeast of Slaughterville. The fire burned northward toward Highway 9, stopping just south of Lake Thunderbird. At least 25 outbuildings and homes were lost in the fire. The smoke plume and pyrocumulus were visible from the National Weather Service forecast office in Norman. Exact ending time of fire unknown. No damage estimates were available.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Amidst windy and dry conditions, grass fires burned 897 acres in Cleveland county on the 12th.

Extreme temperatures coupled with an low humidity, increased winds, and an ongoing drought led to several large wildfires across parts of Oklahoma. Some of the fires burned numerous structures. A cold front entered the region late on the 4th, resulting in slightly cooler temperatures and an end to critical fire weather conditions by the 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported a large wildfire at Tom Steed Reservoir near Altus. The fire resulted in the loss of water to Altus and surrounding communities. No damage information was available. The exact time the wildfire ended is unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire burned roughly 350 acres on the 16th.

A fire which started in Marshall County on September 30th became a wildfire on Tuesday October 2nd, when south winds increased dramatically. Dry conditions brought on by the drought made burn conditions extremely volatile. The south winds increased in the morning and gusted from 40 to 50 mph by afternoon. The fire consumed over twelve square miles and led to the evacuation of over 400 people from Karlstad, Minnesota. Seven homes, two garages, a warehouse, and numerous other outbuildings were burned in the fire. One fireman battling the blaze suffered from heat exhaustion. The fire was 95 percent contained by Wednesday, October 3rd.

CZ_NAME: FOUR CORNERS / UPPER DOLORES RIVER BASIN
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Weber wildfire started June 22 at approximately 4:15 pm, 6 miles south of Mancos and was determined to be human caused. Several areas within or near the fire perimeter were evacuated and numerous road closures were necessary. This fire burned 10,133 acres until containment on July 6th, with both private and public land being affected.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Weber fire was deemed to be human caused and burned a total of 10,133 acres from late June to early July.  Several subdivisions near Mancos were evacuated and nearby roads closed during the height of this fire. Several miles of fence posts and one  outbuilding were burned.  A communications tower was temporarily off line as power to the facility was interrupted by the fire.

CZ_NAME: FOUR CORNERS / UPPER DOLORES RIVER BASIN
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Weber wildfire started June 22nd at approximately 6 pm, 6 miles south of Mancos and was determined to be human caused. Several areas within or near the fire perimeter were evacuated and numerous road closures were necessary. This fire burned 10,133 acres until containment on July 6th, with both private and public land being affected.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Weber fire was deemed to be human caused and burned a total of 10,133 acres from late June to early July.  A national Type 2 fire team was brought in to fight the fire on June 24th as the fire moved toward Highway 160. Several subdivisions near Mancos were evacuated and nearby roads closed during the height of this fire. Several miles of fence posts and one outbuilding were burned. A communications tower was temporarily off line as power to the facility was interrupted by the fire.

CZ_NAME: FOUR CORNERS / UPPER DOLORES RIVER BASIN
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike ignited a wildfire on Moccasin Mesa in Mesa Verde National Park.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Moccasin Mesa Fire began due to lightning ignition on Moccasin Mesa in Mesa Verde National Park and grew to a total of 185 acres before it was contained.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Over the course of about four hours, 12 rural fire departments battled this large wildfire that originated in western Fillmore County approximately four miles southeast of Sutton. The fire burned an area about three-quarters of a mile wide and 5 miles long in a southeast direction, encompassing about 3,500 acres of farmland as very strong northwest winds quickly intensified the fire. A total of two unoccupied homes and seven outbuildings were also destroyed, including 3 machine sheds and a barn.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large wildfire encompassing about 3500 acres of farmland erupted in western Fillmore County, approximately 4 miles southeast of Sutton, as very windy conditions quickly intensified the fire. The fire burned an area about three-quarters of a mile wide and 5 miles long, in a southeast direction. Several outbuildings were engulfed in flames.  A total of 2 unoccupied homes and 7 outbuildings were destroyed, including 3 machine sheds and a barn.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed and moved southeast across parts of northwest Kansas during the late afternoon and evening.  Two separate lightning strikes in extreme southern Sherman County resulted in fires which eventually merged into a large fire consuming 15,000 acres.  One abandoned farm house was destroyed, otherwise no structures or machinery were affected.  The fire lasted approximately 8 hours before it was deemed under control.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large grass fire resulted from two lightning strikes which occurred during the late afternoon.  Erratic, gusty winds from thunderstorm outflows resulted in the fire escalating to eventually cover 15,000 acres in southern Sherman county along the Wallace county border.  One abandoned farm house was destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the middle of the afternoon a landowner southeast of Goodland sustained injuries while lighting a barrel of trash on fire.  The fire spread to nearby fields before being extinguished.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sherman County Rural Fire Department, Brewster Fire Department, and Goodland City Fire were called Monday afternoon to a grass fire in southeast Sherman County.  The landowner added gasoline to a barrel of trash before lighting it.  The gasoline caused a small explosion causing the landowner to be injured and taken to a nearby hospital.  The explosion also caused the barrel to tip over, spilling the burning contents on the grass.  Wind gusts of 25-30 MPH caused the fire to spread from the grass to wheat and corn stubble.  A total of 150 to 170 acres were burned.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire burned 350 acres of grassland near Rochester in Sangamon County on July 27th.  While the exact cause of the fire is unknown, it was likely aided by very dry conditions and northwesterly winds gusting to 25 mph.  No injuries were reported: however, an estimated $20,000 of property damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire burned 350 acres of grassland near Rochester in Sangamon County on July 27th. While the exact cause of the fire is unknown, it was likely aided by very dry conditions and northwesterly winds gusting to 25 mph. No injuries were reported: however, a barn was destroyed by the fire, a small shed was damaged and several pieces of fire fighting equipment were severly damaged or destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Red flag conditions during the afternoon of August 24th led to the development of fast spreading brushfires in Polk County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A fast spreading brushfire burned about 300 acres north of Bolivar near State Highway D and 390th Road. No structures were damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Red flag conditions during the afternoon of August 24th led to the development of fast spreading brushfires in Polk County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large and fast spreading brushfire burned about 1000 acres north of Morrisville on State Highway UU just north of 514th Road. One barn burned in the fire. More than 100 firefighters from 10 departments were fighting the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extremely dry conditions worsened by the on going drought lead to multiple wildfires around the Missouri Ozarks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brush fire got out of hand after a homeowner was burning a tree stump.  The blaze only burned several acres but destroyed several vehicles and a trailer off Reuben Lane in Branson West.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large wildfire occurred near Osceola in Clarke County.  Over 100 acres were burned with one firefighter injured.  Areas burned included pasture, woodland areas, and corn crops.  Fire departments were called from Warren, Clarke, and Madison Counties.  Fire was caused by an unattended burn barrel.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One hundred plus acre wildfire in fields near Osceola.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions, triple digit temperatures and strong southeast winds resulted in a fire that quickly burned out of control during the late afternoon hours of September 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple fire departments responded to the fire that threatened to destroy several homes. Panola County Sheriff���s deputies blocked the road to stop traffic when visibility was restricted by the smoke. The wind was not the friend of the firefighters as they battled the blaze. The fire jumped US 79 and was quick to reach the woods behind a home. Four homes were in danger when firefighters arrived. While some firefighters worked to contain the fire, others worked to hold the flames off from the homes. A shed burned, but the homes were saved. Three dozers were brought in to set up a fire line. Officials from Community 4, Intercommunity, Flatwoods, Carthage, Waskom, Elysian Fields, Caddo, Texas Forest Service, Constable Bryan Murff and Constable Mitch Norton, Texas DPS troopers, EMS and Carthage Fire Marshall all responded to the fire.

CZ_NAME: SOUTHERN SANGRE DE CRISTO MOUNTAINS ABOVE 11000 FT
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The lightning caused wildfire burned 13,572 acres near the base of, and up the northern slopes of East Spanish Peak.  Over 600 firefighters contained the blaze, and one was slightly injured.  Twenty-eight structures were destroyed, including 12 houses, 3 cabins, 12 outbuildings and an infirmary.  Many of the buildings destroyed were on, and near the Spanish Peaks Scout Ranch.  The cost of fighting the wildfire and subsequent mitigation will be several million dollars.

CZ_NAME: SOUTHERN SANGRE DE CRISTO MOUNTAINS ABOVE 11000 FT
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The lightning caused wildfire burned 13,572 acres near the base of the Spanish Peaks.  Over 600 firefighters contained the blaze, and one was slightly injured.  Twenty-eight structures were destroyed, including 12 houses, 3 cabins, 12 outbuildings and an infirmary.  Many of the buildings destroyed were on the Spanish Peaks Boy Scout camp.  At this time, no dollar amount of losses was available, but will likely be a few million dollars.
Lightning sparked the Carpenter One wildfire in the Spring Mountains just outside Las Vegas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning sparked the Carpenter One Wildfire in the Spring Mountains on July 1st. The fire burned a total of 27,881 acres and six structures, and burned well into August before finally being 100% contained.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small brush fire spread into the Windsor Green complex in Carolina Forest, damaging numerous homes with injuries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brush fire spread into the Windsor Green complex the afternoon of March 16th.  The fire only burned 10-15 acres, however it destroyed 26 buildings, with 110 condo units destroyed.  All of the units on Brite Water Court were destroyed, as were units on Twin Pond Court and Pond Shoals.  Three police officers were treated for smoke inhalation.  One fire fighter went into cardiac arrest but was revived and is doing well.  At least 100 people were displaced, and the Red Cross set up a shelter.

CZ_NAME: GREAT SALT LAKE DESERT AND MOUNTAINS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Patch Springs Fire started near the Stansbury Mountains due to a lightning strike on August 10, and was contained two weeks later, but not before causing damage in the town of Terra.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Patch Springs Fire began due to a lightning strike on August 10, two miles from the community of Terra, Utah, which eventually received some damage as the fire spread. Property damage from this fire first occurred on August 17, and the fire eventually grew to 31,010 acres before being contained on August 24. ||The fire destroyed 5 trailer homes and significantly damaged 1 additional trailer home. In addition, 8 outbuildings and 1 commercial property were destroyed by the flames. Along Highway 199, 26 power poles were damaged or destroyed by the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry and warm conditions, along with gusty southwest winds, help fuel several fires near Lincoln. Temperatures that reached around 70 degrees combined with dew point readings in the teens to lower 20s lowered relative humidity values to less than 20 percent for several hours from late in the morning through mid afternoon on March 15th.  Winds were southwest at 15 to 30 mph, but shifted to the northeast at 30 to 45 mph as a cold front pressed south by mid to late afternoon.  The cooler air helped raise relative humidity readings, but only marginally until early evening when temperatures cooled more significantly.  Several fires in the area quickly burned out of control due to the dry, windy weather.  One near Lincoln, of unknown origin, caused around $200,000 worth of damage and threatened many structures was contained before doing much more damage.  The other significant fire, in Seward county west of Lincoln, started when a controlled burn got out of control.  This fire burned around 1,000 acres.  In all it was estimated that at least a half dozen good-sized grassfires in southeast Nebraska this day according to a Lincoln fire investigator.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind fueled a fire that started as controlled burn causing to get out of control and burn 1,000 acres from 168th and Bluff Roads nearly all the way to Highway 34 two miles to the south.  The area is a few miles southeast of Garland.  The flames destroyed a machine shed with machinery in it, scorched the side of a horse barn and also damaged equipment at another property nearby.  Crews from more than a dozen fire departments responded.  The Nebraska State Patrol helicopter helped spot the fire from the air.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Malone Fire in northwestern Val Verde County was brought under control on May 9. The fire began April 27 and eventually burned 14,587 acres and destroyed two structures. The news media reported that fire crews were able to successfully defend other structures on several ranch residences in the area. Residents of Pandale were forced to evacuate, but no damage was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Malone Fire in northwestern Val Verde County was brought under control on May 9. The fire began April 27 and eventually burned 14,587 acres and destroyed two structures. The news media reported that fire crews were able to successfully defend other structures on several ranch residences in the area. Residents of Pandale were forced to evacuate, but no damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Malone wildfire in rural northwestern Val Verde County started on April 27 (estimated around noon) and spread under breezy, dry conditions. A Red Flag Warning was in effect at the time the fire started. The fire burned into May and at the end of April had consumed 12,655 acres and was 50 percent contained. According to media reports, there were some evacuations in Pandale.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Malone wildfire in rural northwestern Val Verde County started on April 27 (estimated around noon) and spread under breezy, dry conditions. A Red Flag Warning was in effect at the time the fire started. The fire burned into May and at the end of April had consumed 12,655 acres and was 50 percent contained. According to media reports, there were some evacuations in Pandale.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The West Fire burned 3000 acres in Val Verde County. The fire started on August 14 and was 100% contained on August 20. One structure was threatened by the fire and was saved.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The West Fire burned 3000 acres in Val Verde County. The fire started on August 14 and was 100% contained on August 20. One structure was threatened by the fire and was saved.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Pocket Fire burned 300 acres in Val Verde County from March 27 through March 30.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pocket Fire burned 300 acres in Val Verde County from March 27 through March 30.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire burned 900 acres on the Old Moody Ranch in Val Verde County from March 6 until March 8 when the fire was 100% contained.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire burned 900 acres on the Old Moody Ranch in Val Verde County from March 6 until March 8 when the fire was 100% contained.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire on the west side of Del Rio burned 400 acres. The fire destroyed two homes and two other structures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire on the west side of Del Rio burned 400 acres. The fire destroyed two homes and two other structures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Holcombe Road Wildfire started April 19 around 3:00 pm in Crockett County and eventually spread into Val Verde County. The fire started in the wake of a cold front that brought dry air and gusty winds. At the time of ignition, the relative humidity at Del Rio had fallen to 10% and 30 foot winds were from the WNW at 15 to 20 mph with gusts up to 36 mph. The fire burned until May 2 and consumed 25,958 acres. Seven structures, four recreational vehicles, and four outbuildings were destroyed. Thirty-five homes were threatened by the fire and saved.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Holcombe Road Wildfire started April 19 around 2:00 pm in Crockett County and eventually spread into Val Verde County. The fire started in the wake of a cold front that brought dry air and gusty winds. At the time of ignition, the relative humidity at Del Rio had fallen to 10% and 30 foot winds were from the WNW at 15 to 20 mph with gusts up to 36 mph. The fire burned until May 2 and consumed 25,958 acres. Seven structures, four recreational vehicles, and four outbuildings were destroyed. Thirty-five homes were threatened by the fire and saved.

CZ_NAME: LITTLE COLORADO RIVER VALLEY IN COCONINO COUNTY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abnormally dry conditions and strong winds allowed several fires to break out around the Flagstaff area over a two day period.  The area had only received 64% of average rainfall since September.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five cars, a travel trailer, and a home under construction burned in a wild fire south of Leupp.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry and breezy conditions contributed to the spread of a wildfire that burned about 40 acres near Alma in Crawford County.  The fire damaged a mobile home.

Unseasonably warm temperatures, very low relative humidity, and gusty wind combined with drought-stricken, dormant vegetation to promote the rapid spread of a number of wildfires across northwestern Arkansas during late March 2017. The largest wildfires occurred in Crawford and Carroll Counties where over 200 acres burned.
Grass fires on two separate days near Faught in Lamar County burned a hay crop and damaged equipment used to gather the hay.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A grass fire in a hay field near Faught heavily damaged a tractor and other hay baling equipment.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Grass fires on two separate days near Faught in Lamar County burned a hay crop and damaged equipment used to gather the hay.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: For the second day in a row, a 50-acre grass fire in a hay field near Faught burned a hay crop and heavily damaged hay baling equipment.

CZ_NAME: LINCOLN COUNTY EXCEPT THE SHEEP RANGE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Three wildfires broke out in southern Nevada, destroying several structures and vehicles before being contained.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cottonwood Fire and Middle Ridge Fire were started by lightning near the Utah state line. The fires destroyed two cabins and a trailer home and damaged a cemetery. Beaver Dam State Park was also closed for a time due to the fires.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Three wildfires broke out in southern Nevada, destroying several structures and vehicles before being contained.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire in Pahrump burned two sheds, a mobile home, and two motor homes, displacing four families. Two volunteer firefighters also suffered heat exhaustion in the 109 degree temperature.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Afternoon temperatures reached into the 70 to 75 degree range along the lower Elk River Valley.  Southwest winds were blowing at 10 to 15 mph. The relative humidity was around 25 percent. ||A 67 year old man near Clendenin was burning some debris near his home.  The wind caused the fire to flare up.  When firefighters arrived, a barn had caught fire and a small brush fire was burning over a hillside. The firefighters found the man collapsed on the ground.  His clothes were not burnt. The preliminary finding was the man died of cardiac arrest, apparently while trying to control the brush fire.

The Reynolds Creek Fire began around 3:45 pm on Tuesday, July 21. It was in an area approximately six miles east of Logan Pass and four miles west of the Saint Mary Visitor Center. The fire burned thousands of trees along Going-to-the-Sun Road, two structures were lost, including the historic Baring Creek Cabin and an old homestead along Saint Mary Lake that was constructed prior to the creation of the park. A vehicle was also destroyed in the fire. The cost of the fire was approximately 10.1 million as of August 7, 2015 and the cause of the fire is under investigation. Resources from Flathead National Forest, Glacier County, East Glacier, Babb, St. Mary, Cutbank, Evergreen, and West Valley Fire Departments, Blackfeet Fire Management, Montana Department of Natural Resources, Flathead County, as well as Glacier County and Montana Disaster & Emergency Services assisted Glacier National Park in the fire incident. The final update on the Reynolds Creek Fire was issued on August 7, 2015.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Reynolds Creek Fire began around 3:45 pm on Tuesday, July 21. It was in an area approximately six miles east of Logan Pass and four miles west of the Saint Mary Visitor Center. The fire burned thousands of trees along Going-to-the-Sun Road, two structures were lost, including the historic Baring Creek Cabin and an old homestead along Saint Mary Lake that was constructed prior to the creation of the park. A vehicle was also destroyed in the fire. The cost of the fire was approximately 10.1 million as of August 7, 2015 and the cause of the fire is under investigation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry northwest winds enhanced wildfires, including the Rocky Fire in Lake County and a property damaging grass fire in Elverta, in northern Sacramento County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The fire started Monday afternoon along Browning Street, about two miles north of Elverta Road, off Highway 99 and Baseline Road in Elverta, Sacramento County. The fire spread into Placer County. One home, six cars and a tractor were destroyed by the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A upper level low passed through the region, which brought elevated fire weather concerns to northern California. Areas impacted within Sacramento's forecast area include the Sacramento and San Joaquin Valleys for areas generally below 1000 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On June 8, conditions were favorable for wildfire growth as relative humidity values fell into the teens and northerly winds gusted up to 25-45 mph. Prior to the start of this event, the local utility company decided to de-energize power lines per CA Public Utility Commissions (CPUC) Public Safety Power Shutoff (PSPS) guidelines. Eventually, a fire did start at 1350PST in Yolo County, which became known as the Sand Fire. There were 2512 acres of land burned over a period of 8 days, along with 7 structures destroyed. The fire also led to road closures from Highway 16 to Highway 20 to the town Brooks in addition to the evacuation of residents living along County Road 41.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Blue Creek Fire started on Monday, July 20 at approximately 1230 in the afternoon. It is burning 8 miles east of Walla Walla, Washington in grass, brush and timber. It is estimated to be 6,004 acres and is 95% contained. Acreage remains unchanged. One primary structure and 11 outbuilding have been destroyed. The fire was human caused and is under investigation.
