The Blue Creek Fire started on Monday, July 20 at approximately 1230 in the afternoon. It is burning 8 miles east of Walla Walla, Washington in grass, brush and timber. It is estimated to be 6,004 acres and is 95% contained. Acreage remains unchanged. One primary structure and 11 outbuilding have been destroyed. The fire was human caused and is under investigation.||Final Update was August 4th.
A large grass became out of control and burned down several oil storage tanks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A grass fire became out of control and consumed about 150 acres in Bourbon County, Kansas about 10 miles northwest of Fort Scott. This fire was between the communities of Xenia and Devon. The fire engulfed three oil storage tanks which were completely destroyed.  Roughly 25000 gallons or 600 barrels of oil were lost.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of gusty south to southwest winds and drying conditions led to several wildfires across Eastern Pennsylvania on the 6th and resulted in one fatality, a couple of injuries and minor property damage. ||In Northampton County, on the afternoon of the 6th, in Lower Saucon Township, a 72-year-old man died after a burning debris fire started by him, spread to his home, two other out buildings and burned about two acres of timber. Along the Lehigh and Carbon County line on the Blue Mountains, a brush fire burned about 27 acres along the Appalachian Trail before it was contained.  The fire started during the late afternoon of the 6th and affected Washington Township in Lehigh County and northwest of Pennsylvania State Routes 248 and 873 near Lehigh Gap (East Penn Township) in Carbon County.   Because of the location, fire fighters used helicopters and aircraft to assist in battling the blaze. Local firefighters from eight departments assisted on foot. In Montgomery County,  in New Hanover Township, an afternoon wildfire consumed twelve acres of timber near the intersection of Colflesh and Church Roads. Three firefighters suffered dehydration and the wildfire threatened one home.  In Monroe County, in Paradise Township, an afternoon brush fire consumed about six acres on Bush Road before it was contained.  The garage of one home was damaged.   ||The peak wind gusts on the 6th included 30 mph at the Philadelphia International Airport and Mount Pocono (Monroe County) and, 26 mph at the Lehigh Valley International Airport.
Dry fuels contributed to a fire that started in the Compass Pointe Division in Brunswick County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dry fuels contributed to a fire that started in the Compass Pointe Division in Brunswick County.  The fire started near railroad tracks east of post 354.  The fire burned a total of 465 acres, 400 of which were woodlands.  There were five homes damaged, and two structures destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire started from someone burning debris in Brunswick County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire started near Clemmons Road in Brunswick County due to debris burning.  The wildfire covered 1578 acres, with 667 acres of timber loss. An abandoned travel trailer and mobile home trailer were destroyed. There were no injuries or evacuations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Nearly a dozen brush fires occurred in Chester County on the 12th as an unseasonably dry April continued. They were reported from Oxford eastward to West Chester.  The largest wildfire occurred in West Fallowfield Township. One person was injured. Through April 12th, less than half an inch of rain has fallen during the month of April at the Philadelphia International Airport.

The Clearwater-Municipal consists of a group of fires in Clearwater, Idaho and Lewis Counties in northern Idaho. The fires, started by lightning, have been burning since approximately 1:15 pm on August 10th. Fire activity blew up Friday, August 14th, after a cold front brought in strong winds, spreading flames north of Kamiah along the Woodland Ridge and Frasure Ridge roads, east to the Caribel area and south to Nikesa Creek in Church Canyon.   This resulted in 42 destroyed homes and at least 79 outbuildings in Idaho county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: KREM news reported The Lawyer Complex has burned 42 homes and 75 other buildings, according to Northern Rockies Incident Management Team.  The National situation reported  118 structures lost (as of the last report 9/10/2015) with the cost of fighting the fire at 25 million dollars. The Idaho County Sheriff's Office says a woman died preparing for evacuations due to the Lawyer Complex Fire. She died Friday evening after falling and hitting her head.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Amidst windy and dry conditions, grass fires burned 347 acres in Murray county and 587 acres in Dewey county on the 4th.
The Scullin fire burned approximately 2100 acres in Murray county on the 18th.
The Hopewell fire burned approximately 200 acres in Murray county on the 19th.

Amidst windy and dry conditions, grass fires burned several thousand acres in Woods county and 725 acres across Blaine and Custer counties. The Woods county fire continued for about a week and spread into Comanche and Barber counties in Kansas, burning a total of 367,000 acres and destroying numerous structures and livestock.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Damages are a very rough estimate. Officials reported over 1,000 bales of hay, hundreds of miles of fence line and approximately 600 cattle lost in the Oklahoma portion of the fire. Kansas and Oklahoma officials reported 16 residential structures and 25 other minor structures were destroyed. There have been no reports of injuries or fatalities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Red Horse fire burned approximately 2549 acres in Woods county on the 18th.
Grass fires burned approximately 488 acres in Roger Mills county and 1010 acres in Woods county on the 6th.

The largest wildfire in Kansas recorded history started  northwest of Alva, OK but quickly moved into Comanche and Barber counties.  By the time it was contained, the fire had consumed nearly 275,000 acres in Kansas (and another 90,000 acres in Oklahoma).  There were 103 structures damaged or destroyed, including 76 homes (11 a total loss), with $706,000 in livestock loss and $27,000,000 in fencing.  Four bridges were destroyed. Fortunately there were no deaths or serous injuries.  It was the 10th largest wildfire in U.S. history.||Total cost (as of June 1) was $30,133,000 but that number may continue to rise.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The damage values were shared between Comanche and Barber counties.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure center and tight pressure gradient and eventually a deeply mixed boundary layer produced strong surface winds.  Winds also were very strong behind the associated cold front late in the day on the 6th.  Winds picked up again on the 7th fanning residual fires.  Many fires were started by downed power lines, many from weakened connections from the January ice storm.  The fire in Ford county was the result of a brush pile in Dodge City that had not been fully extinguished before the dry, warm winds began.  ||Statewide, grass fires shut down I-70 between Russell and Sylvan Grove, and fires were reported in Clark, Cheyenne, Commanche, Ellsworth, Hodgeman, Ford, Meade, Pratt, Rawlins, Rice, Reno, Smith, Stevens and Rooks counties. Residents of Wilson in central Kansas were told to evacuate homes due to fears of fire moving north of I-70.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Protection was evacuated twice but never had damage within the city limits.  Although the fires subsided late on the 6th, the fire flared again by late morning on the 7th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Amidst windy and dry conditions, grass fires burned 780 acres in Atoka county, 330 acres in Noble county, and 740 acres in Noble county on the 28th.
Amidst windy and dry conditions, grass fires burned 325 acres and an out-building in Seminole county as well as 400 acres in Garvin county on the 8th.
Grass fires burned 2100 acres in Seminole county on the 25th.
The Off Guard fire burned approximately 171 acres in Seminole county on the 21st.
The Snake Creek and Hog Field fires burned approximately 179 acres and 349 acres respectively in Seminole county on the 30th.

The Tokewanna Fire, located just on the Wyoming side of the Utah/Wyoming border,  started on July 28, and damaged several structures before it was contained. Note that this episode continued into August.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Tokewanna Fire was discovered on the afternoon of July 28, about 15 miles south of Mountain View, Wyoming. The fire burned approximately 1,300 acres and destroyed 8 structures in the Tokewanna Estates Subdivision. The fire forced the evacuation of 140 homes and the Uinta County Youth Camp, and also closed portions of Highways 271 and 410. One firefighter on the wildfire suffered burns from the fire. The fire was 100% contained as of 6 p.m. MDT Saturday, August 6.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Tokewanna Fire, located just on the Wyoming side of the Utah/Wyoming border,  started on July 28, and damaged several structures before it was contained. Note that this episode began in July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Tokewanna Fire was discovered on the afternoon of July 28, about 15 miles south of Mountain View, Wyoming. The fire burned approximately 1,300 acres and destroyed 8 structures in the Tokewanna Estates Subdivision. The fire forced the evacuation of 140 homes and the Uinta County Youth Camp, and also closed portions of Highways 271 and 410. One firefighter on the wildfire suffered burns from the fire. The fire was 100% contained as of 6 p.m. MDT Saturday, August 6.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Canyon Fire burned over 12,000 acres of land across Vandenberg Air Force Base.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Canyon Fire ignited on Vandenberg Air Force Base in Santa Barbara county. The fire burned 12,518 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Whit Fire exploded near Wapiti, Wyoming, about 12 miles west of Cody, on Tuesday, August 2. The fire grew to nearly 3,000 acres in size during the first 24 hours and evacuations were ordered for several areas. Active fire growth continued during the first week of August with the fire reaching nearly 10,000 acres by Friday morning, August 5. Approximately 700 people were assigned to the fire and aerial tactics were employed in an effort to slow the fire spread. Evacuations were lifted on Saturday morning, August 6. The fire was largely contained by Thursday, August 11, and basically out by August 18. All said, the Whit Fire torched 12,387 acres and destroyed one home and seven outbuildings. The cause of the fire was unknown.

Abnormally dry conditions throughout the fall season led to an increase in brushfires by the end of October. One of these fires in Bell County, near Beverly, became large enough for volunteer fire departments to begin battling.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A volunteer firefighter was injured battling a brushfire in Bell County near Beverly. He suffered head and arm injuries when a tree limb fell and struck him along with the fire apparatus he was on. He later passed away on November 17, 2016 after being hospitalized at Pikeville Medical Center.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Countless wildfires occurred throughout November across Harlan, Letcher, Knott, Bell, Breathitt, and Perry Counties in southeast Kentucky. ||The greatest number of fires and associated impacts were in Harlan County. The county Judge-Executive declared a state of emergency as numerous fires threatened homes and various other structures, including a 7,400 acre wildfire on Pine Mountain which closed Little Shepherds Trail from Swap to the entrance of Kingdom Come State Park for several days. A few outbuildings and an abandoned house were destroyed. Several other road blockages were reported throughout the month as wildfires continued to cause trees to topple over onto roadways, including Kentucky Highways 2005 and 179. Smoke reducing visibilities was also responsible for several road closures.||A large fire took place at Pine Mountain State Resort Park in Bell County. Crews had to use a pumper truck to keep the fire from spreading over the top of a mountain toward Pineville. The Eagles Nest Fire in Breathitt County burned for several days, endangering several homes. Power was knocked out to over 900 citizens in Perry County early in the month as the top support of a power pole was burned, causing the line to drop and the power circuit to fail. Reduced visibility in Letcher County caused a tanker truck carrying 8,400 gallons of gasoline to be involved in an accident. The tanker subsequently rolled over north of Highway 23 at Kentucky Highway 805, allowing 1,200 gallons of fuel to spill. A Knott County home near Topmost was consumed by fire near the end of the first week in November.||The vast majority of all ongoing wildfires were able to be contained on November 28th as increasing moisture and eventual rainfall helped extinguish them.

This Wednesday afternoon featured two notable wildfires in central Nebraska, the second and larger of which impacted southern Valley and northern Sherman counties within this 24-county area, ultimately scorching around 6,000 acres of pasture and crop land. Fortunately, no structural damage or injuries were reported.||This fire ignited around 1 PM in a rural area of far south central Valley County, a short distance southeast of the intersection of Nebraska Highways 22 and 70. Unfortunately, weather conditions were ripe for rapid fire spread and growth. Although relative humidity (RH) values averaged around 30% (slightly above official critical values), very strong northwest winds whipped the flames through dry grasses, with sustained speeds generally 25-35 MPH and frequent gusts to around 45 MPH. It didn't take long for the fire to jump over the county line into far northern Sherman County. Given that it was tracking toward the north side of Sherman Reservoir, several residences in the area were evacuated as a precaution. Fortunately, the fire was brought under control north of the reservoir by early evening before affecting any structures, thanks to the efforts of 13 rural fire departments and even one fire-fighting aircraft. This fire ended up consuming roughly 6,000 acres of dormant pasture and farm land as it traveled a relatively narrow, northwest-to-southeast path of 6-7 miles. On a side note, while only a small fraction of South Central Nebraska was directly impacted by this fire, a highly-visible and locally-thick smoke plume drifted at least 50-100 miles southeast during the afternoon, briefly reducing visibilities in many places, including the Hastings area.

The county Judge-Executive declared a state of emergency as numerous fires threatened homes and various other structures, including a 7,400 acre wildfire on Pine Mountain which closed Little Shepherds Trail from Swap to the entrance of Kingdom Come State Park for several days. A few outbuildings and an abandoned house were destroyed. Several other road blockages were reported throughout the month as wildfires continued to cause trees to topple over onto roadways, including Kentucky Highways 2005 and 179. Smoke reducing visibilities was also responsible for several road closures.||A large fire took place at Pine Mountain State Resort Park in Bell County. Crews had to use a pumper truck to keep the fire from spreading over the top of a mountain toward Pineville. Reduced visibility in Letcher County caused a tanker truck carrying 8,400 gallons of gasoline to be involved in an accident. The tanker subsequently rolled over north of Highway 23 at Kentucky Highway 805, allowing 1,200 gallons of fuel to spill. A Knott County home near Topmost was consumed by fire near the end of the first week in November.||The vast majority of all ongoing wildfires were able to be contained on November 28th as increasing moisture and eventual rainfall helped extinguish them.

As hot and dry September conditions continued into the middle of the month, one notable wildfire occurred in Perry County in mid September near Sassafras and Vicco. The fire got close to a home as it spread into kudzu near the home.

Countless wildfires occurred throughout November across Harlan, Letcher, Knott, Bell, Breathitt, and Perry Counties in southeast Kentucky. ||The greatest number of fires and associated impacts were in Harlan County. The county Judge-Executive declared a state of emergency as numerous fires threatened homes and various other structures, including a 7,400 acre wildfire on Pine Mountain which closed Little Shepherds Trail from Swap to the entrance of Kingdom Come State Park for several days. A few outbuildings and an abandoned house were destroyed. Several other road blockages were reported throughout the month as wildfires continued to cause trees to topple over onto roadways, including Kentucky Highways 2005 and 179. Smoke reducing visibilities was also responsible for several road closures.||A large fire took place at Pine Mountain State Resort Park in Bell County. Crews had to use a pumper truck to keep the fire from spreading over the top of a mountain toward Pineville. The Eagles Nest Fire in Breathitt County burned for several days, endangering several homes. Power was knocked out to over 900 citizens in Perry County early in the month as the top support of a power pole was burned, causing the line to drop and the power circuit to fail. Reduced visibility in Letcher County caused a tanker truck carrying 8,400 gallons of gasoline to be involved in an accident. The tanker subsequently rolled over north of Highway 23 at Kentucky Highway 805, allowing 1,200 gallons of fuel to spill. A Knott County home near Topmost was consumed by fire near the end of the first week in November.||The vast majority of all ongoing wildfires were able to be contained on November 28th as increasing moisture and eventual rainfall helped extinguish them.

Severe drought led to a prolonged wildfire in the Red River Gorge near Tunnel Ridge Road, north of Mountain Parkway. On the morning of November 16th, near-zero visibilities developed on Mountain Parkway just east of the Slade exit as smoke became extremely dense at ground level. A 12 car pileup resulted, injuring approximately 20 people and causing one fatality as a man stepped out of his coal truck to help others. Mountain Parkway was closed for over 10 hours between exits 22 and 40.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On the morning of November 16th, near-zero visibilities developed on Mountain Parkway just east of the Slade exit as smoke became extremely dense at ground level. A 12 car pileup resulted, injuring approximately 20 people and causing one fatality as a man stepped out of his coal truck to help others. Mountain Parkway was closed for over 10 hours between exits 22 and 40.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire started by a lightning strike on Poverty Island just south of the Garden Peninsula burned ten acres over the first couple weeks of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire started by a lightning strike on Poverty Island consumed about 50 acres of land during the month.  The Bureau of Indian Affairs responded to the blaze and were assisted by the U.S. Forest Service and the Michigan DNR.  The fire continued into early August and threatened Poverty Island's historic lighthouse.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong downslope winds combined with a hot dry airmass resulted in extreme fire behavior. It is speculated that above normal winter rains yielded abundant fuels that became primed for rapid intense fire spread by late summer and early fall.
Amidst windy and dry conditions, grass fires burned 2000 acres in Jefferson county on the 5th.

Near record high temperatures ahead of a cold front sent relative humidity to near 30 percent. A wildfire started in these conditions at 7237 N. Hwy 80 in Nixon and consumed 10 acres destroying an outbuilding which contained a vehicle and farm equipment.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Near record high temperatures ahead of a cold front sent relative humidity to near 30 percent. A wildfire started in these conditions at 7237 N. Hwy 80 in Nixon and consumed 10 acres destroying an outbuilding which contained a vehicle and farm equipment.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large wildfire began in Cheyenne County Kansas on this day. Persistent drought and windy conditions made the fire difficult to contain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large fire began near Wheeler, KS. Fire conditions were poor due to persistent drought and breezy/windy conditions. Fire burned approximately 700 acres. No structures were threatened. Times are approximate.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds developed behind a strong cold front most of the day.  Wind gusts up to 65 MPH were reported during the day.  The strongest wind gust occurred in Goodland and was based on roof damage of a mobile home.  The high winds caused at least four semis to be blown over on I-70 and caused some blowing dust. In addition, high winds caused a fire rekindle in Cheyenne County and a new fire to burn farm structures and equipment near Herndon in Rawlins County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This fire occurred north to northeast of Wheeler, Kansas. The fire was a rekindle from a fire from the previous day. Two farmsteads were threatened but saved. Fire burned approximately 800 acres for a total burned area from 3/5 to 3/6 of around 1500 acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire which started in Cheyenne County, KS during elevated fire weather conditions quickly spread throughout the northeast portions of the county, requiring the response of local, state, and federal agencies to fight the fire. Local emergency management found several ignition points along and east of KS Hwy 27 in northwest Kansas. Prevailing winds from the southwest thankfully prevented the fire from spreading into the nearby towns of St. Francis and Wheeler, KS. Initial response from local city and county fire departments had to be quickly supplemented with support from the Kansas Department of Emergency Management, the Kansas National Guard, and the National Weather Service. By the time the fire was fully extinguished on November 10th, around six thousand acres of mainly grassland had been burned by the Cherry Creek fire according to estimates from local emergency management. A state disaster declaration was made by Kansas Governor Laura Kelly in order to aid response operations. No significant structures are known to have burned as a result of this wildfire, however some damage was done to a small cemetery near Wheeler when grasses burned through that area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The start time of the wildfire complex, around 1130 AM CST, was based on radar observations of smoke plumes which were present for several hours on Saturday, November 9th. Over 31 fire starts occurred along Highways 27 and 36, consuming an estimated total of 6,000 acres. Local, state, and federal agencies were involved in the response to the fire through the following day, Sunday, November 10th. NWS Goodland provided on-site support starting the morning of November 10th to protect the property and personnel for the ongoing response.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and dry conditions during the month resulted in two significant wildfires in Southern California. The Alamo fire burned 28,687 acres while the Whittier fire burned 18, 430 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Alamo Fire burned 28,687 acres in San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara counties. One home was destroyed by the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure center and tight pressure gradient and eventually a deeply mixed boundary layer produced strong surface winds.  Winds also were very strong behind the associated cold front late in the day on the 6th.  Winds picked up again on the 7th fanning residual fires.  Many fires were started by downed power lines, many from weakened connections from the January ice storm.  The fire in Ford county was the result of a brush pile in Dodge City that had not been fully extinguished before the dry, warm winds began.  ||Statewide, grass fires shut down I-70 between Russell and Sylvan Grove, and fires were reported in Clark, Cheyenne, Commanche, Ellsworth, Hodgeman, Ford, Meade, Pratt, Rawlins, Rice, Reno, Smith, Stevens and Rooks counties. Residents of Wilson in central Kansas were told to evacuate homes due to fears of fire moving north of I-70.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At least a dozen structures were destroyed by the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Grass fires burned 512 acres in Pottawatomie county and 480 acres in Coal county on the 20th.
The Sand Creek Fire burned approximately 200 acres in Coal county on the 25th.
Grass fires burned approximately 1133 acres in Coal county on the 20th.
Grass fires burned approximately 1138 acres in Coal county on the 24th.

High winds occurred behind a cold front on this Monday afternoon. Northwest winds were sustained between 30 and 40 mph. Wind gusts between 45 and 55 mph were common. The highest gust observed was 59 mph near Lebanon. Blowing dust was visible everywhere, generally reducing the visibility to 3 to 7 miles. Satellite imagery showed the dust originated in eastern Colorado, and it was transported northeastward just ahead of a cold front. However, winds behind the front picked up additional dust. These high winds combined with extremely low relative humidity (RH) values to create dangerous fire weather conditions. Afternoon minimum RH values were between 7 and 15%. A significant wildfire occurred in Rooks County, very close to Stockton.||At dawn, a deep low pressure system (983 mb) was over South Dakota with a warm front extending east into the Great Lakes, and a cold front extending southwest to Arizona. A dryline extended south into the warm sector, through western Kansas to New Mexico. As the day progressed, both the dryline and cold front swept through the region as the low occluded and deepened further to 978 mb. In the upper-levels, a trough was over the Western U.S., with a ridge in the East. During the day, a strong shortwave trough over Utah lifted northeast out of the base of the western trough and into Nebraska and South Dakota.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This fire started shortly before noon CST on March 6th about 3 miles west-southwest of Stockton. The fire spread east, getting within a mile of southern portions of Stockton, also threatening storage tanks of diesel fuel and fertilizer. A frontal boundary passed through, switched wind direction and pushed the fire just off to the southeast. In total, this fire burned approximately 10,000 acres before being extinguished about 3 miles south-southeast of Stockton. One home was destroyed by the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire occurred east of Webster State Park on this Friday afternoon. This fire started on Highway 24 between county roads 11 and 12, and then spread approximately 5 miles to the southeast. The fire was contained by 8 PM, though crews monitored hot spots into the next day. A faulty lightning arrester on a power pole was suspected as the cause of the fire. A portion of Highway 183 was closed for a time, and mutual aid was provided from neighboring counties as well as private companies and farmers. The city of Stockton issued an evacuation order for the south part of town.||An anomalously warm air mass was in place, and the region was in the warm sector of a low pressure center over Ontario, Canada. A very weak cold front extended southwest from the low across the Northern Plains at 6 AM CST. This front was moving rapidly south, and it crossed Rooks County around noon. Northwest winds increased significantly behind the front. The peak wind gust at the Stockton airport was 55 mph measured at 1:02 PM CST. A high temperature in the lower 80s occurred just after frontal passage, and this was over 30 degrees above normal. A record high of 83 occurred at Hill City, one county to the west. With dewpoints falling into the lower 30s, this resulted in relative humidity values in the middle to upper teens.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This wildfire burned approximately 3,500 acres, spread across an area from roughly 5 miles southeast of Webster State Park to 3 miles east of Webster State Park. Damage from the wildfire included one hunting cabin being burned down, siding melted on the side of a barn and fencing damage. Three homes were threatened, but were not damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions combined with gusty winds to create a couple of large wildfires across Northeast Arkansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire occurred off County Road 511 in Portia. Approximately 300 acres were burned. One seasonal hunting house was destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds on the backside of an upper level storm system reached the ground in Hitchcock and Red Willow counties.  The peak wind gust was 66 MPH at McCook.  The high winds also fueled a wildfire which consumed a house on the north side of McCook.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The high winds caused a piece of metal roofing to touch an overhead power line, igniting the fire three miles northwest of McCook.  The high winds pushed the fire in a southerly direction, burning 212 acres.  Evacuations were ordered for the northwest part of McCook totaling 446 people.  McCook elementary school students were moved to the high school.  Sixteen people were treated for burns and smoke inhalation.  The only severe burn victim was a transient living in a canyon.  One home on the north edge of McCook was destroyed by the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With dry high pressure across southeast Georgia and well below normal rainfall for the month, a small brush fire damaged two homes near Metter.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Metter Fire Department reported that a small brush fire damaged two homes near Lauren Lane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire broke out during the afternoon of April 29th near the Bruce Mound Winter Sports Area in southwest Clark County. The fire consumed 89 acres of mainly county lands and a small amount of private property. No structures were lost in the fire but several were threatened. Residents near the fire were evacuated. The cause of the fire was determined to be improper burning of debris. A Red Flag Warning had been issued due the combination of warm temperatures, low relative humidity, high winds and plenty of available dry tinder to burn.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire near the Bruce Mound Winter Sports Area burned 89 acres of mainly public land. No structures were lost in the fire, although several were threatened. Residents near the fire were evacuated. The cause of the fire was determined to be improper burning of debris.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought high winds, blowing dust, and a wildfire to Northwest Kansas. The high winds led to some wind damage across the area. In addition, the winds caused widespread blowing dust with zero visibility, which resulted in at least 2 accidents on area roadways. Finally, as the winds brought down power lines in Weskan, a wildfire began and rapidly spread.  The fire was so large that fire departments from neighboring counties were asked to respond.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wildfire started just north of the town of Weskan. Cause was power lines snapped due to high winds with the cold front. Fire ran 7 miles to the southeast and reached approximately three quarters of a mile wide at times. Fire was detected by GOES-16 imagery as well as radar. At least two structures were lost along with numerous power poles. Damage to railroad and railroad bridge also noticed by NWS Employee passing through a few days later.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire developed between Hugoton and Moscow as the result of a cotton gin fire that got out of control.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The fire did not consume any structures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several major wildfires were sparked on the 12th. Most significantly (in terms of size/extent) were the Rhea fire (mainly Dewey county, but also affecting Woodward and Custer counties), burning 286,196 acres, causing 1 fatality and 3 injuries (including a burnover of a truck), and destroying 50 structures before it was contained on the 25th; and the 34 Complex (mainly Woodward county), burning 62,481 acres, causing 4 injuries, and destroying 33 structures before it was contained on the 24th; and the Shaw fire (Roger Mills county) burning 7,257 acres and causing 1 fatality and 1 injury.||The Rhea fire fatality was near seiling where a 62 year old woman died inside her vehicle on the 14th. The Shaw fire fatality was a a 61 year old man who died on the 12th as a result of burn injuries.||Other notable fires include the East Reydon fire (1,232 acres in Roger Mills County), and the Roadside fire (916 acres in Woodward county). On the 13th, the Dollar Pond fire burned 257 acres and destroyed 1 structure in Caddo county. On the 14th, the Martha fire burned 33 acres, caused 2 injuries, and destroyed 24 structures in Jackson county.
A wildfire burned roughly 650 acres about 7 miles west of Anadarko on the 9th, with no damage being reported.
The 308 Wildfire burned 1200 acres from July 18th until the 24th in Llano County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 308 Wildfire burned 1200 acres from July 18th until the 24th in Llano County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Cap Fire started July 23 one mile west of CR-413 and three miles north of Hwy-16 in Llano County. The fire burned 351 acres before it was contained on July 24.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cap Fire started July 23 one mile west of CR-413 and three miles north of Hwy-16 in Llano County. The fire burned 351 acres before it was contained on July 24.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Grass fires burned approximately 300 acres in Archer county on the 5th. A structure was threatened.

A wildfire began on July 15th 5 miles east of Sage Junction south of Highway 33 due to exploding targets from gunfire practice.   It was near Menan Butte.   The fire grew to around 1,000 acres over grass and brush.  Highway 33 was closed for a short time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire began on July 15th 5 miles east of Sage Junction south of Highway 33 due to exploding targets from gunfire practice.   It was near Menan Butte.   The fire grew to around 1,000 acres over grass and brush.  Highway 33 was closed for a short time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The 600 acre Twin BUtte Fire started 5 miles west of Rexburg south of Highway 33 near Menan BUtte.  It was a grass and brush fire and Highway 33 was closed for a short time.   The fire began at around 1:45 MDT on July 24th.  No structures were threatened.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 600 acre Twin Butte Fire started 5 miles west of Rexburg south of Highway 33 near Menan BUtte.  It was a grass and brush fire and Highway 33 was closed for a short time.   The fire began at around 1:45 MDT on July 24th.  No structures were threatened.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning induced fire began on July 16th north of the St Anthony Sand Dunes and grew to over 4,300 acres in grass and brush .
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A lightning induced fire began on July 16th north of the St Anthony Sand Dunes and grew to over 4,300 acres in grass and brush .

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Desert Ride Fire about 12 miles west of Rexburg began August 11th and was human caused. West winds of 15 to 20 mph caused the grass and brush fire to grow to 7,500 acres in the Menan Butte area and was caused by a man shooting a 22 caliber rifle at a firework on the ground causing it to ignite. The fire was contained on August 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Desert Ride Fire about 12 miles west of Rexburg began August 11th and was human caused. West winds of 15 to 20 mph caused the grass and brush fire to grow to 7,500 acres in the Menan Butte area and was caused by a man shooting a 22 caliber rifle at a firework on the ground causing it to ignite. The fire was contained on August 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The twenty mile fire began on July 12th at around 8:30 pm MDT just over 20 miles west of Idaho Falls.   It was caused by lightning and burned around 200 acres of grash and brush.  No structures were threatened with no closures or evacuations.  It was controlled by July 14th.   Rain on the 13th helped with containment.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The twenty mile fire began on July 12th at around 8:30 pm MDT just over 20 miles west of Idaho Falls.   It was caused by lightning and burned around 200 acres of grash and brush.  No structures were threatened with no closures or evacuations.  It was controlled by July 14th.   Rain on the 13th helped with containment.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The North Heglar fire was induced by lightning on July 16th and grew to 2,300 acres 24 miles southeast of the interstate 84/86 interchange.   IT was grass, brush and timber with some structures threatened.   North Heglar Road and Mill Flat Campground were closed to the public.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The North Heglar fire was induced by lightning on July 16th and grew to 2,300 acres 24 miles southeast of the interstate 84/86 interchange.   IT was grass, brush and timber with some structures threatened.   North Heglar Road and Mill Flat Campground were closed to the public.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fire which was an escaped agricultural burn grew to 13,500 acres 4 miles southeast of Malta.  It began September 22nd and was controlled don September 27th.   It burned grass, brush and timber but caused no structural damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A fire which was an escaped agricultural burn grew to 13,500 acres 4 miles southeast of Malta.  It began September 22nd and was controlled don September 27th.   It burned grass, brush and timber but caused no structural damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Indian Butte wildfire began September 12th at around 6 pm MDT and burned 13,072 acres in Clark County.   It began on Indian Creek Road 9 miles northwest of Dubois and was human caused.  Dry Creek road and a portion of Pleasant valley Road were closed.    Campers were evacuated on the 13th in the Dry Creek and Pleasant Valley area.  One home was evacuated on the 12th but did not get damaged.  The fire burned in grass, brush and timber.   The fire was considered 100 percent contained on September 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Indian Butte wildfire began September 12th at around 6 pm MDT and burned 13,072 acres in Clark County.   It began on Indian Creek Road 9 miles northwest of Dubois and was human caused.  Dry Creek road and a portion of Pleasant valley Road were closed.    Campers were evacuated on the 13th in the Dry Creek and Pleasant Valley area.  One home was evacuated on the 12th but did not get damaged.  The fire burned in grass, brush and timber.   The fire was considered 100 percent contained on September 20th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire began from unknown causes about 16 miles southeast of Meeker.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cabin Lake Fire began in late July from unknown causes about 16 miles southeast of Meeker and grew to 5,975 acres before it was contained in early October.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire began from unknown causes about 15 miles northeast of Meeker.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The James Fire began from unknown causes about 15 miles northeast of Meeker and grew to 324 acres before it was contained in early September.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike ignited a wildfire about 5 miles north of Meeker.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sulphur Fire began due to lightning ignition about 5 miles north of Meeker and grew to a total of 977 acres before it was contained.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cabin Lake Fire began from unknown causes about 16 miles southeast of Meeker and grew to 5,975 acres before it was contained in early October.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike most likely ignited a wildfire 16 miles southwest of Hayden.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Indian Run Fire began in mid August, most likely due to lightning, 16 miles southwest of Hayden and grew to approximately 170 acres before it was contained within a week.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extremely dry and windy conditions, combined with critically dry vegetation, led to an uncontrolled wildfire 30 miles northeast of Meeker that lasted for several days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Wyman Fire began on April 30th, 30 miles northeast of Meeker. It grew to 455 acres before it was contained a few days later on May 2nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Sharps fire began by human cause on July 29th via exploding targets.   It continued through a good part of August and grew to 64,853 acres and located approximately 6 miles east of Bellevue on Sharps Canyon Road. The BLM closed public lands in and around the Sharps fire in Blaine County. This included all BLM-managed lands east of Highway 75, south of East Fork Road, then south of the Sawtooth National Forest Boundary, west of Fish Creek Road, and north of US Highway 20, and east of Gannett Road.   Other closures were the following:  Muldoon Canyon Road is closed from EE-DA-HO Ranch (east of Bellevue). East Fork Road is closed at Triumph. Little Wood Reservoir Road is closed at the Hunt Lane. Quigley, Slaughterhouse Creek Roads, Indian Creek, and Ohio Gulch Roads are closed where the pavement ends. High Five, Road Canyon Road and Baugh Creek, are also closed.   No structures were damaged.  Mandatory evacuations were ordered for Little Wood recreation Area campground and all residences on Little Wood Reservoir Road and Flat Top Road north of the reservoir.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sharps fire began by human cause on July 29th via exploding targets.   It continued through a good part of August and grew to 64,853 acres and located approximately 6 miles east of Bellevue on Sharps Canyon Road. The BLM closed public lands in and around the Sharps fire in Blaine County. This included all BLM-managed lands east of Highway 75, south of East Fork Road, then south of the Sawtooth National Forest Boundary, west of Fish Creek Road, and north of US Highway 20, and east of Gannett Road.   Other closures were the following:  Muldoon Canyon Road is closed from EE-DA-HO Ranch (east of Bellevue). East Fork Road is closed at Triumph. Little Wood Reservoir Road is closed at the Hunt Lane. Quigley, Slaughterhouse Creek Roads, Indian Creek, and Ohio Gulch Roads are closed where the pavement ends. High Five, Road Canyon Road and Baugh Creek, are also closed.   No structures were damaged.  Mandatory evacuations were ordered for Little Wood recreation Area campground and all residences on Little Wood Reservoir Road and Flat Top Road north of the reservoir.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Fruitland Shed Fire began on June 27 in the city of Fruitland and was contained on June 28.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Fruitland Shed Fire was a human-caused wildfire that began on June 27 in the city of Fruitland and was contained on June 28. The fire burned 20 acres and destroyed seven structures, including two permanent residences. Two people were treated for smoke inhalation in association with the fire, including a firefighter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 500 acre wildfire occurred over Massacre Rocks about 5 to 10 miles southeast of American Falls. on June 9th and 10th.   The fire was driven by wind gusts of 40 mph and spread rapidly.   Cooler temperatures and lighter winds slowed growth and it was contained quickly over open land.   No structures were threatened.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 500 acre wildfire occurred over Massacre Rocks about 5 to 10 miles southeast of American Falls. on June 9th and 10th.   The fire was driven by wind gusts of 40 mph and spread rapidly.   Cooler temperatures and lighter winds slowed growth and it was contained quickly over open land.   No structures were threatened.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning caused an 8,272 acre fire 7 miles north of Raft River on BLM property.  It was a grass and brush fire that began on July 6th at around 3 pm MDT.  It was controlled on July 8th with no structures threatened and no evacuations required.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning caused an 8,272 acre fire 7 miles north of Raft River on BLM property.  It was a grass and brush fire that began on July 6th at around 3 pm MDT.  It was controlled on July 8th with no structures threatened and no evacuations required.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extremely moist airmass remained in place that provided fuel for numerous afternoon and early evening thunderstorms, especially for locations west of I-95 and the St. Johns River basin after 4 pm toward the I-75 corridor where afternoon and evening sea breeze and outflow mergers occurred under light westerly steering flow (< 5 kts).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire of unknown size was started by lightning near Hunt Club Road and Biggin Church Road, just south of Beach Blvd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wildfire potential was elevated across portions of SE GA and NE FL due to recent rainfall deficits and low ground moisture. Record high temperatures and an extended period of low afternoon humidity created an elevated fire danger despite not meeting locally defined Red Flag Conditions. Isolated storms created lightning start fires, including the Perimeter Fire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two wildfires started along U.S. Highway 17 near the Nassau River off of Yellow Bluff Road. On May 22 around 345 pm, one fire was 100% contained with only 25% on the larger southernmost fire which was estimated at 150 acres just north of Yellow Bluff Road. The Yellow Bluff fire spread northwest and portions of Interstate 95 between Interstate 95 near mile marker 368. The right northbound lane of I-95 was closed due to the proximity of the wildfire. At 3:28 pm on 5/23, the Yellow Bluff fire was about 400 acres. Both lanes of I-95 were closed between mile markers 366 and 373 due to the proximity of the fire and smoke blowing over the interstate. The fire did spot on the west side of I-95 Florida Highway Partrol. Around 213 pm on 5/24, the fire was up to 600 acres in size and was about 30% contained. All lanes of Interstate 95 were re-opened except of the right northbound lane for fire emergency vehicle staging. Around 7:30 pm on 5/29, the fire was about 80% contained and was about 604 acres and holding with minimal smoke impacts to Interstate 95.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 2100 acre range fire tracked across far southwestern Chase county during the afternoon and early evening hours of October 26th.  The fire was started by a combine and quickly moved south approximately 3 miles, burning approximately 2100 acres of grassland.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A fire was started by a combine 1/2 mile south of the intersection of Road 729 and Avenue 315 in SW Chase county.  Aided by 30 MPH northerly winds, the fire raced south and south southeast burning approximately 2100 acres before it was extinguished.  A fire truck was damaged and two garages were destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm, dry and breezy conditions across the Mid-South help set the stage for a wildfire in Tipton County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several hundred acres burned in a cut corn field near Bride Road between Leighs Chapel and Mt. Lebanon Road. An estimated 300-500 acres burned. More than 60 firefighters worked for 8 hours to contain the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Copper Breaks fire burned roughly 7,200 acres of land and cost nearly 2.2 million dollars in damage and for fire suppression.
A wildfire burned roughly 8,275 acres and destroyed 1 outbuilding. The town of Fargo was also evacuated.
A campfire sparked a 600 acre range fire at the Nebraska National Forest on November 16th. The fire consumed mainly grassland and did not move into forested areas of the National Forest.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A grass fire started approximately 12 miles east southeast of Thedford during the early evening hours of November 16th. The fire consumed approximately 600 acres of grassland and was extinguished later that night.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds, low relative humidity levels and dry vegetation led to an extreme fire danger. Several grass fires were reported during the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A rapidly moving grass fire near 168th and Buffalo Rd lead to an evacuation of the Meadow Oaks neighborhood (46 Homes). Buffalo Rd was also closed for a period of time. The fire was under control by 3:30 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds gradually decrease during the afternoon hours over north-central Montana as daylight diminishes and winds aloft begin to relax some. Until then still expect significant impacts across areas with strongest winds including wind damage, reduced |visibility in blowing dust and critical fire weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadwater County des reported a fast-moving fire in Confederate Gulch, approx 3 miles ne of mt-284 at 200pm. Reported out at 645pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds gradually decrease during the afternoon hours over north-central Montana as daylight diminishes and winds aloft begin to relax some. Until then still expect significant impacts across areas with strongest winds including wind damage, reduced |visibility in blowing dust and critical fire weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Grassland fire detected on satellite around 440pm and confirmed by dispatch.
